urn:contentItem:6FX2-55S3-S21W-400T-00000-00Trump's distraction machine is working2025-05-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisTrump's distraction machine is working

Trump continues to win the information war and Democrats, the media and the American people are left overwhelmed

Link to Image

There was a menacing cloud hanging over Chicago as I walked down Michigan Avenue the other day. It slowly descended. At first, I thought the cloud was fog, but the air was not damp. I continued walking. I noticed people were covering their mouths and noses with their shirts or jackets. Some of them were coughing. I chose to breathe deeply. My throat was not itching. My eyes were not burning. I breathed deeply again. I wondered, is the air full of incinerated medical waste? Asbestos or some other poison that will give me cancer? Smoke from a forest fire miles away? Was HAARP or some other weather control device that the conspiracy theorists have long been obsessed with malfunctioning? I laughed out loud.

I then asked myself: Given how bad things are in America right now, what is the worst that can possibly happen to me from this bad air? I quickly realized the answer: a lot. So I covered my mouth and nose like everyone else.

Eventually, my phone buzzed with a weather alert. Chicago was experiencing a historic dust storm. In the Middle East, such a storm is called a "haboob." I walked several more blocks and looked up at Trump Tower. The dust cloud was now hovering below the huge "Trump Tower" sign. I smiled at the absurdity and power of the metaphor that is the Age of Trump and its oppressive toxicity that has confused and disoriented so many Americans.

Donald Trump is a master propagandist and agent of chaos and distraction with power and influence over a vast propaganda and disinformation machine. Trump's ability to dominate the 24/7 media and this age of spectacle is likely unprecedented in modern (if not all of) American history. He is a defining personality and character of this era.

In a 2023 conversation, Lee McIntyre, author of the book "On Disinformation: How to Fight for Truth and Protect Democracy," explained to me: "I doubt that Trump has ever taken a course in psyops or that he reads disinformation training manuals in his spare time, but he is nonetheless a master, near-genius-level propagandist. He uses the exact same techniques of disinformation on an American audience that Putin uses on his citizens."

When Donald Trump, his MAGA Republicans and the larger antidemocracy movement encounter difficulties with their "shock and awe" campaign and blitzkrieg against American democracy and society, they amplify the power and reach of their disinformation and propaganda experience machine. The mainstream news media, the Democrats and other members of the responsible political class (and many among the general public) have been conditioned to respond almost like Pavlov's dogs. They chase the newest outrage or spectacle and react like it is a surprise instead of focusing on the bigger picture and goals that these controversies and "shocking" events are advancing and/or hiding.

In a recent New York Times opinion essay, Ezra Klein explained how disorientation and a lack of focus are the intended outcome of Donald Trump and his agents' "flooding the zone" strategy and tactic:

Focus is the fundamental substance of democracy. It is particularly the substance of opposition. People largely learn of what the government is doing through the media - be it mainstream media or social media. If you overwhelm the media - if you give it too many places it needs to look, all at once, if you keep it moving from one thing to the next - no coherent opposition can emerge. It is hard to even think coherently....

The flood is the point. The overwhelm is the point. The message wasn't in any one executive order or announcement. It was in the cumulative effect of all of them. The sense that this is Trump's country now. This is his government now. It follows his will. It does what he wants. If Trump tells the state to stop spending money, the money stops. If he says that birthright citizenship is over, it's over.

Or so he wants you to think. In Trump's first term, we were told: Don't normalize him. In his second, the task is different: Don't believe him.

Trump knows the power of marketing. If you make people believe something is true, you make it likelier that it becomes true...

It is a strategy that forces you into overreach. To keep the zone flooded, you have to keep acting, keep moving, keep creating new cycles of outrage or fear. You overwhelm yourself. And there's only so much you can do through executive orders. Soon enough, you have to go beyond what you can actually do. And when you do that, you either trigger a constitutional crisis or you reveal your own weakness.

Trump's "big beautiful bill" is set to take trillions of dollars away from the American people and give it to the richest people and corporations. If enacted, it will be one of the largest - if not the largest - transfers of wealth in American history and further gut the social safety net. Trump's "big beautiful bill" is unpopular with the American people and would likely trigger a huge backlash - given any sustained attention.

While the GOP-controlled House passed Trump's bill, the media's attention was mostly focused on Trump's "gifted" 400-million-dollar jetliner, a literal flying palace and king's court, from the government of Qatar. This is part of a much larger pattern of conflict of interests and corrupt power in apparent violation of the Constitution's Emoluments Clause and other ethics laws in which Donald Trump, his family and inner circle have leveraged the office of the presidency for personal enrichment.

Meanwhile, the United States Supreme Court has ordered a pause on Trump's mass deportation program under the Alien Enemies Act. There have been a series of lower court rulings that have also ordered a pause or outright stop to key parts of the Trump administration's actions and policies. A series of public opinion polls recently showed that Trump's support at this point in his presidency among the American people has collapsed at a rate not seen in 80 years. However, new public opinion polls show that Trump's support may have stabilized and is crawling back to his ceiling of approximately 45% to 47%. In total, Donald Trump's policies and behavior remain widely unpopular.

Donald Trump's historic global tariff regime has not created a new "golden age" for the United States and the American people. Leading economists and other business leaders continue to warn that the shocks from Trump's tariffs will cause disruptions to the economy if not a recession (or worse). Moody's has downgraded the credit-rating of the United States from AAA (the highest level).

Donald Trump and his administration's foreign policy -- and his brand as a "dealmaker" - continues to falter. Most notably, the war in Ukraine continues and the United States' role as the world's leading democracy and an indispensable nation has been greatly diminished in just the first four months of Trump's return to power.

Trump and his agents responded by turning their firehose of distraction, falsehoods and spectacle on full blast. The water is rising very quickly.

In a recent Truth Social post, Donald Trump continued his attacks against singer Taylor Swift ("Has anyone noticed that, since I said 'I HATE TAYLOR SWIFT,' she's no longer 'HOT?'"). He also turned his rage against Bruce Springsteen, Beyonce, Bono and Oprah Winfrey by accusing them of being part of a vast anti-Trump conspiracy. On Wednesday, Trump shared a video on his Truth Social platform of him hitting Bruce Springsteen with a golf ball that then causes the singer to stumble on stage.

MSNBC's Steven Benen sorts through Trump's conspiracy theories and warns:

To the extent that reality still has any meaning in situations like this, let's just briefly note that there's literally no evidence of Harris or her campaign paying anyone for endorsements; there was nothing "unlawful" or "corrupt" about the support the then-Democratic nominee received from celebrities during the 2024 campaign; Beyonc � did not face "loud booing" after she endorsed Harris; and there's nothing "illegal" about public figures publicly backing a presidential candidate.

It's also probably worth mentioning in passing that Trump's hysterical online communications don't do any favors to his "very stable genius" description of himself.

But of particular interest was the president's interest in "a major investigation into this matter."

All things considered, there's no reason to get too worked up about every Trump tantrum, his rage toward celebrities who've dared to criticize him, his weird approach to pop culture, or his use of the word "illegal" as a synonym for "stuff I don't like." What I do care about, however, is the president's willingness to use the power of the state to pursue critics in authoritarian-style fashion.

This is especially true now with the Justice Department led by an attorney general who apparently sees herself as an extension of the White House and its political agenda - which raises the prospect of a federal investigator actually initiating a probe into celebrities that Trump doesn't like.

Trump also shared an AI-generated video of himself as a member of the rock band Journey playing their iconic song "Don't Stop Believing" before a huge crowd of his MAGA people. In keeping with his drive for unlimited power, Trump also recently shared a series of AI-generated images of himself as the new Pope and a Sith Lord or other supremely powerful evil Jedi from George Lucas' "Star Wars" universe.

Relatedly, former FBI director James Comey posted an image on the social media platform Instagram of the numbers "86 47" formed from seashells on a beach. Trump responded that Comey was making a coded threat against his life ("Eighty-six" is slang for "replace" or "get rid of"; Donald Trump is the 47th president of the United States). The MAGA chorus dutifully amplified Trump's paranoid conclusions. The Secret Service is now investigating Comey's alleged threat against Donald Trump. Comey has responded that this is all so much nonsense, and he was just sharing an image of seashells on the beach.

In her newsletter, historian Heather Cox Richardson offered this contextfor Donald Trump and his forces' coordinated distraction campaign and attempts to dominate the information space:

[R]etired entrepreneur Bill Southworth tallied the times Trump has grabbed headlines to distract people from larger stories, starting the tally with how Trump's posts about Peanut the Squirrel the day before the election swept like a brushfire across the right-wing media ecosystem and then into the mainstream. In early 2025, Southworth notes, as the media began to dig into the dramatic restructuring of the federal government, Trump posted outrageously about Gaza, and that story took over. When cuts to PEPFAR (the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief) and the U.S. Agency for International Development threatened lives across Africa, Trump turned the conversation to white South Africans he lied were fleeing "anti-white genocide."

Southworth calls this "narrative warfare," and while it is true that Republican leaders have seeded a particular false narrative for decades now, this technique is also known as "political technology" or "virtual politics." This system, pioneered in Russia under Russian president Vladimir Putin, is designed to get people to vote an authoritarian into office by creating a fake world of outrage. For those who do not buy the lies, there is another tool: flooding the zone so that people stop being able to figure out what is real and tune out.

The administration has clearly adopted this plan. As Drew Harwell and Sarah Ellison of the Washington Post noted in early March, the administration set out to portray Trump as a king in order "to sell the country on [Trump's] expansionist approach to presidential power."

Richardson adds:

Dominating means controlling the narrative. That starts with perceptions of the president himself. Trump's appearances have been deeply concerning as he cannot follow a coherent thread, frequently falls asleep, repeatedly veers into nonsense, and says he doesn't know about the operations of his government.

Donald Trump and his forces' ability to "flood the zone" as part of their larger propaganda and disinformation campaign is not some "unknown unknown," a mystery, an impenetrable black box, a form of magic or a supernatural power. Information about how to effectively counter such strategies and tactics is readily available to almost anyone who wants to seek it out.

Want a daily wrap-up of all the news and commentary Salon has to offer? Subscribe to our morning newsletter, Crash Course.

For example, a free 2016 report from the Rand organization offers this advice:

We are not optimistic about the effectiveness of traditional counterpropaganda efforts. Certainly, some effort must be made to point out falsehoods and inconsistencies, but the same psychological evidence that shows how falsehood and inconsistency gain traction also tells us that retractions and refutations are seldom effective. Especially after a significant amount of time has passed, people will have trouble recalling which information they have received is the disinformation and which is the truth. Put simply, our first suggestion is don't expect to counter the firehose of falsehood with the squirt gun of truth.

The Rand report continues:

Our second suggestion is to find ways to help put raincoats on those at whom the firehose of falsehood is being directed.

Don't expect to counter Russia's firehose of falsehood with the squirt gun of truth. Instead, put raincoats on those at whom the firehose is aimed.[My emphasis added]

Another possibility is to focus on countering the effects of Russian propaganda, rather than the propaganda itself. The propagandists are working to accomplish something. The goal may be a change in attitudes, behaviors, or both. Identify those desired effects and then work to counter the effects that run contrary to your goals...

That metaphor and mindset leads us to our fourth suggestion for responding to Russian propaganda: Compete! If Russian propaganda aims to achieve certain effects, it can be countered by preventing or diminishing those effects.

In our 2023 conversation, Lee McIntyre offered this additional advice about how to resist and win an information war:

[D]isinformation has three goals. First is to try to get you to believe a falsehood. Second is to polarize you around a factual issue so that you begin to distrust, and even hate, the people who do not also believe this same falsehood. But finally comes the third and in some ways the most insidious goal of all they want you to give up. I think one message people get from disinformation is that everyone is biased, and that all speech is political. Or that things are so confusing - and there are so many voices out there who disagree - that it's just impossible to know the truth. People become confused and then cynical. They begin to feel helpless. And that is precisely the type of person that an authoritarian wants you to be.

They want you to give up. The easiest way to control a population is to control their information source. But you are not powerless. There is something you can do to fight back against disinformation. That's why I wrote the book.

But even before you read the book, I want you to know this: the most important step in winning an information war is first to admit that you are in one. [My emphasis added]

In the end, howling and complaining that "the other side is not playing fair" instead of adapting and overcoming is no real defense and a path to defeat.

Unfortunately for the American people and the future of their democracy and freedom, throughout the long Age of Trump, the Democratic Party, the so-called Resistance, the mainstream news media and other supposed defenders of democracy and "the institutions" have not learned and internalized that lesson.

urn:contentItem:6DDW-4KK1-DYJT-22BJ-00000-00Teen charged in arson that sparked 52-acre N.J. wildfire2024-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisCLASSIFIEDSPg. B3Teen charged in arson that sparked 52-acre N.J. wildfireRodrigo Torrejón (Staff Writer)

A 14-year-old was charged with aggravated arson for starting a wildfire that consumed 52 acres in South Jersey, police said.

The Marlton teen, whom police did not identify because he is a juvenile, was arrested Nov. 7 and accused of starting the fire on Oct. 30 near Sycamore Drive in Evesham Township, by the Berlin Township border, Evesham Township police said in a Facebook post.

Firefighters from the Evesham Fire Department and New Jersey Forest Fire Service, along with Evesham Township police, battled the blaze for several days. No nearby structures were damaged, police said.

Investigators found evidence that the teen intentionally set the fire, police said. It was unclear how authorities determined that.

The teen was also charged with causing or risking widespread injury or damage, police said. He was being held in the Middlesex Juvenile Detention Center, awaiting a first court appearance.

Authorities are also investigating whether a Nov. 7 fire in the area of Sycamore Drive that burned through 375 acres is connected to the Oct. 30 fire. As with the October fire, the blaze took firefighters days to place under control. No structures were damaged, police said.

Anyone with information on the fires is asked to call the Evesham Police Department at 856-983-1116 or the department's confidential tip line at 856-983-4699. Tipsters can also email mahand@eveshampd.org or leave anonymous tips by texting ETPDTIP to 847411.

The wildfires in Evesham are among more than 500 such fires that have erupted across New Jersey since October in what state officials have called an unprecedented dry period in the Garden State that stretches back to at least August.

Gov. Phil Murphy declared a drought warning for New Jersey on Wednesday, the first time the state has declared such a warning since 2016. New JerseyAmerican Water, the state's largest drinking water supplier, issued a mandatory conservation notice immediately after the declaration.

The New Jersey Forest Fire Service has responded to 537 wildfires since early October, an increase of more than 1,300% over the same period last year.

In one case, an 18-year-old firefighter was killed battling a blaze at the New Jersey-New York border when he was struck by a falling tree.

And last week, Richard Shashaty, 37, of Brick Township, was charged with arson and firearms violations after authorities said he started a fire near Six Flags Great Adventure that consumed 350 acres. Authorities say he started the blaze by firing a shotgun loaded with so-called Dragon's breath shells designed to spread flames.

Firing incendiary or tracer ammunition is prohibited in New Jersey, officials said.

urn:contentItem:6C7F-1TK1-DY7R-R4VM-00000-00Data from IPB University Advance Knowledge in Data Systems (Scalability Testing of Land Forest Fire Patrol Information Systems)2024-06-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisINFORMATION TECHNOLOGY - DATA SYSTEMSData from IPB University Advance Knowledge in Data Systems (Scalability Testing of Land Forest Fire Patrol Information Systems)


2024 JUN 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- Investigators publish new report on data systems. According to news reporting originating from Bogor, Indonesia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The Patrol Information System for the Prevention of Forest Land Fires (SIPP Karhutla) in Indonesia is a tool for assisting patrol activities for controlling forest and land fires in Indonesia. The addition of Karhutla SIPP users causes the need for system scalability testing."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from IPB University: "This study aims to perform non-functional testing that focuses on scalability testing. The steps in scalability testing include creating schemas, conducting tests, and analyzing results. There are five schemes with a total sample of 700 samples. Testing was carried out using the JMeter automation testing tool assisted by Blazemeter in creating scripts. The scalability test parameter has three parameters: average CPU usage, memory usage, and network usage. The test results show that the CPU capacity used can handle up to 700 users, while with a memory capacity of 8GB it can handle up to 420 users."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "All users is the user menu that has the highest value for each test parameter The average value of CPU usage is 44.8%, the average memory usage is 69.48% and the average network usage is 2.8 Mb/s. In minimizing server performance, the tile cache map method can be applied to the system and can increase the memory capacity used."
For more information on this research see: Scalability Testing of Land Forest Fire Patrol Information Systems. JOIN: Jurnal Online Informatika, 2023,8(1):11-18. Abstract

In 2023, South America experienced an unprecedented heatwave that threatened socioeconomic structures and ecosystems. This study uses attribution analysis to evaluate the contributions of atmospheric circulation patterns and human factors to the heatwave's probability and intensity. The 2023 heatwave is a 1-in-130-year event and a 1-in-65-year event, with and without considering the 2023 heatwave in the fitting, respectively. The large-scale meteorological analysis revealed that the heatwave was driven by an anomalously high-pressure system that formed a heat dome from dry, hot air columns. ALL (all-forcing scenario) and GHG (greenhouse gas scenario) simulations indicate the likelihood of future extreme heatwaves increases by 28.45% [27.60%, 29.30%] (90% confidence interval) and 30.42% [29.51%, 31.33%] (90% confidence interval), respectively, based on data from 1850 to 2014. Insights from Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) models emphasize that human-induced warming significantly contributes to heatwaves, which highlights the need for effective climate adaptation and mitigation strategies.

IntroductionThe trends of climate change, variability, and extreme events with severe impacts at global and regional scales are becoming increasingly evident1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6–7. Specifically, heatwaves are expected to increase in frequency by the end of the 21st century in this region and other parts of the world that have experienced prolonged periods of insufficient precipitation, particularly in SA (including the Amazon Basin, Pantanal wetlands, Argentina, and Uruguay)8. In 2023, the average temperature in South America reached a historic high, exceeding the 1991–2020 average by 0.81 °C (with an anomaly range of 0.75–0.96 °C). Relative to the 1961–1990 baseline, the temperature in 2023 was 1.37 °C higher (with an anomaly range of 1.17–1.62 °C). Due to the influence of the El Niño phenomenon, the warming trend in the region in 2023 was more pronounced compared to 2022. The period from 1991 to 2023 showed the highest warming trend (~0.2 °C or more per decade) since 1900 in South America, compared to the previous 30-year periods of 1900–1930, 1931–1960, and 1961–19909. The Amazon, as one of the world's largest biodiversity and carbon reserves, experienced relentless heatwaves in 2023, with many areas experiencing at least 20 more heatwave days than the average from 1991 to 202010. The heatwave affected not only Amazonia—especially southern Amazonia—but also central South America, with higher intensity than in Amazonia. These record-breaking events include unusually hot winters and springs in South America11,12, characterized by their unique intensities, durations, and impacts. These catastrophic heatwaves have led to widespread agricultural droughts, severe wildfires, and accelerated carbon loss from tropical rainforests in South America13, 14, 15, 16, 17–18. Climate variability and change-induced heatwaves and droughts severely affect local agriculture, ecosystems, and residents' lives19, 20, 21–22. Human influences and climate change have increased the vulnerability of terrestrial ecosystems to extreme climate events and fires, leading to increased heatwave intensity, frequency, and duration23. These trends are expected to worsen with the intensification of global warming24. Understanding regional heatwave trends is crucial for assessing their impacts on biophysical and human systems25. Studies on heatwaves have provided essential scientific insights into their multifaceted impacts on climate, ecology, and socioeconomic systems; in this way, they support the formulation of effective adaptation strategies and boost resilience.

The increasing frequency of heatwaves and their adverse impacts—particularly on sectors such as agriculture (due to crop stress), public health (through heat-related illnesses), water resources (leading to drought conditions), and energy (increasing demand for cooling)—highlight the mechanisms behind regional heatwave occurrences and their physical processes26. From the perspective of large-scale circulation, heatwaves can be analysed from both thermodynamic and dynamic angles. They are often associated with summer blocking high-pressure systems, which lead to subsidence and clear sky conditions, causing adiabatic warming of the air and allowing radiative warming near the surface27,28. This condition typically results in regional heat domes, which are linked to high-altitude high-pressure systems that prevent the ascent of warm air below, further increasing temperatures29,30. These phenomena are also related to abnormally high-pressure systems, primarily due to enhanced land‒sea thermal contrasts and atmospheric teleconnections in response to El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) transitions31, 32, 33–34.

Furthermore, human-induced greenhouse gas and aerosol emissions (and land use changes, such as deforestation) have amplified heatwaves, a trend anticipated to persist in the coming years35, 36–37. In summary, the interplay between natural atmospheric circulation fluctuations and external factors can disrupt the Earth's energy balance and water cycle, leading to intensified heatwaves across various timescales and regions38. Accurately quantifying the contributions of different physical processes is essential for comprehending the lifecycle of heatwaves39,40. This includes examining atmospheric dynamics such as horizontal and vertical advection, surface latent and sensible heat fluxes, and radiative factors like solar insolation, surface albedo, temperature, water vapour, clouds, and aerosols41.

Although many researchers have examined the causes and development of heatwaves, the specific roles of atmospheric circulation and human-induced warming in extreme events are still not fully understood23. While climate models aid in decomposing temperature anomalies into internal and external factors, they often struggle to accurately represent regional internal variability patterns. Consequently, estimating the role of internal atmospheric circulation variability in extreme temperature events via climate models remains a challenge42.

Given South America’s critical role in the global climate system, climate change attribution research in this region has expanded significantly in recent years, making extensive use of observational data and climate models (e.g., the CMIP series) to examine the causes and influencing factors of extreme events—particularly heatwaves and droughts43, 44, 45–46. Researchers often separate natural variability (such as El Niño–Southern Oscillation) from anthropogenic factors (e.g., greenhouse gas emissions, land-use changes) to quantify their relative contributions to temperature and precipitation anomalies8,47, 48, 49, 50, 51–52. Multiple studies have shown that human activities have markedly intensified the frequency and severity of heatwaves over the past few decades, while land-use changes affecting surface energy balance and hydrological cycles may further exacerbate these extreme events47,53,54. Overall, these attribution studies provide essential scientific insights into the mechanisms driving climate evolution in South America, offering valuable guidance for risk assessment, adaptation strategies, and mitigation measures.

Given these complexities, this paper aims to explore the following scientific inquiries: (a) How unprecedented was the extreme heatwave in South America in 2023 when viewed in a historical context, particularly from the long-term perspective of 1979 to 2023? (b) What atmospheric conditions were linked to this heatwave? (c) How do atmospheric circulation patterns and human-induced warming impact regional heatwaves in the context of climate change, and what changes in these influences might we anticipate in the future?

Results

Characteristics of changes in South American heatwaves

The year 2023 was the hottest year on record for SA. The year 2023 was the warmest on record in many parts of the region, which is reflected by the high temperature anomalies at the country level. Station data for 2023 relative to 1991–2020, In South America, above-normal temperature anomalies of around +2 °C, up to +3 °C in some locations, were observed in central and northern Argentina, the central and southern Andes of Peru, Bolivia, northern Chile and Paraguay, the Peruvian and Bolivian Amazon, and the entire tropical zone of South America, some of them reflecting the heatwaves that affected the region, Negative temperature anomalies of –0.5 to −1.0 °C were observed in the extreme south of Argentina and Chile9. This extraordinary heatwave was characterized by three main indicators: HWM, HWL, and HWD, with anomaly values generally exceeding twice the standardized deviation of the 1979–2010 climatology (Fig. 1b, c and Supplementary Fig. 1). Additionally, in 2023, an event occurred that was unprecedented in the historical record (Fig. 5 in Supporting Information), i.e., the highest recorded regional average HWL and HWM from 1979 to 2023 (Fig. 1d). The two heatwave indicators were strongly correlated, with Pearson correlation coefficients exceeding 0.89 and p values < 0.05, and demonstrated notable increasing trends over time. On average, HWL and HWM have risen by 1.2 days and 0.1 °C per decade. Additionally, the spatial distributions of SAT and heatwave attributes underscored a marked trend of extremely high temperatures in SA. Figure 1e, f show the progression of the 2023 heatwave, where the average SAT for SA was significantly above the climatological mean throughout the spring season. Furthermore, from November 10 to 20, 2023, the SAT anomaly exceeded the 90th percentile of climatological anomalies. Atmospheric mechanisms of heatwaves in South America

To statistically estimate the unprecedented nature of the 2023 heatwave in SA, we analysed the spring SAT and three heatwave characteristics via both stationary and nonstationary GEV fits. Compared with those of stationary models, this approach generally yields better results. For most variables, the nonstationary GEV location models were insufficient to capture the nonstationary characteristics of SA temperature changes, except for HWD. Specifically, the SAT anomalies increased significantly at rates of 0.68 and 0.75 with GMST when the 2023 heatwave in SA was considered and not considered (Fig. 3a–b). This intensified warming results from the diverse regional responses of local temperatures to global climate change. In the statistical analyses, including or excluding the 2023 heatwave in SA significantly affects the estimated return period. When the 2023 event is excluded. The nonstationary GEV model applied to the observed data suggests that the heatwave is an extremely rare phenomenon, with an estimated occurrence probability of about once in 130 years. Specifically, HWM is expected once every 40 years, while both HWD and HWL occur less frequently than once every 1000 years. However, when the SAT of the 2023 heatwave is included, it is reclassified as a once-in-65-year event (HWD once every 100 years, HWL once every 465 years, and HWM once every 54 years) (Supplementary Fig. 3). These findings underscore that the 2023 heatwave in South America set new records for surface air temperature anomalies and heatwave characteristics. Ignoring this event might result in a substantial overestimation of return periods.

Based on the analysis of Fig. 3c–f regarding different sites, Val de Cans International (representing the Amazon region) and Viracopos (representing the Southeast region of Brazil) show a significant upward trend in annual maximum temperatures. Notably, extreme temperature events in the Amazon are expected to occur every 252 years, compared to every 1766 years for Viracopos. This indicates that Amazon faces a greater threat from climate change, as its ecosystem is more sensitive to extreme temperature fluctuations, which may lead to increased frequency of forest fires, disruption of ecological balance, and loss of biodiversity. Additionally, the rainfall patterns in the Amazon rainforest could also be affected, exacerbating droughts and extreme weather events, which pose severe risks to local communities' livelihoods and food security. Therefore, the impacts of climate change in the Amazon region are particularly severe and urgent compared to those in Southeast Brazil.

To investigate the physical mechanisms behind the causes of heatwaves, we explored the climatic conditions and circulation characteristics, Figure 4 shows the climatic conditions and circulation characteristics over SA in 2023, highlighting both horizontal and vertical structures. In 2023, the eastern and central regions of SA experienced suppressed precipitation, resulting in a 13.65% reduction in total annual rainfall compared with the climatological average. This prolonged low precipitation significantly reduced the soil moisture and dried the air, leading to surface warming. The persistent low-precipitation and high-temperature anomalies were primarily linked to a robust high-pressure system over SA (refer to Fig. 4c, d). A significant area of water vapour divergence was observed in central and eastern SA (Fig. 4c). Figure 4e illustrates the cross-sectional view of the geopotential height in a vertical-meridional orientation across SA, which is typically marked by substantial positive geopotential height anomalies. This "dome" structure is centred in the mid-to-upper troposphere, spanning the 100–150 hPa pressure levels. The South Atlantic Convergence Zone (SACZ) and the South American Low-Level Jet (SALLJ) play vital roles in the development of spring heatwaves in South America56. An active SACZ can lead to subsidence and anticyclonic circulation primarily over southeastern Brazil and nearby areas during specific periods, resulting in higher temperatures57. Increased (decreased) convection in the SACZ is associated with a weakened (strengthened) SALLJ.

Moreover, Fig. 4f presents a notable column of positive temperature anomalies spanning from 200 to 1000 hPa over South America (SA), with a warming center emerging at higher altitudes between 20°S and 30°S. This pattern suggests the presence of a high-pressure system (500 hPa) between 20°S and 30°S, as indicated in Fig. 4d, and a reduction in relative humidity at ~10°S, expanding the thermal dome (Fig. 4g). This is because heatwaves increase atmospheric temperatures, thereby increasing the capacity of air to hold more water vapour.

Interannual variability also plays a role in the formation of heat waves in South America. The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is a major factor influencing interannual variability in global weather patterns58. The ENSO cycle has a substantial effect on surface temperature anomalies59. Against the backdrop of global warming, atmospheric anomalies induced by El Niño events have intensified60. Extreme El Niño events cause accelerated warming of the equatorial Pacific, especially in the eastern part, leading to extreme equatorial swings in the Pacific convergence zone, which exacerbates continental warming58.

In atmospheric dynamics, wave activity flux is commonly used to diagnose the propagation of Rossby waves. Wave activity flux can be employed to analyse how synoptic-scale transient waves regulate stationary waves over a period, diagnose the evolution characteristics of wave activity during a weather event, and examine the three-dimensional propagation characteristics of stationary Rossby waves. The T-N wave activity flux is an improvement over the Plumb wave flux, with an enhanced meridional component. This enhancement allows for a better description of large-amplitude Rossby longwave disturbances in the westerlies within zonally nonuniform airflow.

From the vector changes in wave activity flux, it is evident that the heatwave is consistently accompanied by the presence of an Atlantic blocking high. Thermal forcing is a crucial factor in the formation of blocking highs. In the plumb flux, blocking highs form over the Pacific, whereas in the southwestern Pacific and central SA, blocking highs develop and cross the Andes Mountains. On the eastern side of the Andes, an extreme heat dome forms, trapping the generated heat in the atmosphere and thus leading to the accumulation of heatwaves and further increases in temperature (Fig. 5).Fig. 5

Contributions of human activities and global warming to heatwaves in SA

Human activities are another significant factor contributing to the occurrence of heatwaves61. Carbon dioxide emissions from human activities are a major greenhouse gas that acts as a blanket over the Earth, trapping more solar heat near the surface. Compared with the randomness of natural variability, studies have indicated that human activities significantly increase the likelihood of record-breaking heatwave events. Global warming increases background temperatures, increasing the likelihood of extremely high-temperature events, which have significantly increased in SA over recent decades19,53.

Figure 7 shows climate change trends and the significance of signal detection under different emission scenarios. In Fig. 7a, the trends in surface maximum temperature anomalies under various emission scenarios are shown. The picontrol (grey line) represents preindustrial control simulations used to assess natural variability in the climate system without human interference, showing inherent natural variability trends towards stability. The surface maximum temperature trends in the SSP585 (red line) and SSP126 (blue line) scenarios reflect the potential impacts of different socioeconomic development paths on climate change. The high-emission scenario (SSP585) shows a significant temperature increase trend, whereas the low-emission scenario (SSP126) depicts a more moderate increase, highlighting the importance of emission reduction in mitigating climate change. Additionally, we present the probability density function (PDF) of Tmax anomalies in the SA region from November 15 to 21 for the years 1951–2021. The PDF is estimated via kernel smoothing functions. Figure 8a shows the Tmax anomaly PDFs simulated for ALL (HIST), NAT (HIST), GHG (HIST), and AER (HIST) from 1951 to 2020, as well as for ALL (SSP245), NAT (SSP245), GHG (SSP245), and AER (SSP245) from 2021 to 2100. On the basis of a two-sided Kolmogorov test, there is no significant difference at the 0.05 level between the observed and ALL-simulated PDFs for 1951–2020. This finding indicates that the CMIP6 model can effectively simulate the PDFs of Tmax anomalies in SA during this period. In Fig. 8a, the black dashed line represents the observed Tmax anomaly in SA in 2023. The area enclosed between the dashed line and the distributions of the PDFs reflects the probability of such extreme events occurring under different external forcings. In Fig. 8b, both two-signal and three-signal analyses demonstrate the dominant role of anthropogenic factors in recent extreme heat events. The three-signal approach further reveals that greenhouse gas emissions have a more pronounced impact on maximum temperatures, while the cooling effect of aerosols partially offsets the warming trend. Although natural factors contribute to high-temperature events, their influence is relatively smaller compared to anthropogenic forcings and is associated with greater uncertainty. Human influence on heatwaves, such as increased greenhouse gas concentrations, has increased the likelihood of warming events. Compared with those from 1951 to 2020, the PDFs for the ALL and GHG simulations exhibit a more pronounced rightward shift from 2021 to 2100. Under the ALL and GHG simulations, the future probabilities of such extreme events increased by 28.45% and 30.42%, respectively. Discussion

This paper presents an examination of the unprecedented 2023 heatwave in SA, emphasizing its extreme features in terms of duration, intensity, and effects (refer to Fig. 1). Heatwaves have significant consequences for ecosystems and human societies. The stable analysis of spring SAT indicates that when considering or not considering the 2023 heatwave in SA via statistical simulations, it is regarded as a once-in-every-65-year or once-in-every-130-year event, respectively (Fig. 3). Ignoring the 2023 heatwave may lead to a severe overestimation of its recurrence period, undermining accurate risk assessments and precise predictions related to climate risks. Importantly, owing to the short observation period, the choice of statistical distribution models, and the extreme nature of the event, these recurrence periods may be significantly exaggerated. Therefore, we recommend the use of long-term observational and assimilated data to thoroughly understand the physical mechanisms behind extreme climate events to reliably estimate their recurrence periods.

From the perspective of weather behaviour and the broader climate context, the 2023 heatwave in SA was largely driven by a high-pressure system (Fig. 4d), which facilitated descending air movements in its central area, resulting in the formation of a heat dome. During the downward movement of the air, anticyclone interactions and adiabatic heating led to atmospheric warming. The stronger the heat dome is, the higher the near-surface temperature62,63. On the other hand, a lower water vapour flux resulted in fewer clouds and less precipitation, increasing the amount of solar radiation at the surface. The divergence of water vapour (positive divergence) leads to dry weather conditions, exacerbating the intensity and duration of heatwaves64. This heatwave was also influenced by the terrain; on the eastern side of the Andes, the descending air transformed into hot, dry winds, creating the Foehn effect. The westerlies were blocked by the Andes, preventing Atlantic moisture from reaching the Brazilian and Patagonian plateaus, which intensified the heatwave65.

Interannual variability in the mechanisms of SA heatwaves also contributed to their development. The ENSO significantly influences global weather pattern variability57. Circulation anomalies, which are part of extensive Rossby wave trains across the South Pacific, are linked to convective irregularities in the equatorial western and central Pacific. Furthermore, the subsiding conditions encouraged by the SACZ within the subtropical anticyclonic circulation intensified warming in subtropical areas experiencing relatively dry conditions31. Subsiding in the southwesterly low-level jet (SALLJEX) and non-adiabatic warming caused temperatures to rise in the subtropical regions of South America56. During the heatwave event, northerly winds prevailed in regions surrounded by eastern Argentina, Paraguay, southern Brazil, and Uruguay. These north winds were promoted by frontal systems advancing towards the equator from higher latitudes, predominantly raising temperatures to extreme levels through advection processes. The heatwave was accompanied by increased solar radiation and reduced precipitation, specific humidity, and cloud cover. The timing of heatwaves is correlated with atmospheric circulation anomalies, which often present as abnormal high-pressure systems66. The heat dome, which is an anomalous high-pressure system, led to significant temperature increases. Extreme high temperatures are also linked to soil moisture deficits, where land‒atmosphere feedback could amplify heatwaves, particularly as warming climates favour the occurrence of heatwaves42,67, 68–69.

The heatwave in South America in 2023 resulted from a combination of factors, including the strengthening of high-pressure systems, the impact of severe drought, and the influence of El Niño. The high-pressure systems led to stable weather conditions, suppressing cloud formation and causing ground temperatures to rise abnormally70. Simultaneously, the drought exacerbated soil moisture evaporation, further increasing temperatures and creating a feedback loop. Additionally, the El Niño phenomenon contributed to warmer sea surface temperatures in the Pacific, which can alter weather patterns across South America and intensify heat events71. This heatwave is closely linked to global climate change, as the rise in greenhouse gases likely makes extreme heat events more frequent and intense. Consequently, this heatwave not only significantly affected ecosystems and agricultural production but also highlights the serious challenges posed by climate change and El Niño, underscoring the need for greater attention and research on the interactions between heatwaves and other meteorological phenomena.

By integrating the heatwave maps (Fig. 1b, c) with the anomalies of sensible and latent heat flux presented in the supplementary materials (Fig. 3a, b), we can gain in-depth insights into the mechanisms of climate change in South America. The anomalies in sensible heat flux (HWL) reveal positive regions, particularly in the northern and central areas, indicating an increase in heat accumulation that may lead to more frequent heatwave events. This significant rise in heat in these areas contributes to elevated surface temperatures and exacerbates drought conditions, which in turn affect vegetation moisture status and ecosystem health. Furthermore, the anomalies in latent heat flux (HWM) highlight variations in evaporation and transpiration, especially in negative anomaly regions, suggesting a link between reduced precipitation and insufficient water evaporation. This disruption of the hydrological cycle exacerbates climate instability, resulting in soil drought and decreased ecological resilience. Overall, these interactions create a negative feedback loop of climate change, potentially leading to a significant increase in the frequency and intensity of heat waves.

We will continue to track El Niño events and their effects on regional climates and implement suitable strategies to address their challenges, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions and increasing climate adaptability and resilience. These initiatives aim to alleviate the effects of El Niño events on the global climate and ecosystem, safeguarding both human and environmental health. CMIP6 climate models suggest that greenhouse gases significantly contribute to the increase in daily maximum temperatures in SA, both historically and in the future. However, these models are not specifically designed to simulate individual heatwave events in SA. According to the ALL and GHG simulations, the likelihood of future extreme heatwave occurrence increases by 28.45% (confidence interval [27.60%, 29.30%]) and 30.42% (confidence interval [29.51%, 31.33%]), respectively. Regional and short-term climate changes, including heatwaves, require greater focus and research.

Methods

Definition, characteristics, and statistical methods of heatwaves

To gain a thorough understanding of heatwave activity, this study utilizes data from the fifth-generation European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts reanalysis (ERA5) dataset72. The analysis focuses on heatwaves that primarily occurred during spring of 2023, covering the period from September to November from 1979 to 2023. During heatwave events, surface air temperature (SAT) is represented by the temperature at 2 m above ground level (T2m). This study identifies several key characteristics of heatwaves, including the yearly count of heatwave days (HWD, days), the length of the longest event each year (HWL, days), and the mean intensity of all events annually (HWM, °C). The HWD is determined for each grid point as the number of days when the maximum temperature (Tmax) exceeds the 90th percentile threshold for that specific day of the year, which is based on a 5-day window from the 1979 to 2010 baseline, Among these metrics, heatwave intensity (HWM) is defined as the average daily maximum temperature over the heatwave period, effectively capturing the event’s overall severity and enabling straightforward comparisons across different heatwaves. The HWL and HWM are then statistically analysed on the basis of the identified HWD11.

During the 2023 heatwave in South America, extensive wildfires occurred, marking a year of intense wildfire activity across the region9. The combination of El Niño events and climate warming created conditions for fires to spread uncontrollably73. According to the European Forest Fire Information System, the FWI is divided into six risk levels: very low (FWI < 5.2), low (5.2 < FWI < 11.2), moderate (11.2 < FWI < 21.3), high (21.3 < FWI < 38.0), very high (38.0 < FWI < 50.0), and extreme (FWI > 50.0)74.

Global temperature increases cause atmospheric thermal expansion, triggering circulation changes that affect regional climates75. Temperature fluctuations play a role in the occurrence of extreme events. The influence of changes in these circulation patterns on the probability of extreme temperatures is studied by examining the dynamic and thermodynamic impacts of global warming to assess the likelihood of extremely high-temperature events28.

To investigate the atmospheric circulation characteristics of the 2023 heatwave in SA, composite anomalies of relevant atmospheric variables are computed to discern weather patterns and circulation dynamics. The analysed variables include precipitation, maximum surface temperature, water vapour flux and divergence, temperature (T), geopotential height (Z), sea-level pressure (SLP), and relative humidity. Climate anomalies are determined by contrasting the original measurements with climatological averages from 1979 to 2010. The impact of human-induced forcing on SAT changes can be assessed via climate model simulations from the sixth phase of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6)42,50, which evaluate observed and simulated temperature trends under various forcings, the results of detection and attribution studies, and observationally constrained future projections. This approach provides deeper insights into the mechanisms and uncertainties of anthropogenic climate change.

Variations in global mean surface temperature (GMST) anomalies effectively capture the changing nature of local temperature patterns76,77. This dynamic approach considers the location parameter of the generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution as dependent on the GMST, while the scale (σ) and shape (ε) parameters are assumed to be constant. To ensure that the increasing variability in the SAT with changes in the GMST does not affect the nonstationary model fit, this study allows both location and scale parameters to be adjusted in relation to the GMST covariate. We apply three nonstationary GEV models to investigate the nonstationarity of the SAT and alterations in heatwave characteristics. The GEV distribution is commonly used to model hydrometeorological extremes, and combining models that have shape parameters dependent on climate indices with time-dependent scale parameters can significantly improve the goodness of fit78.

Nonstationary frequency analysis

This study employs a nonstationary frequency analysis method. Given that heatwaves are considered extreme climate events with distinct characteristics, influenced by both natural and human activities, it is crucial to consider these nonstationary factors for accurate future climate predictions79,80. We adopt a nonstationary generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution to model surface air temperature (SAT) and heatwave characteristics (HMD, HWL, HWM). Previous studies have shown that GEV can accommodate changes in the location parameter (μ) in response to anomalies in global mean surface temperature (GMST)76,77.

We utilize the location parameter (μ) and scale parameter to model the impact of GMST on local SAT. To characterize the nonstationarity of heatwaves, we employ four methods: a traditional stationary model and three nonstationary models.

Stationary GEV model: In this model, the parameters μ, σ, and ε remain constant.

Nonstationary GEV location model: Here, the location parameter μ is permitted to change linearly with GMST, while the parameters σ and ε are held constant.

Nonstationary GEV scale model: In this case, the scale parameter σ varies linearly with GMST, while the location and shape parameters (μ and ε) remain constant.

Nonstationary GEV location and scale model: This model accommodates changes in both μ and σ concerning GMST, with the shape parameter ε held constant.

To evaluate the effectiveness of each GEV model, we apply the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), defined by the formula AIC = 2k−2 ln(L'), where k denotes the number of parameters being estimated, and L' is the maximum likelihood for the respective model. We assess the uncertainties associated with the nonstationary frequency analyses, computing a range from 5% to 95% using 1000 bootstrap samples. In light of the infrequency of events akin to the 2023 South America heatwave, we also examine earlier instances within the same period. This analysis considers the outcomes both when including and excluding the 2022 South America heatwave in the GEV fitting procedure, with temperature data illustrated in Fig. 3, and heatwave characteristics depicted in the Supporting Information.

Optimal fingerprint method

Detection and attribution methods are employed to determine the causes of climate change76,81,82. These methods depend on climate models to precisely replicate the physical processes within the climate system. Optimal fingerprinting is applied via generalized multivariable linear regression, where the observations (Y) are regressed against multimodal parallel signal patterns (X), represented as . In this equation, β denotes the scaling factor or regression coefficient, ν accounts for residual internal variability from X, and is the residual, representing internal variation. To derive scaling factors, the total least squares (TLS) method is utilized, employing regularized instead of empirical covariance estimates. A forced response is identified at a 5% significance level if the 90% confidence interval of the scaling factors does not include zero. If the detected signal’s 90% interval includes unity, the observed and externally forced signals are considered consistent. For analysis, both single and dual-signal methods are employed. In single-signal analysis, observations are regressed onto a single factor (including ALL and ANT) multimodal mean to estimate the ALL signal. The ANT signal is inferred from the difference between the ALL and NAT signals. This method uses available data to estimate ALL and NAT signals, although changes can represent all modes. Alternatively, models generated by the ALL and NAT signals simplify the process and reduce the number of simulations. Consistency in detection outcomes is indicated. In dual-signal analysis, observations are regressed simultaneously onto ALL and NAT responses, with their scaling factors transformed linearly to evaluate the relative contributions of natural forcings (NATs) and anthropogenic forcings (ANTs) to the observed data. This method determines whether ANT and NAT signals are distinct and separates the effects of ANT forcings from NAT signals and inherent system variability83,84.

The probability ratio (PR) and fraction of attributable risk (FAR) were defined by Fischer and Knutti85. These metrics are employed to compare event probabilities between counterfactual natural scenarios (from simulations excluding human influence) and factual scenarios (including human influences). PR measures how much human impact alters the probability of an event, whereas FAR estimates the portion of an event's occurrence due to human activities2. Uncertainties in PR and FAR are determined with the bootstrap confidence interval method, with median values providing the best estimates.

April 25th, 2025 (New Hampshire Bulletin — Delivered by Newstex)

The Centennial Fire burns in the White Mountain National Forest in May 2022. (Photo courtesy of the N.H. Forest Protection Bureau)

In 2024, New Hampshire wildfire numbers climbed 24%, burning nearly double the acres compared to 2023, according to the state Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

Rapidly changing weather conditions in the fall brought about the bump, said Chief Steven Sherman, head of the state's Forest Protection Bureau. The flames threatened 37 structures and destroyed four, the department said.

#8216;We had really dry, low relative humidity conditions, and the forest fuels just dried out so quick that we ended up with a lot of acres in the fall,#8217; Sherman said, #8216;which isn't completely unheard of, but last year was just the way everything changed so quick, I think, is what was surprising to everybody.#8217;

With Gov. Kelly Ayotte declaring this week Wildfire Awareness Week, it's a reminder of the dangers the fires pose in New England, where wildfire risk is considered relatively low. While the flames can bring destruction, the smoke alone can cause serious health problems, even for residents far from the site of the fire. Granite Staters experienced this up close in 2023 when Canadian wildfire smoke prompted air quality concerns in the state.

Changes in the climate, driven by human use of fossil fuels, are creating the warmer, drier conditions in which wildfires thrive, scientists say.

#8216;I think it's a really fair expectation that one of the most widely experienced impacts of global warming will be reductions in air quality from wildfire,#8217; said Justin S. Mankin, an associate professor in Dartmouth's Department of Geography.

The Centennial Fire burns in the White Mountain National Forest in May 2022. (Photo courtesy of the N.H. Forest Protection Bureau)

#8216;There's been a lot of compelling science that has shown that the particulate matter — so these are little, little aerosols from burned fuels — that can then get mobilized throughout the atmosphere, carried extremely long distances, thousands of kilometers, deposited elsewhere, and affect the air quality of people very far away from from the wildfires,#8217; he said. #8216; And it poses some, you know, real cardiovascular and pulmonary issues, particularly for people that have pre-existing conditions of some kind, or for the young as well.#8217;

Though 2024 saw higher activity, Sherman said the number of wildfires in the state has remained consistent, with the average sitting at over 200 fires a year and between 220 and 250 acres burned.

#8216;Really, what we're seeing happen more often now is that we just have these extreme shifts in weather,#8217; Sherman said. Even with rain in the state so far this spring, he said, #8216;conditions can change just so rapidly, where before we get into green up, we'll probably have a period here, it looks like we might be entering one, where we're going to have those lower relative humidities, and conditions will just change very rapidly.#8217;

Sherman attributed the #8216;quicker shifts in extreme weather#8217; to the impacts of climate change. He said those shifts are the biggest change he's seen since he started doing this work in the late 1990s. He also noted the impact of lower snowpack in the winter.

#8216;It used to be more common that your snowpack would get you out of that drought situation with the slow melt in the spring, and you'd go into a nice, lush spring,#8217; Sherman said. #8216;And this year, you can still look at the drought monitor and see that that drought in the southern part of New Hampshire is still hanging on.#8217;

Mankin said the #8216;ingredients for wildfire#8217; are fairly straightforward: fuel, ignition, and a way for the fire to spread.

#8216;The way climate change is really most saliently impacting wildfire risk is by altering the fuel loadings on the ground and kind of creating the conditions that give the wildfire time to spread, #8216; Mankin said, #8216; so often by altering precipitation patterns, because it's really precipitation that puts out wildfires.#8217;

Mankin emphasized that wildfires are #8216;an essential and natural part of ecosystems,#8217; and an #8216;important sign of ecosystem health.#8217;

New England in general has historically been described as #8216;the asbestos forest, meaning it took a lot to get it to burn,#8217; said Steven Roberge, a professor of natural resources and the state specialist of forest resources for the University of New Hampshire Extension.

A New Hampshire forest ranger works on a prescribed fire. (Photo courtesy of the N.H. Forest Protection Bureau)

But there are forest types and ecosystems in the region that rely on periodic burning, #8216;historically, either by Indigenous people or just natural events like lightning strikes and things like that,#8217; Roberge said. Prescribed fires — carefully planned, managed fires set for a purpose — are used as management tools today, but #8216;I think most folks who do prescribed fire would probably tell you that they don't have a chance to do it enough,#8217; Roberge said.

The Northeast is full of fuel for wildfires, and #8216;it likely has a wildfire deficit owing to the way we've managed wildlands in the Northeast and our kind of history of fire suppression,#8217; Mankin said. #8216;And at some point, that deficit will likely be recouped by the climate system and by those ecosystems.#8217;

The changing conditions raise questions about the status quo of management practices.

#8216;I think the risk is increasing, and I think we need to be prepared for that,#8217; Mankin said. #8216;You know, to the extent that we are acclimatized to the status quo, the status quo is no longer right, and to the extent that we are adapted to a wildfire regime that we had, that regime is no longer, and so that requires a real careful interrogation of current practices and how they should be altered to accommodate a rapidly changing climate system.#8217;

To monitor the fires, each town has a forest fire warden appointed by the state, Sherman said. Local fire departments are the first to respond to the fires, with the state there to offer support, he said. And each day, working in conjunction with the National Weather Service, the state puts out an updated fire risk.

If a wildfire starts in the state, the response is 100% suppression, Sherman said. But about two to three times a year, the state will do a prescribed fire. These fires follow detailed burn plans, and are done under #8216;very strict guidelines,#8217; he said.

The White Mountain National Forest runs its own program and does significantly more burning than the state. But #8216;in the past few years, we've actually hired a prescribed fire coordinator, so we're building up our capacity more,#8217; Sherman said.

Spring is the start of wildfire season, prompting the awareness week in late April. Research shows that the vast majority of wildfires are caused by humans.

Residents need to obtain fire permits for any outside burning, such as bonfires, Sherman said. Additionally, they should be aware of weather conditions and avoid burning on hot, windy, dry days, he said. And it's vital to extinguish fires completely; #8216;that means stirring it up, putting water, stirring it up again, and doing that until it's out cold,#8217; Sherman said.

The department also recommends residents clear pine needles and leaves from gutters and roofs, as well as keeping wildfire fuel (such as twigs, branches, firewood, shrubs, or other flammable materials) at least 5 feet away from buildings.

While wildfire risk in New England is considered relatively low, #8216;these hazards are experienced locally and need to be managed locally,#8217; Mankin said.

#8216;It's hard to kind of get wildfire intensities that look anything like the American West, but we are not invulnerable to it,#8217; Mankin said, #8216;and I think this last year and the last several years have actually really been salient examples of that.#8217;

The most obvious way to mitigate these risks, Mankin said, #8216;is decoupling human well-being from carbon emissions, which means, you know, investing in the energy transition and the decarbonization of our economy away from this ancient, fossilized way of sourcing energy. That will prevent future climate change, which alters the risks of wildfire massively.#8217;

Prescribed fires are set for a purpose and carefully planned. (Photo courtesy of the N.H. Forest Protection Bureau)

urn:contentItem:6F7R-J2J3-RX8C-R1K5-00000-00Evacuation Orders in Place Amid Massive South Carolina Wildfires2025-03-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisEvacuation Orders in Place Amid Massive South Carolina WildfiresAdeola Adeosun

Evacuation orders expand as a 1,200-acre wildfire threatens Carolina communities while Gov. McMaster declares a State of Emergency.

Massive wildfires across the Carolinas have forced evacuations of multiple neighborhoods, particularly in the Carolina Forest area near Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, where a fire has grown to approximately 1,200 acres.

According to the State Fire Marshal, there are ongoing response operations to more than 175 wildfires, impacting 4,200 acres across the state, including Horry, Spartanburg, Oconee, Union, and Pickens Counties primarily due to dry, windy conditions.

Newsweek contacted the South Carolina Forestry Commission via email on Sunday for comment.

The Context

The rapidly spreading wildfires threaten thousands of residents in populated areas, with hundreds already displaced from their homes.

These fires come amid unusually dry conditions in the region, with February rainfall 1.5 to 2.5 inches below average in the Carolinas, creating perfect conditions for wildfires to spread quickly when combined with gusty winds and low humidity.

Why To Know

South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster has declared a State of Emergency to support wildfire response efforts, and the state's Forestry Commission has implemented a statewide burning ban.

Evacuation orders have expanded overnight to include multiple Carolina Forest neighborhoods including Indigo Bay, the Farm, Summerlyn, parts of Walkers Woods, Avalon, and sections of Covington Lakes, Spring Lake, and Blackberry Lane, according to officials. International Drive has been closed between Highway 90 and area schools to facilitate emergency response.

In North Carolina, 400-500 acres have burned in the Blue Ridge mountains near the towns of Tryon and Saluda, forcing residents to evacuate.

The U.S. Forest Service is responding to wildfires in all four national forests in North Carolina, with the largest fire currently in Croatan National Forest where at least 114 acres have burned. Horry County Fire Rescue has deployed 410 personnel with 127 fire apparatus to battle the blaze, using drones to monitor fire movement.

The National Weather Service (NWS) issued a Red Flag Warning for much of the Southeast due to critical fire danger conditions.

Understanding Wildfires in South Carolina

Any forest fire, brush fire, grass fire, or other outdoor fire that is not controlled and supervised is classified as a wildfire.

The Palmetto State experiences approximately 3,000 wildfires annually, burning an average of 18,000 acres—one of the highest rates in the nation considering the state's size and population, according to the South Carolina Forestry Commission.

The most common cause of wildfires in South Carolina is debris burning (35 - 45 percent), followed by woods arson (25 - 30 percent). Wildfire season typically peaks in late winter and early spring, with March often being the most active month, though some of the largest fires have occurred in early April.

What People Are Saying

South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster: "This State of Emergency ensures that our first responders, who are working tirelessly and risking their lives to protect our communities from these wildfires, have the resources they need."

McMaster added: "Dangerous wildfire conditions require that a statewide burning ban remain in effect until further notice. Those who violate this ban will be subject to criminal prosecution."

Weather Channel Meteorologist Robb Ellis: "Wildfires are not only common in parts of the Carolinas but are part of the natural ecosystem of the area, especially in the Sandhills and Coastal Plain. Pine forests regularly rely on wildfire for the release of seeds from pinecones and to clear vegetation for new growth."

Horry County Fire Rescue on Facebook: "Should an evacuation occur; public safety personnel will go through the neighborhood knocking on doors to notify residents of the risk of remaining in place. Act swiftly if told to evacuate. As of this time, no structures have succumbed to the wildfire, and no injuries are reported."

What Happens Next

Emergency personnel will continue firefighting efforts while monitoring wind patterns that could change the fire's direction.

Evacuated residents are being directed to the Carolina Forest Recreation Center, which has been set up with cots, food, and other necessities for displaced people.

Officials encourage Carolinians to stay informed through official emergency sources and call 911 to report any immediate threats.

urn:contentItem:6D74-80J1-JC11-149B-00000-00University of East Anglia: Global CO2 Emissions From Forest Fires Increase by 60 Percent2024-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisUniversity of East Anglia: Global CO2 Emissions From Forest Fires Increase by 60 PercentTargeted News ServiceNORWICH, England

(TNSres) -- The University of East Anglia issued the following news:

A major new study reveals that carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from forest fires have surged by 60% globally since 2001, and almost tripled in some of the most climate-sensitive northern boreal forests.

The study, led by the University of East Anglia (UEA) and published today in Science, grouped areas of the world into 'pyromes' - regions where forest fire patterns are affected by similar environmental, human, and climatic controls - revealing the key factors driving recent increases in forest fire activity.

It is one of the first studies to look globally at the differences between forest and non-forest fires, and shows that in one of the largest pyromes, which spans boreal forests in Eurasia and North America, emissions from fires nearly tripled between 2001 and 2023.

Significant increases were seen more broadly across the extratropical forests and amounted to an additional half a billion tonnes of CO2 per year, with the epicentre of emissions shifting away from tropical forests and towards the extratropics.

Increased emissions were linked to a rise in fire-favourable weather, such as the hot-dry conditions seen during heatwaves and droughts, as well as increased rates of forest growth creating more vegetation fuels. Both trends are aided by rapid warming in the high northern latitudes, which is happening twice as fast as the global average.

The study reveals a worrying increase in not only the extent of forest wildfires over the last two decades, but also their severity. The carbon combustion rate, a measure of fire severity based on how much carbon is emitted per unit of area burned, increased by almost 50% across forests globally between 2001 and 2023.

The work involved an international team of scientists - from the UK, the Netherlands, US, Brazil, and Spain - who warn that further expansion of forest fires can only be averted if the primary causes of climate change, such as fossil fuel emissions, are tackled.

Lead author Dr Matthew Jones, of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research at UEA, said: "Increases in both the extent and severity of forest fires have led to a dramatic rise in the amount of carbon emitted by forest fires globally. Startling shifts in the global geography of fires are also underway, and they are primarily explained by the growing impacts of climate change in the world's boreal forests.

"To protect critical forest ecosystems from the accelerating threat of wildfires, we must keep global warming at bay and this underscores why it is so vital to make rapid progress towards net zero emissions."

Threats to carbon storage

Forests are of worldwide importance for carbon storage, with their growth helping to remove CO2 from the atmosphere and reduce rates of global warming. They also play a crucial role in meeting international climate targets, with reforestation and afforestation schemes being implemented to remove carbon from the atmosphere and offset human CO2 emissions from hard-to-abate sectors such as aviation and certain industries.

The success of these schemes relies on carbon being stored in forests permanently, and wildfires threaten that. Extratropical fires are already emitting half a billion tonnes more CO2 than two decades ago, and the long-term effect depends on how forests recover. More widespread and severe forest fires are a sign that emissions are now out of balance with the carbon captured by post-fire recovery.

Dr Jones, a NERC Independent Research Fellow, said: "The steep trend towards greater extratropical forest fire emissions is a warning of the growing vulnerability of forests and it poses a significant challenge for global targets to tackle climate change.

"We know that forests rebound poorly after the most severe fires, so there is huge interest in how the observed increases in fire severity will influence carbon storage in forests over the coming decades. This demands our close attention."

Escalating wildfire impacts masked until now

Significantly, the increased emissions from forest fires contrasts with the reduced burning of the world's tropical savannahs during the same period. Previous studies have shown that, since 2001, the area burned by all fires (forest and non-forest) fell by a quarter globally, mainly due to this.

The latest findings are important because forest fires burn more severely and release larger amounts of harmful smoke to the atmosphere than savannah grassland fires, presenting major threats to those living near fires and to more distant communities exposed to poor air quality caused by smoke.

The authors say the study debunks the narrative that falling overall annual area burned by fire globally means falling wildfire impact.

"Until now, reduced burning in the already fire-prone savannahs and grasslands has masked increases in forest fire extent and severity that are hugely consequential for society and the environment," said Dr Jones. "Our work shows that fires are increasingly happening where we don't want them to - in forests, where they present the greatest threat to people and to vital carbon stores."

Managing wildfires

Machine learning was key to unlocking new observations about the shifting global geography of forest fires. It was used to group the world's forest ecoregions into 12 distinct pyromes, allowing the researchers to isolate the effects of climate change from other influencing factors such as land use.

This knowledge also reveals new insights into which strategies can be most effective for mitigating wildfires and protecting forests. Dr Jones said: "Substantial financing is required to support strategic programs of forest management, stakeholder engagement, and public education, all of which represent a meaningful shift of fire management strategy from largely reactive to increasingly proactive.

"For example, priority areas for forest management and fire breaks must be defined based on proactive monitoring of forest productivity, particularly in the extratropics. Managing fuel loads in places where they could present greatest danger during fire-favourable weather is a key priority for limiting the severity and impact of fires when they do occur".

The work was supported by funders including the UK Natural Environment Research Council (NERC), European Commission Horizon 2020 programme, and European Space Agency.

'Global rise in forest fire emissions linked to climate change in the extratropics', Matthew W Jones et al, is published online in Science on October 17.
