Pennsylvania State University posted the following news:

* * *

Focus on sanitation and clean water may improve control of endemic cholera

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. -- Public health strategies, from vaccination to improving sanitary conditions, may have different impacts depending on whether a disease is endemic -- persisting in a particular location for an extended period of time -- or a new outbreak, because the dominant transmission routes may differ, according to a new study. The study, which modeled cholera transmission after interventions in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), highlights how long-term strategies like improving access to clean water and sanitary infrastructure could be particularly effective in locations where cholera is endemic due to the contribution of an environmental reservoir.

A paper describing the research, led by researchers at Penn State, was published in the journal PLOS Neglected Tropical Diseases.

"When conducting interventions for an infectious disease, public health officials must decide how to allocate resources and prioritize strategies that will have the most impact," said Alexandre Blake, first author of the paper, who completed the work when he was a postdoctoral researcher in biology in the Penn State Eberly College of Science and the Center for Infectious Disease Dynamics (CIDD). "We are particularly interested in how to allocate resources in endemic situations. If an epidemic is like a forest fire, with transmission burning intensely before coming to a stop, then an endemic disease is more like a slow burn, with transmission constantly in the background with occasional flare ups. We used statistical modeling to better understand cholera transmission in the city of Kalemie in the DRC, where it is endemic. We specifically focused on the two years following a series of interventions to evaluate the impact of those interventions."

Cholera is a bacterial disease that can be transmitted when the bacteria are ingested. The disease can cause severe diarrhea, which can potentially contaminate water sources with the disease-causing bacteria and lead to increased transmission, especially in areas with poor sanitation or limited infrastructure to treat drinking water. Although many people who become infected have no symptoms or mild symptoms, symptomatic cases of cholera can progress quickly, leading to severe dehydration that can be fatal. One study estimated that 1.3 million to 4 million cholera cases worldwide cause between 21,000 and 143,000 deaths each year. The Global Task Force on Cholera Control has created a road map to eliminate cholera in 20 countries by 2030, particularly targeting sub-Saharan Africa, where cholera has been endemic since the early 1970s.

Interventions for cholera often include vaccination, which can be rapidly implemented, as well as water, sanitation and hygiene improvements, collectively called WASH. Large scale WASH strategies, such as improving infrastructure for sanitation and access to clean water, are more expensive and take months to years to implement.

"We know that WASH and vaccination are great tools to prevent cholera," Blake said. "But the impact of vaccination has largely been studied in epidemic situations as a rapid response. WASH is slow and costly to implement which makes it hard to accomplish in low-income settings. To eliminate cholera, we need to better understand the many factors that drive transmission as well as the impact of different interventions in endemic settings."

From late 2013 to early 2016, Doctors Without Borders led intervention efforts in Kalemie, including vaccination and WASH efforts. WASH efforts focused on improving access to clean water, for example by installing pipes, water reservoirs and public drinking fountains, as well as distributing water filters and, during outbreaks, chlorinating drinking water to kill bacteria.

The researchers built several statistical models to determine which combination of factors best explained cholera transmission during this period. They used satellite images of light at night to track seasonal occupancy of the city, which impacts the number of people in the area capable of becoming infected with or transmitting the bacteria. They also included rainfall and other environmental variables that might impact the bacteria's ability to survive in the nearby lake and infect more people.

Although the researchers did not find much impact of the seasonal movement of people in Kalemie, they did find that a large portion of transmission resulted from the environment, likely because the lake acts as a reservoir for the cholera bacteria.

"Because the bacteria persist in the lake, some residents of the city may have opportunities to be regularly exposed and may ultimately develop some level of immunity, which shapes transmission dynamics and eventually the impact of some interventions," Blake said.

The researchers estimated that most of the cholera transmission could be avoided if environmental exposure or contamination was prevented. The researchers also estimated that the majority of residents had some immunity during this period due to regular outbreaks and persistent exposure in the environment. Taken together, the researchers said that vaccination would have a smaller impact on preventing transmission compared to WASH in such settings.

Blake said that early in epidemic situations, most people in the area are assumed not to be immune to the disease, so fast-paced responses like vaccination can be a good choice for management -- but endemic infections require a more comprehensive approach.

"In an epidemic setting, it's almost never a wrong decision to vaccinate because the majority of the population is susceptible to the disease, so vaccinating early in the outbreak can quickly increase immunity levels," he said. "But in endemic settings, this assumption may not be true. Vaccines are ideal for people who do not already have some level of protection from previous exposure, but testing to see if an individual is already immune can be costly or impractical. So, in areas like Kalemie where there may be relatively high levels of immunity due to environmental transmission, we estimate a higher proportion of cases can be avoided from long-term strategies like WASH if both strategies are competing because of limited resources."

An additional benefit of WASH, Blake said, is its positive impact on general health.

"Whether it's talking to people on the street about hygiene or improving sanitation and access to clean water, WASH provides basic needs and can reduce transmission of more than just cholera," he said. "WASH efforts have greater up-front costs but have long-lasting impacts."

Blake noted that studies to confirm the level of immunity in Kalemie and other endemic areas are needed. Ultimately, he said, this information could be used to refine intervention strategies targeting endemic diseases that have an environmental reservoir that contributes to transmission.

"Vaccination and WASH efforts are both critical tools in controlling the spread of diseases like cholera," said Nita Bharti, associate professor of biology, who is also affiliated with CIDD at Penn State and senior author of the paper. "But a 'one size fits all' approach is not going to work across epidemic and endemic situations. We need a location-specific understanding of the role of the environment and transmission routes to control cholera and other infectious diseases in endemic areas."

In addition to Blake and Bharti, the research team at Penn State includes Adam Walder, who has since graduated with a doctoral degree in statistics, and Ephraim Hanks, associate professor of statistics, both affiliated with CIDD. The team also includes Placide Okitayemba Welo at Programme National d'Elimination du Cholera et de lutte contre les autres Maladies Diarrheiques in the DRC; Francisco Luquero at Epicentre in France; and Didier Bompangue at the University of Kinshasa in the DRC.

Funding from the U.S. National Institutes of Health, U.S. National Science Foundation, and the U.S. National Institute of Food and Agriculture supported this research.

urn:contentItem:6DVM-6FJ3-RSJ7-5485-00000-00Eileen Rascon's New Book, "Sleep Tight, My Angel Bear," is a Heartfelt Story of a Young Woman Who Provides a Lost Orphaned Bear a Place to Hibernate for the Winter2025-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisEileen Rascon's New Book, "Sleep Tight, My Angel Bear," is a Heartfelt Story of a Young Woman Who Provides a Lost Orphaned Bear a Place to Hibernate for the Winter

Port Hueneme, CA January 09, 2025 --(PR.com)-- Fulton Books author Eileen Rascon, who was born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, has completed her most recent book, "Sleep Tight, My Angel Bear": a charming and engaging story of a young woman who comes to the rescue of a bear cub after he has lost both his mother and his home in a forest fire.

As a child, author Eileen Rascon immigrated with her family to the United States, where they settled in Chicago, Illinois. She is married to Edward Rascon, and they are the proud parents of four children and proud grandparents of eight. Eileen and Edward relocated from Chicago to Port Hueneme in Ventura County, California. In her spare time, the author enjoys being with her family, and writing poems and stories to share with them.

"A sad little bear with nowhere to go is helped by a kind stranger," writes Rascon. "They become lifetime friends while learning that sometimes the angels we cannot see will bring us to the angels we can see."

Published by Fulton Books, Eileen Rascon's book is a beautiful story that explores the importance of helping others and the impact that being there in one's time of need can have on another's soul. With vibrant illustrations to help bring Rascon's story and message to life, "Sleep Tight, My Angel Bear" is sure to capture the hearts and minds of readers of all ages, encouraging them to come together and help those in need, no matter what their differences or struggles may be.

Readers who wish to experience this uplifting work can purchase "Sleep Tight, My Angel Bear" at bookstores everywhere, or online at the Apple iTunes store, Amazon, Google Play, or Barnes and Noble.

urn:contentItem:6G7B-VXY3-RS6M-450S-00000-00Modeling forest and rangeland ecosystem responses to drought across Hyrcanian bioclimatic zones of Iran using GLM and LAI analysis2025-11-15T08:18:07Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisModeling forest and rangeland ecosystem responses to drought across Hyrcanian bioclimatic zones of Iran using GLM and LAI analysis

Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

Drought substantially affects ecosystem structure and function, shaping vegetation dynamics and influencing long-term environmental sustainability. This study examines drought effects on forest and rangeland ecosystems across three bioclimatic zones in the Hyrcanian region of Iran. MODIS-derived Leaf Area Index (LAI) data (2001–2022) and Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) were used with a generalized linear model (GLM) to assess vegetation responses. The findings indicate that rangeland ecosystems, especially in Zones II and III, are susceptible to drought, with SPI accounting for over 80% of the observed LAI variability in these regions. Forests better withstand dry conditions, with SPI explaining about half of the changes in LAI Zone III, with high elevation and snow-dominated precipitation, is drought-sensitive. Zone I near the Caspian Sea has higher humidity and more stable conditions. Zone II, with a semi-humid cold climate, exhibits the largest LAI fluctuations due to its strong dependence on moisture. Elevation, vegetation type, and climate critically influence drought responses. Targeted land management, including water optimization and conservation, is essential. Future research should integrate additional factors such as soil moisture, land cover change, and anthropogenic pressures such as deforestation, overgrazing, and environmental degradation alongside predictive modeling to enhance ecological sustainability.

IntroductionThe northern forests of Iran, particularly within the Hyrcanian region, encompass a broad range of climatic conditions, spanning from humid temperate forests to semi-arid rangelands. This ancient region, dating back to the Tertiary period, is recognized globally as a biodiversity hotspot. However, rapid land-use changes, climate variability, deforestation, and widespread wildfires, which are often intensified during drought episodes, pose serious threats to these ecosystems1, 2, 3, 4–5. Despite its ecological significance, the Hyrcanian region’s diverse bioclimatic zones have not been sufficiently studied in terms of their ecological responses to drought. Many existing studies have examined drought impacts at broader spatial scales or have relied on indices such as Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI)6. While NDVI is widely used for monitoring vegetation health, it tends to saturate in areas with dense vegetation and does not directly reflect the biophysical properties of plant canopies. Consequently, the LAI, a biophysical parameter closely related to canopy structure, is considered a more accurate and reliable metric for monitoring vegetation and assessing drought impacts particularly in densely forested areas like northern Iran7. LAI is especially useful in evaluating the effectiveness of ecosystem restoration efforts and in monitoring vegetation responses under drought conditions8, 9, 10–11. LAI represents the ratio of total leaf surface area to the ground surface area and offers valuable insights into the structural and functional characteristics of plant canopies12. It is extensively employed in ecological and environmental research, playing a pivotal role in assessing vegetation health and productivity, as well as regulating key ecological processes such as photosynthesis, evapotranspiration, and energy exchange within ecosystems13.

There is a limited number of studies that have used long term satellite-derived data such as MODIS LAI in combination with standardized drought indices like the SPI to evaluate vegetation decline. Additionally, no comprehensive research has yet compared the responses of forest and rangeland ecosystems across different bioclimatic zones of the Hyrcanian region over an extended temporal scale. This gap in the literature presents a barrier to evidence-based, localized strategies for managing ecosystems under increasingly unstable climatic conditions. Drought is a naturally occurring and slowly developing phenomenon caused by prolonged periods of insufficient precipitation. Over recent decades, its frequency and severity have risen globally, primarily due to increased water demand and climate change. Drought has widespread implications for agriculture, economies, and ecosystems14,15. In Iran, the frequency and intensity of drought events have shown a significant upward trend over the past three decades, posing substantial challenges to environmental sustainability and resource management. To systematically evaluate drought characteristics, indices such as the SPI, Standardized Precipitation Evapotranspiration Index (SPEI), and Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI) are commonly used16. In addition to drought indices, numerous studies have investigated the impact of drought on vegetation health and productivity, revealing that severe droughts can cause substantial declines in ecosystem function. However, climate adaptation measures and enhanced land management practices have improved ecosystem resilience (see Table 1 for specific examples). Despite these findings, there is still limited research on how regional bioclimatic characteristics, ecological thresholds, and vegetation types influence ecosystem responses to drought. Among the various drought indices, the SPI is the most widely used due to its simplicity in calculation and flexibility across different time scales, making it a practical and reliable tool for regions with high climatic variability, such as northern Iran17. Remote sensing data, particularly MODIS-derived LAI, provide valuable insights into temporal changes in vegetation cover and enable accurate assessment of drought impacts at regional scales17,18.

In this study, the SPI is used in conjunction with LAI data to analyze the effects of drought on vegetation across the Hyrcanian region. The research focuses on three distinct bioclimatic zones within the region, each with differing moisture regimes and ecological sensitivities. Zone I, located near the Caspian Sea, is characterized by high humidity, whereas Zones II and III are relatively drier and more susceptible to drought stress. The main objectives of this study are as follows: (1) To analyze the temporal trends of LAI in forest and rangeland ecosystems from 2001 to 2022 across different bioclimatic zones; (2) To examine the relationship between vegetation dynamics and drought severity within these zones over the long term; (3) To compare the responses of forest and rangeland ecosystems to drought across the diverse bioclimatic zones of the Hyrcanian region.

The findings of this study aim to enhance understanding of drought’s impact on vegetation in northern Iran and provide practical recommendations for the conservation and sustainable management of forest and rangeland ecosystems. Given the increasing frequency and severity of drought events, these insights are expected to play a critical role in developing adaptive strategies to strengthen both the ecological and economic resilience of these landscapes.

Materials and methods

Study area

This study was conducted in northern Iran’s rangelands and forestlands, including the Hyrcanian region. The Hyrcanian forests and rangelands contain plant species that are remnants of the Arcto-Tertiary period, making them of high botanical geographical significance and one of the wealthiest and most diverse natural ecosystems in the world29. This region has outstanding biodiversity value and is recognized as a unique area in many environmental studies. According to the classification by Khatibi and Saberi (2020), this region includes three bioclimatic zones that were selected for this study30 (Fig. 1) These three zones were selected based on multivariate statistical and cluster analysis, which examined 137 climatic parameters across Iran between 1981 and 2018. These analyses led to the identification of 26 bioclimatic regions in the country, which were then compared with the vegetation cover map of Iran. The biotic and climatic characteristics of each zone are presented in Table 2.

LAI extraction and rainfall calculations

This study utilized the MODIS LAI product (“MODIS/061/MYD15A2H V6.1”) to analyze LAI dynamics (https://doi.org/10.5067/MODIS/MYD15A2H.061). The product’s algorithm selects the best pixel from all the images captured by the Aqua sensor within 8-day time periods. In this study, we used a maximum-value composite procedure (MVC) to extract the maximum values of the LAI index monthly. This approach effectively eliminated noise and unwanted signals, significantly enhancing the final data quality.

The MODIS LAI product has been extensively validated in numerous field studies and used in the intercomparison of various LAI products. This product demonstrates high accuracy and has been widely validated in studies, including those by Yan et al. and other reputable scientific sources31. MODIS LAI data are recognized as accurate and reliable for long-term vegetation studies.

The Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform extracted LAI data from 2001 to 2022. GEE’s filtering capabilities defined the relevant dataset, study period, and spectral bands. To ensure accuracy, a scale factor of 0.1 was applied to refine the LAI values, and a 1-kilometer spatial resolution was maintained for consistency with other environmental datasets incorporated in this study.

Monthly precipitation data from 28 synoptic stations, evenly distributed across the study area, were obtained from the Islamic Republic of Iran Meteorological Organization (IRIMO, 2022; www.irimo.ir) from 2001 to 2022. To estimate the average monthly precipitation for each homogeneous bioclimatic region, a Thiessen polygon network was first constructed based on the spatial distribution of the selected synoptic stations (see Supplementary Fig. S1 online). Using this network, the mean monthly precipitation for each bioclimatic sub-region was calculated through a weighted averaging approach, where the contribution of each station was determined by the area of its corresponding Thiessen polygon within that sub-region. The land use map of the country’s rangelands and forests was also obtained from Iran’s Research Institute of Forests and Rangelands (R.I.F.R., 2022; www.rifr-ac.ir).

Trend analysis

The Mann-Kendall (MK) test is a widely used nonparametric approach for detecting trends in time series data. However, when a time series exhibits positive autocorrelation, the MK test may overestimate trend significance, potentially leading to false detections32. To mitigate this issue, they introduced the concept of “prewhitening” the time series before applying the MK test, effectively reducing the influence of autocorrelation and improving the reliability of trend detection33,34.

Researchers demonstrated that when a time series exhibits positive autocorrelation, trend detection tests such as the MK test tend to overestimate the statistical significance of trends. This can result in false identification of trends that are not truly present. To address this issue, they proposed a preprocessing step known as pre-whitening before conducting any trend analysis33.

Following their recommendation, subsequent studies, including those by Douglas et al. and Zhang et al., successfully applied the pre-whitening technique to detect temporal trends in streamflow data across the United States and Canada. The standard procedure for applying this method involves the following steps: (1) Calculate the lag-1 serial correlation coefficient, denoted as r̂1, (2) If r̂1 is not statistically significant at the chosen significance level αL, apply the trend detection test directly to the original time series (y1, y2, …, yn), (3) The trend identification test is applied to the pre-whitened time series (y2 - r̂1y1, y3 - r̂1y2, …, yn - r̂1yn-1). This study employed the “modifiedmk” package in R (10.32614/CRAN.package.modifiedmk) to implement the PW-MK test36.

The Theil-Sen estimator was utilized to determine the slope magnitude of the detected trends. Renowned for its robustness, the Theil-Sen method does not assume a specific data distribution and remains resistant to outliers. It calculates the median slope across all possible pairs of data points within the time series, ensuring a reliable and unbiased estimation of the trend. The primary strength of the Theil–Sen median trend analysis is its ability to effectively manage nonnormal distributions and outliers, making it a robust alternative to conventional trend estimation techniques. By employing this method, we ensured that the trend analysis results remained accurate, reliable, and resistant to noise or extreme data variations.

Meteorological drought

Our study employed the SPI to assess meteorological drought, the most widely utilized among the various drought indices due to its adaptable timescale and relatively simple calculation process38. As SPI quantifies drought conditions by comparing current precipitation levels with historical records over a specified period, it is well-suited for application in northern Iran, as they have highlighted18 Positive SPI values indicate above-average moisture levels, whereas negative values signify drier-than-normal conditions. The SPI was computed for each bioclimatic subregion at 1, 3, 6, 9, and 12-month timescales using the weighted average of monthly precipitation specific to each subregion.

Drought frequency

The SPI at a 12-month scale was employed to identify drought and wet periods, as this time scale reflects a complete annual climatic cycle. In this study, monthly SPI values were calculated for each bioclimatic region from January 2001 to December 2022 (a total of 264 months).

Drought frequency was defined as the percentage of months in which SPI values were less than − 1, relative to the total number of months in the study period. Similarly, wet frequency was calculated as the percentage of months with SPI values greater than + 1.

To distinguish the severity levels of drought and wetness, the classification thresholds presented in Table 3 were applied39. Based on this classification, the frequency of each drought/wetness class (moderate, severe, and extreme) was separately calculated and analyzed for each bioclimatic region.

Effective SPI.

This study investigates the relationship between LAI in rangeland and forest ecosystems and meteorological drought, as represented by the SPI. Different types of droughts can variably affect the ecological conditions of these ecosystems, with impacts varying across bioclimatic regions and time scales (e.g., SPI at 1, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months). Additionally, ecological responses may reflect a temporal delay influenced by past drought events. To understand these dynamics, it is critical to identify the SPI component most significantly affecting LAI variations in each bioclimatic region and month. To this end, cross-correlation analysis was conducted between SPI values (with time lags of 0 to 12 months) and corresponding LAI values for each bioclimatic sub-region and month. The SPI component with the highest correlation coefficient, defined by its specific time scale and lag, was identified as the ‘effective SPI’ for each sub-region and month. This ‘effective SPI’ is used throughout the study to represent the SPI value most closely associated with LAI variability.

Vegetation modeling via the GLM

The average LAI values for rangeland and forest ecosystems from 2001 to 2022 were examined to evaluate vegetation’s spatiotemporal patterns and its response to drought. For this purpose, the LAI anomaly was calculated monthly for each bioclimatic zone from January 2001 to December 2022. This analysis aimed to evaluate the strength of the relationship between LAI anomalies and SPI over varying temporal periods. Subsequently, the effective SPI was computed separately for each month. The responses of vegetation within rangeland and forest ecosystems to the effective SPI were then examined using a GLM for each subregion. This methodology offers valuable insights into how vegetation dynamics in these ecosystems are affected by drought conditions over time.

GLMs help capture complex associations between response and predictor variables. In this study, the variables under investigation are the LAI and SPI indices based on monthly time series data. Given the nature of the SPI, the number of observations for each time scale (i.e., 1, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months) is equal to the number of monthly LAI observations. The LAI variable is a continuous variable taking values 0 ≤ LAI. Therefore, for regression GLM models, we need to use continuous distributions on )0, ∞). The Gamma and Gaussian distributions with a “log” link function can satisfy that. The gamma distribution is generally used to gather heavy-skewed data. However, our results revealed that the LAI is not too skewed and tends to follow a normal distribution. Hence, we used the Gaussian distribution with a “log” link function for GLM models.

To evaluate the predictive performance of the GLM models given the relatively small sample size (22 observations per model), we applied a leave-one-out cross-validation (LOO-CV) approach, also known as Jackknife. In this method, one observation was excluded in each iteration, and the model was trained on the remaining data to predict the excluded value. This process was repeated until each observation had been left out once and predicted accordingly40.

Results and discussion

Seasonal LAI trends and green seasons by bioclimatic zone

LAI reflects key aspects of vegetation dynamics, including seasonal variation, phenology, and productivity. As shown in Fig. 2, across bioclimatic zones, LAI trends follow predictable seasonal patterns shaped by climatic drivers and vegetation type. Forests exhibit low LAI from November to March due to dormancy, while rangelands reach their minimum between July and February, driven by water and temperature stress. Based on LAI anomalies above the 75th percentile (2001–2022), green seasons vary: March–June in R_II, April–June in R_III, May–July in R_I, and May–August in forests. These patterns underscore the role of temperature, precipitation, and dormancy in regulating productivity41. Long-term LAI monitoring enhances our understanding of climate impacts and supports informed land management, as observed in similar Central Asian rangelands.

LAI trends across bioclimatic zones.

Table 4 provides a quantitative summary of monthly and seasonal LAI trends across different forest and rangeland zones. Among the studied regions, Zone R_III exhibited the strongest and most consistent positive trends throughout the year. Notably, its annual trend (Zmk = 3.12**, Sen’s slope = 0.03) and green season trend (Zmk = 2.31*, slope = 0.03) were the highest among all zones. During autumn, R_III showed significant increases, especially in October (Zmk = 3.28**, slope = 0.17) and September (Zmk = 2.80**, slope = 0.15), indicating an extension of the growing season likely linked to warming conditions. Similarly, Zone R_I showed high seasonal sensitivity, with statistically significant increases during spring and summer months notably in May (Zmk = 2.48*, slope = 0.64) and June (Zmk = 2.38*, slope = 0.46) resulting in the second-highest annual trend (Zmk = 2.85*, slope = 0.02). In contrast, Zone R_II exhibited lower trend magnitudes and fewer significant changes, reflecting greater vegetation stability and potential adaptation to higher temperature regimes.

F_I showed modest but significant increases in forested zones in autumn (October: Zmk = 2.11*, slope = 2.00) and over the year (annual: Zmk = 2.11*, slope = 0.07). F_II and F_III displayed weaker or inconsistent trends, suggesting varied responses to climatic drivers such as temperature and precipitation. These findings highlight notable spatial heterogeneity in LAI dynamics across bioclimatic zones. The highest LAI increases are concentrated in R_III and R_I, emphasizing their sensitivity to seasonal and interannual climate variability. In contrast, R_II appears more stable, possibly due to its ecological resilience or slower response to recent climatic shifts. This analysis enables more direct comparison and supports a clearer understanding of vegetation responses across ecoregions by including significance levels and slope magnitudes.

The results demonstrated Google Earth Engine-derived indices’ high accuracy and practical applicability for large-scale LAI estimation, supporting improved vegetation monitoring and land management strategies. However, it should be noted that the spatial resolution of MODIS LAI data may limit the detection of fine-scale ecological changes, which could introduce uncertainties into the interpretation of localized vegetation dynamics.

As a result, combining remote sensing with field measurements provides a comprehensive understanding of vegetation dynamics and productivity42. Our results align with other studies, showing that LAI trends are highly responsive to climate, with forest and rangeland ecosystems exhibiting distinct seasonal and regional variations. These shifts emphasize the role of climate change, moisture, and temperature in regulating vegetation phenology, stressing the need for long-term monitoring and adaptive land management strategies43, 44–45.

Drought frequency across bioclimatic zones

The spatial distribution of drought classes across different bioclimatic zones is illustrated (Fig. 3), along with a pie chart showing their proportional distribution (Fig. 3a). A 22-year analysis reveals significant regional differences in climate extremes. Region III, which experienced the highest drought frequency (17.3%), showed a predominance of Severe Drought (SD) events, highlighting increased environmental stress. However, this does not uniformly affect vegetation. Despite frequent drought conditions, rangelands in Region III display significant positive trends in LAI, particularly in the spring and late summer, suggesting that seasonal moisture inputs such as early snowmelt and late-summer rainfall mitigate drought effects and support vegetation growth during key periods.

In contrast, forests in Region III show no significant long-term LAI trend, although there are positive monthly trends, with a notable increase in December. This indicates a responsive but insufficient reaction to seasonal moisture. Thus, the vegetation in Region III, especially in rangelands, shows resilience that is more influenced by moisture timing and sources (e.g., snowpack) than by drought class frequency alone. In Region I, which experiences the highest frequency of Moist-Wet (MW) conditions, a significant upward trend in LAI aligns with improved moisture availability and increased vegetation productivity. This positive correlation between LAI and frequent wet conditions indicates a robust ecological response in this low-elevation region near the Caspian Sea. Region II, however, shows no significant trend in LAI, despite experiencing a higher frequency of Extreme Wet (EW) and Moderate Drought (MD) conditions compared to Region I. The alternating extremes of wet and dry conditions may cause instability in vegetation growth, preventing a clear trend in LAI. Additionally, the frequent Severe Wet (SW) conditions in Region II, similar to Region III, suggest high variability in precipitation patterns.

These findings are consistent with studies from Central Asia and the French Alps, which highlight the role of water availability in moderating the impacts of climatic extremes46,47. In our research, regions with limited water (II and III) showed increased sensitivity to climatic changes, reflecting broader global patterns of vegetation stress due to water scarcity. Elevation also plays a significant role in shaping local climates48. Region I, located at lower elevations near the Caspian Sea, experiences higher humidity and reduced drought stress. In contrast, at higher elevations, Region III supports drought-tolerant species that help maintain ecosystem stability. Finally, our study’s weak correlation between long-term drought indices and surface water changes echoes previous research. This suggests that human activities and water management practices are crucial factors in determining water resource availability, highlighting the need for adaptive water resource management strategies in vulnerable regions49.

Selection of the effective SPI for the LAI

Cross-correlation analysis of the SPI and LAI time series across bioclimatic zones shows significant spatial and temporal variations in the relationship between precipitation and vegetation growth. Results indicate that the effect of SPI on LAI varies depending on the month and the bioclimatic zone. The Spearman correlation coefficients between LAI and various SPI timescales have been calculated (see Supplementary Fig. S2 online). In summary, the matrix of Spearman correlation coefficients and the selected effective SPI (eSPI) values for each month of the year across the studied regions are displayed (Fig. 4). Rangeland ecosystems show a stronger SPI-LAI correlation than forest ecosystems, suggesting that precipitation variability has a more immediate impact on vegetation in these areas. In bioclimatic Zone II, the highest correlations occur from May to October, particularly with the 6-month and 9-month SPI with a one-month lag. This highlights the importance of medium-term droughts in driving LAI variations in rangelands. The dynamics of soil moisture and its response to precipitation are highly complex and depend not only on the amount of rainfall but also on factors such as evapotranspiration, runoff, vegetation type, soil properties, meteorological conditions, and topography50,51. Therefore, vegetation response to precipitation variability is influenced by long-term soil water storage resulting from the cumulative and interactive effects of these factors. As a result, the impact of precipitation on vegetation is often observed with a time lag. Similarly, Zone III exhibits a peak correlation between May and July, aligning with the growing season and indicating that early to mid-spring precipitation influences vegetation productivity. These months, shown in green (Fig. 4), represent the period when SPI most effectively explains LAI fluctuations. In forest ecosystems, the strongest SPI-LAI correlations occur from May to September, during peak growth months, indicating the crucial role of spring and summer precipitation in forest photosynthesis and biomass production. Lower correlations in winter months (e.g., January and February) suggest that winter precipitation has less direct influence on LAI fluctuations due to the dormant phase of forest vegetation. The study of Balochistan Province, Pakistan, is relevant to our work, as it also examines the SPI-vegetation productivity relationship, validating our findings by showing how SPI timescales affect vegetation productivity during mid-term droughts. Both studies emphasize the strong SPI-vegetation correlation during peak growing seasons, confirming SPI’s effectiveness as a drought-monitoring tool across ecosystems52.

The study’s results, as presented in Table 5, provide a detailed analysis of the relationship between the LAI and the SPI across different bioclimatic zones using a GLM. The findings highlight the seasonal variations in LAI response to drought conditions, with the regression models indicating varying degrees of correlation across different months and regions. The adjusted R² values demonstrate how well the SPI explains variations in LAI, with some regions and months showing stronger correlations than others. For example, such regions as R_II and R_III exhibit higher adjusted R² values in certain months, suggesting a more substantial predictive capacity of the SPI for LAI in these areas. Additionally, the root mean square error (RMSE) values provide insights into the model’s accuracy, with lower values indicating better model performance. The results suggest that SPI significantly influences LAI trends, particularly in months with more pronounced drought effects. These findings have important implications for environmental monitoring and agricultural management, providing a framework for assessing vegetation responses to climatic variability. By demonstrating the effectiveness of GLM in analyzing LAI-SPI relationships, the study contributes valuable knowledge for predicting vegetation dynamics in response to drought stress, which can inform sustainable land and water resource management strategies.

Overall, changes in the LAI in response to drought were more predictable in rangelands than in forests, as shown in Table 5. The GLM analysis results indicated that in certain months, the Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) explained more than 80% of the variations in the LAI in bioclimatic zones R-II and R-III (Table 5). This strong statistical association highlights the dominant role of temporal precipitation fluctuations, as captured by SPI, in driving vegetation canopy dynamics across these ecosystems. The high explanatory power of the model reflects the sensitivity of canopy structure and leaf area to drought conditions, particularly in regions where water availability is a primary limiting factor for vegetation growth. In forests, the SPI also explained up to about 50% of the variations in LAI in certain months, although this value is lower than that observed in rangelands. This difference may be attributed to the distinct physiological characteristics of plant species and their specific adaptations to environmental stress46. Rangeland ecosystems are typically more sensitive to moisture fluctuations due to their reliance on surface and near-surface soil moisture, which is directly influenced by short-term and seasonal precipitation patterns. In contrast, forest ecosystems exhibit a more complex response to drought conditions, as their deeper root systems enable them to access water from deeper soil layers. Understanding these differences is essential for developing targeted management strategies that can effectively mitigate the impacts of climate change and ensure the sustainability of ecosystem health and function. A study conducted in the Khansar region also supports our findings by indicating that rangelands are more drought-sensitive. This emphasizes the importance of understanding ecosystem-specific responses to drought for effective land management53.

Model diagnostics and assumption checking

We used the Gaussian distribution with a log link function for the GLM models, as the LAI values are continuous and non-negative. To support this choice, the histograms of the observed LAI values for each month of the year and each study area, along with their corresponding theoretical Gaussian distributions, can be found as Supplementary Fig. S3 online.

The standardized residuals of the GLM models closely followed a normal distribution, confirming the validity of the normality assumption and suggesting good model fit with no major misspecification issues (see Supplementary Fig. S4 and Fig.S5 online).

Furthermore, analysis of residuals indicated no visible patterns when plotted against fitted values or independent variables, supporting the assumptions of residual independence and homoscedasticity across the range of predictors (see Supplementary Fig. S6 and Fig.S7 online).

Cross-validation of GLM models

The results of the Jackknife cross-validation indicated that model performance was generally better in rangeland areas than forest areas. This was supported by lower prediction errors (e.g., RMSE and MAE) and higher correlation coefficients between predicted and observed LAI values in rangelands (see Supplementary Fig. S8 and Fig.S9 online). These findings suggest that the models simulate vegetation responses to climatic variability more reliably in rangeland ecosystems.

LAI deviation across forest and rangeland ecosystems under drought conditions

Forest ecosystems (F_I, F_II, F_III) exhibit stronger drought resistance than rangeland ecosystems (R_I, R_II, R_III), as indicated by fewer minor fluctuations in their LAI during dry periods (Fig. 6). Forests maintain stable LAI during extreme dry conditions (ED and SD) due to deeper root systems, greater species diversity, and the creation of moisture-retaining microclimates beneath the canopy. This microclimate effect is significant in forest ecosystems. Microclimate, defined as the climatic conditions near the ground surface at a small scale from a few centimeters to several hundred meters, plays a crucial role in regulating plant survival, growth, distribution, and interactions54. Compositional differences among habitats have been attributed to variations in microclimate. Numerous studies have shown that forests exhibit a markedly different microclimate compared to grasslands, being cooler during the day, warmer at night, and more humid during the daytime55. A microclimate with reduced temperature fluctuations in the Hyrcanian forests also enhances soil water retention.

These adaptations allow forests to resist drought stress better. In addition, biodiversity is widely recognized as a key factor in maintaining the stability and functionality of ecosystems in the face of environmental changes and ecological stressors. Numerous studies have shown that higher species diversity enhances the capacity of ecosystems to cope with challenges such as drought56, 57–58. Therefore, the Caspian Hyrcanian forests, with their high biodiversity, are better equipped to withstand drought conditions and maintain ecosystem productivity during dry periods. On the other hand, the soil water holding capacity and soil water availability are also higher in forests compared to grasslands due to greater soil porosity59which contributes to the higher drought resistance of Hyrcanian forests. Rangelands, especially in bioclimatic Zones II and III, show more significant LAI fluctuations during dry months, reflecting greater vulnerability to drought. This is due to their lack of tree cover, leading to quicker surface moisture loss. However, with slightly better drought resistance, rangelands in Zone I still exhibit negative LAI deviations, indicating they face challenges during droughts. The role of ecosystem type in shaping responses to drought, Similar to our results on the differential impacts of drought on highlands and lowlands, this study highlights how forests demonstrate better drought resistance due to deeper root systems and moisture-retaining microclimates. In contrast, rangelands experience more significant fluctuations in vegetation indices. Additionally, both studies emphasize the importance of ecosystem-specific adaptations in mitigating the impacts of extreme climate events60. The variation in drought vulnerability between ecosystems is influenced by factors such as root allocation, mycorrhizal associations, and xylem anatomy61. Given these results, active management is needed for rangelands, particularly in drought-prone areas, to maintain productivity and ecological health. Sustainable forest management is crucial for improving resilience to drought and preserving ecosystem services like carbon sequestration and water filtration. Both ecosystems require tailored management strategies to cope with increasing drought conditions and ensure long-term ecosystem stability in the face of climate change.

The 2007 assessment by the International Expert Panel emphasizes the need for adaptive management strategies despite existing knowledge gaps62. These strategies can help reduce forests’ environmental, social, and economic vulnerabilities and the community’s dependence on them, ensuring long-term sustainability amid increasing drought. In this study, we define resistance as the ability of an ecosystem to survive and maintain its functions during a disturbance (such as drought). At the same time, resilience refers to the capacity to return to pre-disturbance performance levels63. Due to the lack of a strong correlation between LAI and the drought index in forested areas across the studied bioclimatic zones, we assessed drought resistance by analyzing LAI fluctuations across different drought classes. s shown (Fig. 5), the results indicate that vegetation in the humid forest zone (F_I) exhibits the least LAI variability under both drought and wet conditions, reflecting a high level of resistance to climate variability. In the semi-humid zone (F_II), moderate LAI fluctuations were observed, indicating a combination of intermediate resistance and partial resilience. However, in the semi-arid zone (F_III), the highest fluctuations in LAI occurred, with marked increases during wet periods and sharp declines during droughts. This pattern contrasts with the commonly proposed delayed response hypothesis for semi-arid ecosystems64. It suggests that vegetation in this zone responds rapidly to climatic changes, displaying high short-term resilience during wet periods but low resistance to drought stress. This is particularly evident in semi-arid climates, where vegetation is susceptible to changes in precipitation, which directly influences its growth patterns and survival rates. The sensitivity to precipitation variations in these climates results in more pronounced fluctuations in vegetation indices, such as LAI, during extreme weather conditions. Our study and the comparative study show that drought resistance and resilience can be analyzed using LAI deviations. Both studies demonstrate that forest ecosystems maintain stability under extreme drought conditions, while rangelands experience more significant fluctuations in LAI, indicating higher vulnerability to drought stress65. A similar analysis in three rangeland regions with differing bioclimatic conditions showed that humid rangelands (R_I) exhibited relatively low LAI fluctuations, indicating notable resistance to drought. In the semi-humid rangelands (R_II), more pronounced LAI fluctuations and noticeable reductions during dry periods were observed, suggesting reduced resistance and moderate resilience. The semi-arid rangelands (R_III) experienced the highest LAI variability, with substantial declines under drought conditions, reflecting low resistance and resilience to water stress. In summary, forest ecosystems across all three bioclimatic zones showed lower LAI variability than rangelands, indicating higher resistance to drought. However, rangelands exhibited quicker recovery in some wet conditions, demonstrating comparatively higher short-term resilience. Based on these findings, targeted ecosystem-specific management strategies can be developed. Using remote sensing technologies to monitor changes in vegetation cover is essential. These methods will help identify damaged areas and enable timely decision-making for conserving natural resources. Additionally, development plans should be implemented with precise environmental assessments and consideration of new climatic conditions to prevent further degradation. For instance, in semi-arid rangelands (R_III) where low resistance and resilience were observed, spatial policies should prioritize active restoration efforts, such as soil conservation and introducing drought-tolerant shrub species with deeper root systems. Conversely, in humid forest zones (F_I) where vegetation showed strong drought resistance, sustainable forest management practices focused on maintaining canopy cover and limiting land-use change should be reinforced.

Previous studies have shown that climate change impacts on grassland vegetation phenology vary by elevation66,67. A previous study found that herbaceous and annual plant-dominated rangelands are more vulnerable to drought than those dominated by shrubs and bushes, primarily due to their shallower root systems and lower capacity for water retention68.

In continuation of examining the role of ecosystem type in drought response, it is evident that environmental and anthropogenic factors such as temperature, land-use change, and soil characteristics also play critical roles in intensifying or mitigating drought impacts. Rising temperatures and heatwaves can significantly affect forest functioning by intensifying evaporation from both root systems and tree canopies, leading to increased dryness and biological stress, ultimately causing tree mortality even in the absence of precipitation deficits69. Therefore, drought assessments must thoroughly consider the effects of temperature and evapotranspiration on forest desiccation and vulnerability.

Moreover, recent studies have widely recognized meteorological variables such as temperature and precipitation as primary drivers of vegetation dynamics, particularly influencing LAI variations. These factors are closely linked to reduced greenness and structural changes in forest vegetation under warmer conditions70. In parallel, soil serving as the foundational medium for plant growth plays a vital role in water retention and the resilience of vegetation cover. In forest and rangeland ecosystems, soil degradation caused by recurrent droughts or human activities can reduce its moisture-holding capacity and, consequently, impair plant growth. This process, which results from the interaction of multiple stressors, including climate change and drought, can severely diminish vegetation greenness and survival71.

Additionally, land-use change is a major driver in weakening the resilience of natural ecosystems to drought. The conversion of forests to agricultural lands, infrastructure development, mining activities, and human-induced wildfires are among the leading causes of deforestation and vegetation loss in the Hyrcanian forests72,73. Such activities reduce canopy cover, accelerate surface moisture loss, degrade soil structure, and diminish biodiversity, reducing the ecosystem’s capacity to withstand drought stress.

Overall, understanding the complex interactions among climatic factors (e.g., temperature and precipitation), soil properties, and human-induced disturbances (e.g., land-use change and unsustainable exploitation) is essential for accurately interpreting ecosystem responses to drought and developing effective management and mitigation strategies.

The LAI distribution function for severe drought (SPI = -2), extreme wet conditions (SPI = + 2), and normal conditions in May for rangelands and forests across bioclimatic regions is illustrated (Fig. 7). The results indicate that although the SPI index affects forest vegetation cover, its impact is weaker and less pronounced than that of rangelands. This is due to the Hyrcanian forests’ ability to retain moisture during drought, aided by relative precipitation, fog, and deep soils. Forest biodiversity also enhances resilience to climate stressors61. Having adapted to water scarcity, natural forests are more resilient to climate fluctuations. Moreover, LAI may not be the most accurate metric for forest cover changes; alternatives like NDVI, EVI, or VCI might better capture drought impacts. The SPI index, focusing on meteorological drought, does not consider hydrological effects like groundwater depletion. Indices like SPEI or SSI may offer a more accurate measure of drought effects on water availability. Thus, the weak correlation between SPI and vegetation changes is due to humid forest conditions, resilience, index limitations, and the difference between meteorological and hydrological droughts. Further studies should explore these factors. In contrast, rangelands are more drought-sensitive due to reduced precipitation and water resources. Herbaceous and shrubby species in rangelands with shallow root systems are highly vulnerable. The correlation between LAI and SPI is stronger here, showing a clear link between medium-term droughts and vegetation reduction. A significant LAI decline in rangelands reflects decreased productivity and biodiversity, while trees in forests with deeper roots store and use water more effectively, making them more drought-resistant. Studies show that climatic factors like rainfall have a direct impact on LAI. Drought periods lead to a significant decline in vegetation cover in rangelands, while forests demonstrate resistance to such stressors, aligning with the patterns outlined (Fig. 7)74.

Conclusion

This study examined the impact of drought conditions on forest and rangeland ecosystems within the Hyrcanian bioclimatic zones of Iran, utilizing the LAI and the SPI as primary indicators. The results demonstrated that rangeland vegetation is more sensitive to drought, exhibiting greater fluctuations in LAI, whereas forests, characterized by deeper root systems and canopy-driven microclimates, show higher resistance. This resistance in forests is attributed to their ability to access subsurface water resources and reduce surface evaporation; however, their resilience is lower due to a longer recovery time required for canopy restoration following drought events. Significant variations in vegetation responses to drought were observed across different bioclimatic zones, likely due to differences in vegetation types and climatic and topographic factors such as temperature, precipitation, and elevation. Statistical models indicated that the SPI explained over 80% of the variability in LAI in certain rangeland areas, whereas this value was approximately 50% in forested regions. Our findings revealed that vegetation in the humid zone (F_I) exhibited the least variability in the LAI under varying moisture conditions, indicating the highest level of drought resistance. In contrast, the semi-arid zone (F_III) experienced the most significant LAI fluctuations, with sharp declines during drought and rapid increases during wet periods, reflecting low resilience in this zone. This pattern differs from previous studies’ commonly reported delayed response of semi-arid ecosystems to drought. Such differences may be attributed to specific bioclimatic characteristics of the region, the impact of successive drought events, or human interventions such as land-use changes and ecological pressures.

From a management perspective, these findings underscore the necessity for tailored strategies for forest and rangeland ecosystems. In drought-affected rangelands, particularly those under intense stress, priority should be given to improving soil quality and introducing drought-resistant species, whereas maintaining biodiversity and increasing canopy density in forests can enhance ecosystem resistance. Additionally, water resource management should be optimized considering ecosystems’ spatial and temporal sensitivity to drought. This study has certain limitations that may influence the interpretation of results. The moderate spatial resolution of MODIS satellite data may not fully capture vegetation responses at finer scales. Furthermore, the SPI, which focuses solely on meteorological drought, does not encompass drought stress’s full hydrological and biological dimensions. Using linear models might also inadequately represent the complex responses of vegetation to drought conditions. Future research is recommended to incorporate key environmental variables such as temperature, soil moisture, evapotranspiration, and soil infiltration into predictive models to enhance accuracy and comprehensiveness. Applying advanced modeling approaches capable of capturing nonlinear and multifaceted interactions could further improve the precision of results and inform more effective management interventions. Ultimately, this study provides important insights into the effects of drought on the Hyrcanian Forest and rangeland ecosystems and establishes a scientific foundation for developing sustainable management and long-term resilience strategies for these ecosystems.

urn:contentItem:6FJ8-P243-RRTG-94T0-00000-00Wildfires are ravaging the West. Can new bipartisan legislation help?2025-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & US NEWSWildfires are ravaging the West. Can new bipartisan legislation help?Amy Joi O'Donoghue

Isaac Hale, Deseret News

The Sandhurst Fire burns near radio towers above Ensign Peak and north of Salt Lake City on Saturday, July 20, 2024.

1

After a deadly year of wildfires, including the California fires that devastated the area around Los Angeles, lawmakers are looking at ways to reduce their number and spread.

Last year, Utah logged 1,244 reports of wildfires, the highest number recorded since 2020. Nationally, the total acres burned rose from 2.7 million acres in 2023 to nearly nine million in 2024, a 231% increase.

To that end, Sen. John Curtis, R-Utah, and three of his fellow senators introduced the Fix Our Forests Act, bipartisan legislation meant to combat catastrophic wildfires, restore forest ecosystems, and make federal forest management more efficient and responsive.

"Utah and the American West are on the front lines of a growing wildfire crisis - and the longer we wait, the more acres will burn, and more families will be impacted," Curtis said upon introduction of the bill on Friday.

"After months of bipartisan cooperation and consensus-building, my colleagues and I are introducing comprehensive legislation to support forest health, accelerate restoration, and equip local leaders - from fire chiefs to mayors - with the tools and data they need to protect lives, property, and landscapes. I'm proud of this bill and look forward to receiving additional input from my colleagues as it advances through committee and the full Senate."

The other sponsors include Sens. John Hickenlooper, D-Colo., Tim Sheehy, R-Mont., and Alex Padilla, D-Calif.

Rex Warner, for the Deseret News

Post CA Fires_000023.JPG

Post CA Fires_000023.JPG

1

California's deadly wildfire rampage

California wildfires this year destroyed more than 11,000 homes and left a wave of fear in evacuated communities who wondered if anything would be left.

The California fires were amplified by strong winds, but in addition to that, dried out, overcrowded forests are a key culprit in the dramatic uptick Western states are seeing in wildfire frequency and the resulting devastation.

Frustration over wildfires

Curtis said in a media call with Utah reporters on Friday that he drove up to Brian Head Resort and could see the charred trees from a previous "horrific fire" still left standing.

"And I remember the news cycle at the time, there were some very angry local people. I think even local legislators were angry because this could have been prevented. The Forest Service had not managed these forests in a way that would have prevented this forest fire," Curtis said.

"That's what this bill is all about. It's about managing our forest in a way that is in harmony with those who definitely want to preserve and protect them, - and, by the way, count me as one of those - but also in a way that doesn't tie hands, that helps these people make good decisions and do so quicker. And so I think this is a huge deal for Utah, for the West, for those who worry about forest fires in the area," he added.

It is a sentiment that has been expressed before, and for years.

The Seeley Fire in 2012 is an example.

A 2012 plume of smoke that state officials said a Forest Service official decided to let burn erupted into the Seeley Fire, which cost $9 million to quell and caused immense problems with the watershed in Emery County.

In a meeting years later, Utah Gov. Spencer Cox was blunt: "Someone made a terrible decision without consulting with state and local officials."

Curtis emphasized that the bill would not exclude public input and is a bipartisan effort - a heavy lift during this time of polarized politics.

Drying conditions and less moisture is a combination that makes the situation worse, and his colleagues see that.

"We can see Republicans and Democrats coming together, spending a large amount of time in overcoming differences - and, I don't mind telling you - some pretty large differences in how we approach this and finding a path forward and (this is) a big huge shout out to my three Senate colleagues."

What the Fix Our Forests Act would do

Curtis said forest health challenges are also increasing in frequency and severity due to climate stressors like drought and fire, and biological threats like invasive species - all of which the West is particularly vulnerable to. From 2001 to 2019, total forest area declined by 2.3%, while interior forest area decreased by up to 9.5%. The Intermountain region had the largest area losses, and the Pacific Southwest had the highest annual loss rates.

TheFix Our Forests Actwould:

Establish new and updated programs to reduce wildfire risks across large, high-priority "firesheds," with an emphasis on cross-boundary collaboration.

Streamline and expand tools for forest health projects(e.g., stewardship contracting, Good Neighbor agreements) and provide faster processes for certain hazardous fuels treatments.

Create a single interagency program to help communities in the wildland-urban interfacebuild and retrofit with wildfire-resistant measures, while simplifying and consolidating grant applications.

Strengthen coordination efforts across agencies through a new Wildfire Intelligence Center, which would streamline federal response and create a whole-of-government approach to combating wildfires.

"A century of fire suppression and decades of reduced forest management have left us with overgrown, unhealthy forests that are more vulnerable to disease and catastrophic wildfire," said Gov. Cox."Thanks to Sen. Curtis's strong leadership on the Fix Our Forests Act, along with the tools provided by President Trump's executive order, we're now equipped to do the critical work our forests need. This bill will help us protect watersheds, enhance wildlife habitat, reduce wildfire risk, and provide the timber we need to build strong homes and neighborhoods."

Some conservation groups weighed in on the proposal as well.

"The declining health of our national forests and the fish and wildlife habitat that they provide is a concern for America's hunters and anglers," said Joel Pedersen, president and chief executive officer of the Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership. "

"TRCP applauds the leadership of Sens. Curtis, Sheehy, Hickenlooper, and Padilla for introducing the bipartisan Fix Our Forests Act in the Senate and urges Congress to advance these important forest management provisions and to accompany them with adequate resources and capacity to carry out on-the-ground work."

The legislation is key given the federally-managed lands involved.

"About half of our lands in California are publicly owned and managed by the federal government," explained California Natural Resources Secretary Wade Crowfoot. "So, reducing catastrophic wildfire risk clearly relies on helping our federal lands become healthier and more resilient to fire."

Supporters include: The Nature Conservancy; National Wildlife Federation; Environmental Defense Fund; National Audubon Society; Citizens' Climate Lobby; Rural Voices for Conservation Coalition; The Stewardship Project; the Federation of American Scientists; CAL FIRE; the International Association of Fire Chiefs; Alliance for Wildfire Resilience; Megafire Action; the Association for Firetech Innovation; Climate & Wildfire Institute; Tall Timbers; Bipartisan Policy Center Action (BPC Action); and Hispanics Enjoying Camping, Hunting, and the Outdoors (HECHO).

2024 DEC 25 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in science. According to news reporting originating from Tambov State Technical University by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The article proposes a classification of fuzzy information about the terrain for solving problems in the fields of agriculture and forestry."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Tambov State Technical University: "This classification allows for a more accurate description and understanding of the characteristics of fuzzy information, which can be useful for decision-making under uncertainty. Special attention is given to the area of forest fire modeling using geographic information systems."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "A hybrid fuzzy network is proposed for classifying the parameters of the fire source and the environment to select the optimal analytical model."

urn:contentItem:6BS6-W331-JBSP-10V6-00000-00Research Reports on Climate Change from National and Kapodistrian University of Athens Provide New Insights (Modelling Future Forest Fire Risk for the Tourism Sector of Crete)2024-04-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEResearch Reports on Climate Change from National and Kapodistrian University of Athens Provide New Insights (Modelling Future Forest Fire Risk for the Tourism Sector of Crete)


2024 APR 10 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- A new study on climate change is now available. According to news originating from Athens, Greece, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Wildfires are one of the strongest drivers of degradation of Mediterranean ecosystems, while weather and climate are among the main factors influencing fire potential."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from National and Kapodistrian University of Athens: "From this perspective, we attempt to assess the future forest fire risk in Crete in the near (2046-2065) and distant future (2081-2100), under the Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) of RCP2.6, RCP4.5, and RCP8.5. A risk assessment model was developed according to the conceptual framework of the 'impact chain', as defined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), aiming at the formulation of a final composite risk index. The multicriteria spatial analysis, which was implemented with GIS techniques, highlighted the areas that are expected to be heavily affected in the future. It was found that the forest fire risk for the tourism sector increases with the higher emissions scenarios and towards the end of the century, with the south and central parts of the island exhibiting 'very high' risk."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The effectiveness of this method is underlined, both in terms of implementing the necessary preventive measures against the adverse effects of climate change and of strengthening adaptation planning."
For more information on this research see: Modelling Future Forest Fire Risk for the Tourism Sector of Crete. Environmental Sciences Proceedings, 2023,26(1):150. The publisher for Environmental Sciences Proceedings is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/environsciproc2023026150.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Magdalini Tzouveleki, Laboratory of Climatology and Atmospheric Environment, Department of Geology and Geoenvironment, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, 15784 Athens, Greece. Additional authors for this research include Maria Hatzaki, Varvara Antoniou, Anna Karali, Christos Giannakopoulos.

urn:contentItem:6DD1-7WD1-DYJT-2115-00000-00Man charged with arson in the 'Shotgun' wildfire near Six Flags Great Adventure2024-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisMAIN NEWSPg. X12Man charged with arson in the 'Shotgun' wildfire near Six Flags Great AdventureMichelle Myers (Staff Writer)

As hundreds of acres continue to burn, a man is in custody and accused of starting the fire near Six Flags Great Adventure, one of several drought-related wildfires in New Jersey.

Richard Shashaty, 37, of Brick Township, is charged with arson and firearms violations after allegedly firing prohibited Dragon's Breath shards linked to what authorities are calling the "Shotgun Fire" in Jackson Township.

On Wednesday, Jackson Township first responders were called to the Central Jersey Rifle Range for a fire that would devour about 350 acres in less than a week, officials said.

"The fire was caused by magnesium shards of a Dragon's Breath 12-gauge shotgun round igniting available combustibles on the berm of the shooting range. The firing of this type of incendiary or tracer ammunition is prohibited in the State of New Jersey," law enforcement and forest fire officials said in a statement.

The fire is presumed to have started in the southwest corner of the rifle range, according to the statement by the Ocean County Prosecutor's Office Major Crime Unit-Arson Squad, New Jersey Forest Fire Service, and the New Jersey State Fire Marshal's Office. It resulted in 15 structures being evacuated and the closure of Stump Tavern Road.

On Saturday, Shashaty turned himself in at the Jackson Township Police Department headquarters, accompanied by his attorney, officials said. He was transferred to the Ocean County Jail, where he awaits a detention hearing.

The Shotgun Fire is just one of multiple wildfires across New Jersey. Heavy smoke from fires in South Jersey, including the Pheasant Run fire in Gloucester County and the Bethany Run Wildfire in Burlington and Camden Counties, prompted Philadelphia's Office of Emergency Management to issue a warning Sunday morning to "use precaution if outdoors and close doors and windows."

In Pennsylvania's Berks County, Sunday marked the third day in a row that firefighters battled the Neversink Mountain fire near Reading. That fire forced some evacuations through Saturday morning and resulted in a non-fire-related injury to a firefighter.

Through these fires, rain has been the missing hero. Close to 88% of the contiguous United States is considered "abnormally dry" by the interagency U.S. Drought Monitor.

Rain in the forecast for Sunday evening would end Philadelphia's record six-week dry run, but don't expect it to last. The dryness is expected to resume soon after.

Staff writer Anthony R. Wood contributed to this article.

2025 FEB 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Current study results on Technology have been published. According to news originating from Anhui, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Acquiring behaviour parameters of wildfire propagation and developing firefighting strategies necessitate a precise and efficient simulation method; fireline coordinates and rate of spread (ROS) are two crucial parameters closely associated with simulation precision.Aims This study proposes an adaptive simulation method for wildfire propagation by integrating continuous time series remote sensing images with a cellular automata (CA) model.Methods The ROS in each direction is calculated using continuous time fireline coordinates derived from multi-source remote sensing images."


Funders for this research include National Key Research & Development Program of China, National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC).
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the University of Science and Technology China, "A time-adaptive propagation algorithm is developed based on the CA model (time-adaptive cellular automata, TCA). Vegetation distribution information is derived to establish a simulation system for verification experiments.Key results The TCA model demonstrated satisfactory simulation performance, with a prediction accuracy of 92.2% for burned area and 87.3% for fireline length within local regions in the MuLi Forest Fire and effectively characterised gradual spread based on low ROS.Conclusion The adaptive simulation method produces fairly precise results and demonstrated its capability to achieve localised and gradual propagation."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This software serves as a powerful tool for wildland surface fire prevention and control.Implications The adaptive simulation method based on continuous time remote sensing images and the CA model are essential for accurately predicting wildfire propagation."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Simulating Wildfire Spread Based On Continuous Time Series Remote Sensing Images and Cellular Automata. International Journal of Wildland Fire, 2025;34(1).
