Results

Distinct impacts of fragmentation on forest resilience

The univariate null model (UNM) and the PCA both show significant correlations (P < 0.05) but of different signs across different biomes between ED and TACkNDVI over the majority (UNM, 81%; PCA, 77%) of fragmented forest grid cells (2° × 2°) (Fig. 1a,b and Supplementary Fig. 1a,b). In tropical (UNM, 91%; PCA, 88%) and temperate (UNM, 87%; PCA, 82%) forests, TACkNDVI is positively correlated with ED (P < 0.05), primarily clustered in the Brazilian Amazon, Central Africa and northern USA (Fig. 1a,b and Supplementary Fig. 1a,b). This indicates that tropical (βTAC = 0.0025 ± 0.0002) and temperate (βTAC = 0.0015 ± 0.0001) forests with stronger fragmentation (larger ED) exhibit weaker resilience (larger TACkNDVI) (Fig. 1c,d and Supplementary Fig. 2d,e). Conversely, in boreal forests TACkNDVI is negatively correlated with ED (βTAC = −0.0008 ± 0.0001) (Fig. 1e and Supplementary Fig. 2f) over most fragmented forests (UNM, 75%; PCA, 72%) (Fig. 1a,b and Supplementary Fig. 1a,b), suggesting a contrasting fragmentation–resilience relationship. This signifies that stronger fragmentation (larger ED) tends to enhance boreal forest resilience (smaller TACkNDVI).

ED and TC are the two most important covariates affecting forest resilience across all climate zones (Fig. 1f,h and Supplementary Fig. 1c–e). Therefore, we further conducted a PLS-SEM analysis, which can effectively address the collinearity issues, to compare their relative importance across the globe (Supplementary Fig. 3). We discovered an asymmetric impact of ED versus TC on forest resilience (Fig. 2). More than 68% of tropical forests show a stronger positive ED–TACkNDVI pathway (path coefficient is 0.38 ± 0.024, P < 0.01) compared with the negative TC–TACkNDVI pathway (path coefficient is −0.21 ± 0.021, P < 0.01) (Fig. 2a). This finding is consistent with the PCAs (Supplementary Fig. 4), where the majority of tropical forests (77%) show a higher sensitivity of TACkNDVI to ED (R = 0.31; P < 0.01) than to TC (R = −0.28; P < 0.01) (Fig. 1f and Supplementary Fig. 4). Overall, tropical forests show a positive asymmetric influence of fragmentation versus TC on forest resilience. However, the asymmetry is reversed in the boreal zone, where >55% of grid cells show a stronger positive TC–TACkNDVI relationship (SEM path coefficient is 0.36 ± 0.030, P < 0.01; R for PCA = 0.17, P < 0.01), compared with a relatively weaker negative ED–TACkNDVI relationship (SEM path coefficient is −0.33 ± 0.028, P < 0.01; R for PCA = −0.14, P < 0.01) (Figs. 1h and 2c and Supplementary Fig. 4). In temperate forests, the positive impacts of ED on TACkNDVI and the negative impacts of TC on TACkNDVI have equal weighting, each accounting for approximately half the total grid cells (Figs. 1g and 2b and Supplementary Fig. 4).

To strictly control the impact of TCs in each bin, we established linear correlations between ED and TACkNDVI for each 10% TC bin (50–60%, 60–70%, 70–80%, 80–90% and >90%) within each 2° × 2° moving window and calculated the slopes (βTAC) of their linear fitting curves (Fig. 3; Methods, ‘Quantify the impacts of fragmentation on forest resilience’). Results show that βTAC is positive for all TC bins in tropical (0.0016 ± 0.00001 on average; Fig. 3a and Supplementary Figs. 6 and 7a–e) and temperate (0.0010 ± 0.00002 on average; Fig. 3b and Supplementary Figs. 6 and 7f–j) forests, but negative in boreal forests (−0.0008 ± 0.00001 on average; Fig. 3c and Supplementary Figs. 6 and 7k–o). Interestingly, βTAC increases with tropical TC, suggesting a stronger negative impact of fragmentation (larger ED) on forest resilience (smaller TACkNDVI) in tropical regions with higher TC compared to lower TC. In temperate forests, βTAC exhibits similar magnitudes for all TC bins. Conversely, in boreal forests, βTAC decreases sharply in areas with nearly full TC (>90%), indicating a stronger positive impact of fragmentation (larger ED) on forest resilience (smaller TACkNDVI) as TC increases. This finding, based on the TC binning analysis, is consistent when upscaling to the climate zoning scales (Supplementary Fig. 8).

Potential mechanisms of fragmentation effects on forest resilience

Fragmentation is expected either to release competition for light and water, and thereby promote forest resilience35, 36, 37–38, or to accelerate exposure to external environmental stress and thus reduce forest resilience31, 32, 33–34. To test these two contrasting assumptions, we applied the PLS-SEM analysis to explore the potential mechanisms through what kind of changes in environmental conditions fragmentation may affect TAC (Methods, ‘Explore the potential mechanisms’). This was achieved by using moving windows for each bin of TC to limit the effects of TC. We found that, within each 10% bin of TC, fragmentation strongly regulates the local land surface temperature (LST), soil moisture (SM), atmospheric dryness (vapour pressure deficit, VPD) and absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (APAR) (Fig. 4), which in turn enhance or diminish forest resilience to macroclimate fluctuations. However, the pathways through which fragmentation affects forest resilience differ greatly across biomes.

In tropical and temperate biomes, forests cool local temperature (Fig. 4a) and increase atmosphere and soil moisture (Fig. 4b,c), alleviating potential constraints from high-temperature stress and drought57, 58–59. This can benefit forest productivity in sunlight-sufficient environments60, 61–62. However, fragmentation significantly (P < 0.001) weakens such cooling (ED positively correlated with ∆LST) and humidification effects (ED positively correlated with ∆VPD) (Fig. 4e), which in turn raises local forest temperature and atmospheric dryness. This fragmentation-induced warming and drying of local environments tends therefore to decrease forest resilience (larger TACkNDVI) (Fig. 5a,b). This impact emerges as the most important direct-influencing pathway in most tropical forests (total path coefficient of these two pathways is 0.39 ± 0.0002; 51.35% of tropical forest pixels) and temperate forests (total path coefficient of these two pathways is 0.13 ± 0.0002; 52.14% of temperate forest pixels) (Fig. 5d,e). Fragmentation-induced warming may further exacerbate atmospheric dryness due to the strong influences of LST on air temperature and, consequently, on VPD (Fig. 5a,b). The total path coefficient is 0.77 ± 0.004 for tropical biomes and 0.75 ± 0.006 for temperate biomes, leading to cascading negative effects on resilience (larger TACkNDVI). This is an important indirect pathway through which fragmentation affects forest resilience (total path coefficient is 0.24 ± 0.0001), particularly affecting 33.65% of tropical forest grid cells.

Conversely, boreal forests are often associated with a slight warming effect on local temperatures (Fig. 4a). Reduction in such biophysical warming due to fragmentation (Fig. 4e) consequently decreases boreal forest resilience (total path coefficient is 0.05 ± 0.0004) (Fig. 5c), where productivity is often limited by low temperature63,64. However, this negative impact is offset by other direct influences on resilience through changes in SM, VPD and APAR. Our analysis indicates that the negative ED–TACkNDVI relationship is largely attributed to the influencing pathways through increases in SM (total path coefficient is −0.03 ± 0.0001) and decreases in VPD (total path coefficient is −0.10 ± 0.0002) (Fig. 5c–e). Fragmentation-induced cooling on local temperatures also decelerates atmospheric and soil dryness (Fig. 5c), further promoting plant transpiration and photosynthesis65, both of which enhance forest resilience (smaller TAC). Furthermore, fragmentation in boreal forests produces a positive ED–∆APAR pathway (path coefficient is 0.22 ± 0.005; P < 0.05) (Fig. 5c). This is particularly important for enhancing forest resilience (total path coefficient is −0.02 ± 0.0002, P < 0.05) in the sunlight-insufficient boreal regions66 (Fig. 5c,e), providing another explanation for the negative ED–TACkNDVI relationship.

Variations across biomes, climates and fragmentation drivers

The fragmentation–resilience relationship varies across forest types (green histograms, Fig. 6). Fragmentation can alter the humidity and temperature conditions in evergreen broadleaf forests and deciduous broadleaf forests in tropical and temperate zones (Supplementary Fig. 15b–e). This alteration leads to the most negative impact of fragmentation on their ecosystem resilience (green histograms, Fig. 6). The fragmentation–resilience relationship also differs in degree of climatic aridity (brown histograms, Fig. 6). In drier climates, fragmentation induces more pronounced changes in environmental climates32 (Supplementary Fig. 16). Therefore, the strength of the fragmentation–resilience relationship is enhanced with aridity (brown histograms, Fig. 6). Forest resilience also responds differently to fragmentation in flood-prone regions (Supplementary Fig. 17), where water is not a limiting factor and local temperatures are typically lower than the surroundings due to strong evapotranspiration. Our analysis shows that, in flood-prone forests, fragmentation probably causes fewer disturbances to the local environment of forests, leading to a weaker fragmentation–resilience relationship (purple histograms, Fig. 6).

Fragmentation associated with different drivers of coincident TC loss8 may have various impacts on forest resilience. We find that fragmentation induced by anthropogenic disturbances, such as commodity-driven permanent deforestation, agriculture and urbanization (except for selective forestry operations within forests), generally result in more substantial changes in local temperature and humidity (Supplementary Fig. 18) and thus produce stronger impacts on forest resilience compared with natural disturbances (for example, wildfire) (red histograms, Fig. 6). Impacts from broader landscape-level environments were also examined in three representative regions in tropical, temperate and boreal forests, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 19a; Methods, ‘Select global forest grid cells’). Our analyses reveal that forests adjacent to built-up lands or croplands generally experience a hotter and drier background environment compared with forests adjacent to natural surface grasslands. This pattern is consistent in both tropical and temperate regions (Supplementary Fig. 19b,c), resulting in a more pronounced decline in resilience (blue histograms, Fig. 6). In addition, changes in the surrounding climate relative to neighbouring disturbances may also influence the fragmentation–resilience relationships. Our findings indicate that fragmentation in areas with neighbouring disturbances (agriculture, urbanization and wildfire) exacerbate climatic variability (Supplementary Fig. 20), leading to a more significant decline in resilience (orange histograms, Fig. 6). Conversely, afforestation or reforestation efforts in the surrounding areas help mitigate climate change impacts (Supplementary Fig. 20), resulting in a weaker effect of fragmentation on resilience (orange histograms, Fig. 6).

Testing potential uncertainties

Uncertainties may arise from satellite-based optical vegetation indices, which often saturate in dense forest18. For instance, LAI, NDVI, kNDVI and enhanced vegetation index (EVI) all perform well in low-density forests, but saturate when the aboveground biomass exceeds 250 Mg ha−1 (Supplementary Fig. 21a–c). In regions with fewer saturation issues (Supplementary Fig. 21d), satellite-based optical vegetation indices converge to show positive correlations between ED and TAC in tropical and temperate zones (Supplementary Fig. 21e–g); while consistently representing negative correlations between ED and TAC in boreal zones (Supplementary Fig. 21e,h). However, in dense forests where optical vegetation indices saturate strongly, such as the central Amazon, southern Europe and western Canada, the fragmentation–resilience relationships cannot be reliably estimated using the correlation between ED and optical vegetation indices-inferred TAC metrics (Supplementary Fig. 21i–k). This uncertainty can be illustrated by comparing the results from independent Ku-band microwave vegetation optical depth (VOD)67 which are less prone to saturation in dense vegetation. We detected a pronounced positive correlation between ED and TACVOD in dense forests of the central Amazon, southern Europe and western Canada (Supplementary Fig. 22). Thus, in low-density forests the choice of vegetation indices does not significantly impact the fragmentation–resilience relationships. However, in dense forests where optical vegetation indices are susceptible to signal saturation, using non-optical remote sensing vegetation indices, such as VOD, can provide more reliable results. Canopy structure and vertical leaf angle issues49 may also compromise the reliability of optical vegetation indices. To address this, we selected the CVI50, which is less affected by either structure or leaf angle, to test the robustness of our evaluations. While the CVI-based fragmentation–resilience relationships become slightly less pronounced, the divergent patterns between tropical/temperate forests (positive) versus boreal forests (negative) still hold true (Supplementary Fig. 23; slope is 1.13, R2 = 0.95, P < 0.001). Furthermore, The aforementioned fragmentation–resilience relationships also remain robust when using other TC data (that is, GFCC) to calculate ED (Supplementary Fig. 24; slope is 0.71, R2 = 0.63, P < 0.001), or using other alternative fragmentation metrics (patch density and mean patch area) instead of ED (Supplementary Fig. 25; patch density: slope is 0.84, R2 = 0.91, P < 0.001; mean patch area: slope is 0.82, R2 = 0.90, P < 0.001), or examining alternative time periods (2000–2015 and 2006–2020) (Supplementary Fig. 26). To be cautious, the robustness of satellite vegetation indices-based fragmentation–resilience patterns were also examined using TAC calculated from the field measurements of data for eddy covariance gross primary production (GPP) from the FLUXNET2025 dataset, which showed a strong consistency with the TAC calculated on the basis of kNDVI (Supplementary Fig. 27; slope is 0.91, R2 = 0.73, P < 0.001). In the last, the pervasive but divergent fragmentation–resilience relationships across global forests remain robust even when downscaling to smaller sizes of forest grid cells (1 km instead of 0.05° resolution) (Supplementary Fig. 28).

Another fundamental issue to be examined is the validity of using TAC as the theoretical indicator of forest resilience. Thus, justification from empirical estimations is important because it gives a directly measurable resilience metric for those locations where disturbances occurred56. To do this, we used the empirical direct recovery rate (DRT) to test the robustness of TAC-based fragmentation–resilience relationships. DRT is a valid direct resilience metric, which is obtained by fitting an exponential recovery model to vegetation time series after experiencing abrupt disturbances56 (Methods, ‘Estimate global forest resilience’). We found similar DRT-estimated fragmentation–resilience relationships to that of TAC-based relationships (Supplementary Fig. 29; slope is 0.68, R2 = 0.55, P < 0.001). Additionally, the divergent TAC-based fragmentation–resilience relationships across biomes also coincided with those obtained by using the time-series variance instead of TAC68,69 (Supplementary Fig. 30). It is worth noting that kNDVI variance-based fragmentation–resilience (Supplementary Fig. 30c–e) can efficiently capture the microwave VOD-inferred fragmentation–resilience pattern in densely forested areas such as the central Amazon (slope is 0.93, R2 = 0.91, P < 0.001), southern Europe (slope is 0.93, R2 = 0.93, P < 0.001) and western Canada (slope is 0.82, R2 = 0.75, P < 0.001). This suggests that the variance metric probably outweighs the TAC metric in representing the fragmentation–resilience relationships in the densely forested ecosystems.

Environmental variability may differ across moving windows, introducing uncertainty in fragmentation–resilience relationships. To address this, we selected four key environmental factors (shortwave radiation, temperature, precipitation and elevation) and quantified the environmental variability within each 2° × 2° moving window using their interquartile ranges (IQR) (Methods, ‘Select global forest grid cells’; (Supplementary Fig. 31). Our analysis revealed that R values for the correlation between ED and TAC decreased as IQR increased (Supplementary Fig. 32), indicating a significant negative impact of environmental variability on the fragmentation–resilience relationships across different windows. Notably, windows in the small IQR cohorts (the lowest 25% IQR range), which were less influenced by environmental variability, showed a regionally averaged R value of 0.74, 0.69 and −0.47 for tropical, temperate and boreal zones, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 33c–e). This indicates a robust relationship between ED and TAC across global forests. Furthermore, R values between ED and TACkNDVI exceeded 0.60 across most TC bins (Supplementary Figs. 34 and 35); and more than 94% of those windows showed significant correlation (P < 0.001) (Supplementary Fig. 33f–h), consistent with randomization-based analyses (Supplementary Fig. 33i–k). To further evaluate the impact of environmental variability associated with the 2° × 2° moving window method, we compared it with a fixed 2° × 2° window method (Supplementary Fig. 36) and also tested against a larger moving window (4° × 4°) (Supplementary Fig. 37). Results showed that the majority (>96%) of 2° × 2° moving windows in small IQR cohorts exhibited significant correlations (P < 0.001) between ED and TAC for both the fixed 2° × 2° window method (tropical, R = 0.71 ± 0.0071; temperate, R = 0.69 ± 0.0103; boreal, R = −0.48 ± 0.0110) and the 4° × 4° moving window method (tropical, R = 0.72 ± 0.0010; temperate, R = 0.71 ± 0.0011; boreal, R = −0.50 ± 0.0014). Additionally, Student’s t-test revealed no statistically significant differences in the R and P values between the 2° × 2° moving window method and both the fixed 2° × 2° and 4° × 4° window methods (Supplementary Figs. 36c–i and 37c–i).

Discussion

One key finding of this study is the demonstration of a pervasive fragmentation–resilience relationship existing in about 77% of global fragmented forests, with 55% showing significant (P < 0.05) positive correlations and 22% exhibiting significant (P < 0.05) negative correlations (Fig. 1). Typically, the fragmentation–resilience relation is mostly equal to or even stronger than that between resilience and TC (Fig. 2). This finding highlights the fact that forests, even with the same TC, exhibit resilience differences with various degrees of fragmentation70,71. Nevertheless, the impacts of fragmentation on resilience, which is now a widespread risk to global forests, has been largely overlooked in previous studies20, 21, 22–23. Therefore, accounting for the spatial and temporal variations in forest fragmentation is crucial for predicting the extent of forest resilience shifts under climate change and understanding their consequences for ecosystem functioning.

Equally important, the discovered pervasive but divergent fragmentation–resilience relationships reconcile the long-standing debates from an environmental stress perspective versus a species competition perspective. The sunlight-sufficient and heat-intensive tropical and temperate biomes are generally biodiversity hotspots72 harbouring many endemic species that are highly sensitive to climate variations (droughts and/or heatwaves)73. Thus, plants in these biomes mostly exhibit limited tolerances to environmental stress74 and are more likely to be constrained by frequent high temperature and drought stress31, 32–33 rather than by sunlight66,75. As such, fragmentation-induced warmer and drier environments not only intensify constraints on ecosystem functioning, thus reducing forest resilience, but also worsen the local forest environment, which is used to provide thermal refuges for biological communities75, 76–77. This may increase the extinction risks for endemic species, leading to biodiversity loss and, in turn, lower resilience78, 79–80. Conversely, in the cold and sunlight-insufficient boreal zones, forests usually show a positive fragmentation–resilience relationship. In these biomes, forests are more susceptible to sunlight and water limitations and low-temperature constraint66,81, 82–83. Although fragmentation-induced cooling slightly constrains forest resilience84,85, fragmentation indirectly decelerates atmospheric and soil moisture dryness and increases available light for plant growth, especially for the understory vegetations86,87. This releases species competition for water and light and thus increases the fraction of APAR88, ultimately benefiting forest resilience.

Our findings have potential implications for forest management and policies. Given the negative fragmentation–resilience relationship, it is crucial to preserve tropical and temperate forests in an intact state to minimize fragmented areas. In these biomes, fragmented areas have been primarily caused by anthropogenic disturbances (for example, commodity-driven deforestation, urbanization and agriculture) (Supplementary Fig. 18a,c) and mostly replaced by impervious surfaces89 and croplands8 (Supplementary Fig. 38). This anthropogenic-induced fragmentation worsens the cool and humid forest environment59,90,91, resulting in notable degradation in forest structure92,93 and productivity60, 61–62 and ultimately a stronger reduction in forest resilience, compared with the natural disturbances (Fig. 6). In contrast, the fragmentation–resilience relationship differs in boreal forests, where natural disturbances (for example, fire) and moderate anthropogenic disturbances (selective forestry operation within forests) are the main cause of fragmentation (Supplementary Fig. 18e)8,83. Fragmented areas resulting from natural disturbances are mostly recovered by grasses or mosses (Supplementary Fig. 38), which often display allelopathic interactions with tree species in native forests94. The impacts of fragmentation on forest resilience tend to be enhanced with rising climatic dryness (Fig. 6). Neighbouring disturbances also have broader landscape-level impacts on the resilience of forest ecosystems (Supplementary Figs. 19 and 20). This overflow impact of disturbance on forest ecosystems suggests the necessity of setting buffer areas to protect the conserved areas. It is also worth noting that uncertainties (for example, signal saturation issues) may compromise the use of the optical vegetation indices-based TAC metric in evaluating the fragmentation–resilience relation in densely vegetated regions such as the tropical Amazonian rainforests. In contrast, the variance-based metric or microwave VOD can outperform the optical vegetation indices and give a better performance. While the global fragmentation–resilience relationships found in this study are overall robust, uncertainties remain to be further examined in some specific regions with regard to the complexity of forest communities, limitations of satellite-based vegetation indices, the validity of TAC estimates and mixed pixel issues across local to global scales.

In summary, our study indicates a pervasive fragmentation (ED)–resilience (TACkNDVI) relationship in global forests. We further discover that the ED–TACkNDVI relationships differ substantially across forest biomes. Specifically, it is positive in tropical/temperate forests and negative in boreal forests. The contrasting ED–TACkNDVI relationships are largely attributed to fragmentation-induced changes in the local environment, which is important for persisting ecosystem services and resilience. Overall, our findings underscore the importance of considering fragmentation, rather than relying solely on changes in TC, when assessing forest resilience. These findings also reconcile the divergent fragmentation–resilience arguments hypothesized by the environmental stress perspective versus the species competition perspective, with broad implications for biome-targeted forest management strategies and practices to improve forest resilience under the pressure of climate change and in the face of anthropogenic disturbances.

Methods

Select global forest grid cells

We first overlaid the 30-m high-resolution global TC change maps from GFW40 with 0.05°-resolution MODIS MCD12C1 land cover images39 and selected the grid cells defined as ‘forestlands’ in the MODIS land cover images. We then calculated the TC for each 0.05° forest grid cell and selected for analysis those forest grid cells with TC consistently >50% (in total of 792,140 grid cells) from 2000 to 2020. For a given forest ecosystem, its resilience variation can be influenced by landscape fragmentation and TC change. To minimize the impacts of TC change, we excluded those 0.05° forest grid cells that experienced >2% loss or >2% gain in TC from 2000 to 202090 and focused solely on those relatively stable areas (<2% of TC loss and <2% of TC gain). This selection was conducted using 30-m resolution TC change maps from GFW, which were updated to 2020 by ref. 40.

Furthermore, we investigated the fragmentation–resilience relationships across three climate zones (tropical, temperate and boreal regions) based on the Köppen–Geiger climate classification map95 and various forest types (evergreen needleleaf, evergreen broadleaf, deciduous needleleaf, deciduous broadleaf and mixed forests) according to the International Geosphere–Biosphere Programme (IGBP) classification criteria based on MODIS MCD12C1 land cover images39 (Supplementary Fig. 15a). The fragmentation–resilience relationships were also tested for various climatic aridity conditions on the basis of the aridity index (ratio of precipitation (P) to potential evapotranspiration (PET), denoted as P/PET) (that is, hyper arid (P/PET ≤ 0.03), arid (0.03 < P/PET ≤ 0.2), semi-arid (0.2 < P/PET ≤ 0.5), dry sub-humid (0.5 < P/PET ≤ 0.65) and humid (P/PET > 0.65)), adapted from WorldCLIM96 (Supplementary Fig. 16a). The fragmentation–resilience relationships were further examined between flood-prone and non-flood-prone regions using the flood extent mapping algorithm provided by ref. 97 (Supplementary Fig. 17a).

Notably, fragmentation induced by different drivers may exhibit various impacts on resilience. To examine this, we classified fragmentation drivers using a 0.1°-resolution global tree loss driver map over the period from 2000 to 2015 developed by ref. 8, who identified five main drivers of TC loss: commodity-driven deforestation (the permanent conversion of forestland to non-forest land), large-scale forestry operations, shifting agriculture (the conversion of forest to agricultural land), wildfires (the burning of forest vegetation) and urbanization (the conversion of forest to urban areas). We then re-analysed the fragmentation–resilience relationships for different fragmentation drivers during 2000–2015 (Supplementary Fig. 18a).

We also evaluated potential impacts from neighbouring land uses based on the MCD12C1 land cover images39. The targeted forest grid cells were classified into six categories based on the predominant land-use types of their surrounding grid cells (4° × 4° windows): shrublands, grasslands, wetlands, forests, croplands and buildings, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 19a). We further tested potential influences from neighbouring disturbances based on the TC loss driver map of ref. 8. Similarly, the targeted forest grid cells were categorized into six groups on the basis of the predominant disturbance type in their surrounding grid cells (4° × 4° windows): commodity-driven deforestation, large-scale forestry operations, shifting agriculture, wildfires, urbanization and afforestation/reforestation (Supplementary Fig. 20a).

Additionally, environmental variability may differ across different 2° × 2° moving windows, introducing potential uncertainties (Supplementary Fig. 31). To address this, we quantified environmental variability for each 2° × 2° moving window by considering four key environmental factors: shortwave radiation, temperature, precipitation and elevation. First, we normalized each environmental variable within each climate zone and computed the IQR for each 2° × 2° moving window. Then, we calculated the maximal IQR of the four environmental variables for each 2° × 2° window to represent its overall environmental variability. On the basis of this metric, we classified all 2° × 2° windows into four groups on the basis of the maximal IQR of each window: large IQR cohort (top 25%), relatively large IQR cohort (25–50%), relatively small IQR cohort (50–75%) and small IQR cohort (bottom 25%) (Supplementary Fig. 32). Finally, we selected moving windows belonging to the small IQR cohort, which were less influenced by environmental variability, to assess the robustness of our findings.

Quantify global forest fragmentation

ED, defined as the edge length per unit area41 (equation (1)), is an effective metric for assessing fragmentation70,98. Generally, large values of ED indicate strong fragmentation. Here, we computed global ED data based on 30-m resolution tree cover maps from GFW40 for each designated 0.05° grid cell using the PyLandStats package in Python.1where i is the index of forest grid cells; ei is the total edge length in the studied 0.05° forest grid cell i; and Ai is the total forest area of cell i.

In this study, we used the ED derived from GFW TC data as the key indicator to conduct forest fragmentation analysis. We also tested the robustness of ED in representing the forest fragmentation by comparing with two other fragmentation indicators derived from GFW TC data (Supplementary Fig. 25): patch density and mean patch area. Patch density was calculated as the number of patches per unit forest area42 (equation (2)), while mean patch area was calculated as the mean patch size per unit forest area43 (equation (3)). Overall, we selected 249,481 fragmented forest grid cells (32% of global forests) at a resolution of 0.05° for analysis. The fragmentation metrics (edge length, forest area, ED, patch density and mean patch area) for each grid cell, as well as the number of fragmented 0.05° forest grid cells used for each 2° × 2° moving window, are shown in Supplementary Fig. 39.23where PD and MPA indicate the patch density and mean patch area, respectively; j is the index of forest patches in grid cell i; ni is total number of forest patches in the 0.05° forest grid cell i; and Aj is the area of forest patch j in cell i.

We also computed a global ED dataset based on the 30-m resolution tree cover maps from the GFCC tree cover images44 to test the robustness of the fragmentation metrics derived from GFW TC data (Supplementary Fig. 24).

Estimate global forest resilience

In this study, resilience is defined as the capacity of ecosystems to withstand disturbances and avoid state shifts, rather than as recovery to the initial state after a major event induces a state change12,99, 100–101. Theoretically, the resilience of a system is closely tied to both the variance and TAC of time series encoding the dynamics of the system55. Thus, we mainly used TAC and variance as the theoretical metrics to estimate forest resilience. Satellite-based vegetation indices have been used to calculate TAC and variance for quantifying ecosystem resilience11, 12–13,15,18,56,69,102. In this study, we adopted the widely used kNDVI time-series data (2000–2020)45 (equation (4)) as the primary vegetation index to calculate one-lag TAC (TACkNDVI) for forest resilience analysis. We retained only NDVI pixels with good quality and used a rolling-mean detrender followed by removing a third-order harmonic function fit to the data as a deseasoner in Python56, to produce kNDVI time series devoid of long-term trends and seasonal patterns for each pixel for further analysis11,13. We further tested the result estimated using the above detrending and deseasoning method, which is consistent with that of the seasonal-trend decomposition procedure based on the locally weighted regression (LOESS) method (STL)103.4

Additionally, we explored four other commonly used vegetation indices—MODIS-NDVI46, MODIS-EVI46, MODIS-LAI47 and a reconstructed SIF product by combining the OCO-2 SIF and MODIS vegetation index data (GOSIF)48—to calculate TACkNDVI, TACEVI, TACLAI and TACSIF, respectively, to test the robustness of relationship between ED and TACkNDVI (Supplementary Fig. 23k–r). To test the potential influences of canopy structure and vertical leaf angle on optical vegetation indices-based estimations, we explored five other vegetation indices, that is, CVI (TACCVI)50,104, DSWI2 (TACDSWI2)51,104, NDDI (TACNDDI)52,104, NDWI (TACNDWI)53,104 and NRFIg (TACNRFIg)54,104, which were found to be less sensitive to variations in structure and vertical leaf angle (Supplementary Fig. 23a–j). To evaluate impacts from the saturation issues of optical vegetation indices in dense vegetation13, we also used Ku-band microwave VOD derived from AMSR-E67 to calculate TACVOD (Supplementary Fig. 22). The satellite vegetation indices-inferred fragmentation–resilience relationships were also examined by using global eddy covariance GPP data from the FLUXNET2025 dataset to calculate TACflux_GPP, (Supplementary Fig. 27). All the optical vegetation indices were computed monthly and resampled to a 0.05° spatial resolution to match the spatial resolution of kNDVI.

A previous study13 introduced an empirical metric—recovery rate—to directly measure ecosystem resilience. The empirical recovery rate was obtained by fitting an exponential recovery model to vegetation time series after experiencing abrupt disturbances56. Thus, we also calculated the empirical recovery rate following the method of ref. 56 to justify the use of TAC and variance as proxies for vegetation resilience. The specific calculation process was summarized as follows. (1) First, for each of the target forest cells, we identified sharp transitions in the time-series vegetation indices where slopes were above the 99th percentile using an 18-point (9 month) moving window and defined their peaks as individual disturbances. (2) Then, we identified the local minimum vegetation index after the individual disturbance, and used the five following years of data after identifying the minimum vegetation index to fit an exponential function to the residual time series, assuming that the recovery after a disturbance to a vegetation state x0 approximately follows equation (5):5where x(t) denotes the state of vegetation at time t following the disturbance. Parameter γ represents the empirical recovery rates. A negative γ indicates that the vegetation system will return to its original stable state at a rate of γ. Conversely, a positive γ suggests that the initial disturbance will be amplified, indicating a non-resilient state of vegetation. It is important to note that the relationship between TAC and the recovery rate γ is exponential, while the relationship between variance and the recovery rate γ follows a power law (1/r).

Quantify the impacts of fragmentation on forest resilience

Given the significant correlation between fragmentation and TC105,106, we used the PCA107, data binning approach and PLS-SEM108 to isolate the impacts of tree cover. This allowed us to better understand the individual influence of fragmentation (ED) on forest resilience (TACkNDVI).

The partial correlation analysis

Partial correlation is a robust method for describing the relationship between two variables while removing the effects of another variable, or several other variables, on this relationship109, 110–111. Thus, we constrained the PCA between ED and TAC (Fig. 1), after removing the effect of TC, temperature, precipitation, shortwave radiation, elevation, longitude and latitude, within 2° × 2° moving windows. Only those 2° × 2° moving windows with >50 records were retained for analysis (249,481 in total).

The PLS-SEM analysis

PLS-SEM is a robust statistical technique designed to analyse complex cause–effect relationships in path models112, 113, 114, 115, 116–117 that include latent variables. In our study, we used a straightforward PLS-SEM model that included two mediating variables, TC and ED, to analyse their effects on resilience (TACkNDVI). The PLS-SEM results for tropical, temperate and boreal forests are shown in Fig. 2. We compared the path coefficients between ED and TACkNDVI with those between TC and TACkNDVI to represent the varying impacts of fragmentation on resilience across global forests. We used the goodness-of-fit (GoF) as an effective indicator to assess the overall predictive performance of PLS-SEM. GoF values >0.7 are considered ‘very good’, while those >0.5 are considered ‘good’65,118.

The data binning analysis

Data binning is a data preprocessing method used to group original continuous data into several categories119. Since data within the same group share similar classification characteristics, the data binning approach can minimize the impact of classification features, allowing to assess the correlation of other variables within the bins. In this study, within each moving window, we established linear correlations between ED and TACkNDVI for each TC bin (50–60%, 60–70%, 70–80%, 80–90% and >90%) and calculated the R values and slopes of the corresponding linear correlation fitting curves (Supplementary Figs. 6 and 7). We then computed the average slopes within each 2° × 2° moving window for each TC bin across different climate zones, as shown in Fig. 3.

Explore the potential mechanisms

To explore the pathways through which fragmentation impacts on resilience, we first quantified the biophysical effects of forest on LST, VPD, SM and APAR, denoted as ∆LST, ∆VPD, ∆SM and ∆APAR, respectively (see later): ∆LST was calculated using the MODIS MOD11C3 v.061 land surface temperature products120; ∆VPD and ∆SM were derived from the TerraClimate dataset96. ∆APAR was calculated on the basis of photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) and fraction of absorbed PAR (FAPAR) data from the global land surface satellite (GLASS) product121,122.

Then, we assumed that the adjacent forest and non-forest areas share the same background state and adopted the space-for-time analogy57 to estimate intrinsic biophysical effects of forests on local environment—∆LST, ∆VPD, ∆SM and ∆APAR123. Specifically, for each 0.05° forest grid cell, the impact of forests on local temperature can be expressed as the LST difference (∆LST) between forest and open land (equation (6)). The ∆VPD, ∆SM and ∆APAR induced by the biophysical effects of forests were calculated similarly to ∆LST. All these changes in climatic variables (∆LST, ∆VPD, ∆SM and ∆APAR) were computed annually and resampled to 0.05° spatial resolution to match the spatial resolution of kNDVI. The analysis results are shown in Fig. 4.6where LSTnon-forest was obtained from neighbouring non-forest areas located within a 50-km radius90,124, as grid cells within this distance were assumed to share a similar background climate123. To minimize distance-related uncertainties, LSTnon-forest within 50 km of the targeted forest grid cells were averaged using the inverse distance as a weighting factor124. Additionally, only forest grid cells with more than five reference grid cells within 50 km were included in the analysis90.

After that, we developed a PLS-SEM framework incorporating four mediating variables (∆LST, ∆VPD, ∆SM and ∆APAR) to represent the pathways through which fragmentation largely impacts on resilience. We ran the PLS-SEM using 1,000 bootstrapping samples to validate the estimates of path coefficients and their coefficients of determination (R2). Only grid cells with GoF > 0.5 were included in the analyses65,125. Results were shown in Fig. 5.

Develop null models to test the result robustness

The UNM approach

The null model approach is a fundamental tool that serves as a baseline or reference point for evaluating the significance of observed data in complex systems126,127. In this study, we developed a UNM between ED and TACkNDVI (Supplementary Fig. 1a), which revealed a consistent global pattern similar to the one observed in PCA (Fig. 1a; Methods, ‘The partial correlation analysis’). Additionally, we developed the UNMs, using TC, temperature, precipitation, shortwave radiation, elevation, longitude and latitude as the predictor variables, respectively, with TACkNDVI as the response variable. These UNMs revealed that fragmentation and TC were the two most influential factors affecting forest resilience (Supplementary Fig. 1c–e). The relative importance of these factors was consistent with the results derived from the PCA (Fig. 1f–h; Methods, ‘The partial correlation analysis’).

The binary linear regression and multiple regression approaches

We further developed the binary linear regression null model (BNM) and multiple linear regression model (MLR), to test the robustness of PLS-SEM. The root mean square error (RMSE), Bayesian information criterion (BIC) and Akaike information criterion (AIC) are effective indicators for evaluating model accuracy128, 129–130. If the RMSE, BIC and AIC of complex models are lower than those of the BNM or MLR, it indicates that the complex models have a higher predictive power than the null models131,132.

First, we established a BNM with ED and TC as the two predictor variables and TAC as the response variable, which was used as a baseline to test the robustness of the PLS-SEM model in depicting the relative importance of ED versus TC in influencing TAC (Fig. 2). Here, we also used the partial correlation approach based on BNM analysis to quantify the relative importance of ED versus TC in influencing TAC (Methods, ‘The partial correlation analysis’). Overall, the results from the BNM showed consistent patterns regarding the relative importance of ED versus TC in influencing TAC (Supplementary Fig. 4). The simulation accuracy of PLS-SEM (RMSE = 0.09; AIC = −2,547; BIC = −2,536) was higher than that of the BNM (RMSE = 0.10; AIC = −2,423; BIC = −2,415) (Supplementary Fig. 5). This indicates that PLS-SEM provided a more reliable approach for depicting the relative importance of ED versus TC in influencing TAC.

Similarly, we established an MLR analysis to test the robustness of PLS-SEM (Fig. 5). In this model, ED, ∆LST, ∆VPD, ∆SM and ∆APAR were used as predictor variables and TACkNDVI was set as the response variable. Our analysis revealed that the RMSE values produced by PLS-SEM were consistently lower than those of the MLR (Supplementary Table 1). We also compared our PLS-SEM model (Fig. 5) with alternative models that excluded one of the climatic variables (∆LST, ∆VPD, ∆SM or ∆APAR). The simulation accuracy of our original PLS-SEM was consistently higher than that of these alternative models (Supplementary Table 2). To ensure robustness, we also conducted PLS-SEM and MLR analyses exclusively using windows belong to the small IQR cohorts, which were less affected by environmental variability (Supplementary Table 2).

urn:contentItem:6F4Y-WXB3-RW2Y-R449-00000-00Researchers from Department of Chemistry Publish Research in Remote Sensing [Wildfire indicators modeling for reserved forest of Vellore district (Tamil Nadu, India)]2025-02-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisPHYSICS - REMOTE SENSINGResearchers from Department of Chemistry Publish Research in Remote Sensing [Wildfire indicators modeling for reserved forest of Vellore district (Tamil Nadu, India)]


2025 FEB 17 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Current study results on remote sensing have been published. According to news originating from the Department of Chemistry by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires significantly impact ecosystems; thus, identifying characteristics that increase the danger of fires is critical to mitigating their negative impacts. This study examines the parameters contributing to wildfires in the Vellore Reserve Forest This paper aims to develop GIS-based risk maps and models to enhance fire protection, fuel mitigation strategies, and land use decisions by improving wildfire risk recognition and prediction. This research discusses Wildfire Modeling in Vellore Reserve Forest, Tamil Nadu, India."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Department of Chemistry: "This field is large and rich in knowledge on the study of wildfires in the study area. Tamil Nadu, India's southernmost state, is divided into 32 districts with diverse landscapes and ecosystems. The Vellore district, covering 6,077 square kilometers, has a significant 27% forest cover, covering 162,286 ha. This forest is primarily found between latitudinal and longitudinal coordinates in the calm taluks of Gudiyatham, Tirupattur, and Vellore-the Vellore Reserve Forest Report 2023 highlights this ecological diversity. Geographic information systems (GIS) based analysis of forest fire was done using normalized difference vegetation index, normalized difference moisture index, fuel danger index (human) activity danger index, weather danger index, topographic danger index, normalized burn ratio index, and differenced Normalized Burn Ratio. The geographical scope of this research encompasses the entire Vellore district of Tamil Nadu, India. Real-time maps were photographed by MODIS and Landsat nine satellites to obtain a normalized difference in vegetation and moisture index. Initially, data are converted to digital maps. The most helpful fuel, activity, weather, and topography danger indexes are calculated using the Raster Calculator utility, Euclidean Distance tool, Kriging tool, and Digital Elevation Model, respectively. In the Vellore district, the calculated activity danger index ranges from 0 to 12,000, showing that the high risk emanates from human activities. The climate is dry from May to July, and the weather danger index is 345-348. In other seasons, the weather index is 338-341, indicating a low-risk level. In Vellore, low to medium-risk values for the topography index are 56.5-933, and high-risk values are 934-1,690. Fire severity is indexed in terms of both NBR and dNBR. NBR and dNBR are calculated from the NIR-SWIR ratio. Despite the limited data sources being a big challenge in this paper, the innovative elements of this study are characterized by a comprehensive, integrated strategy that employs GIS technology, providing an understanding of localized factors influencing wildfire ignition."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This research contributes significant data and insights regarding the metrics that govern wildfire dynamics, serving as a vital resource for wildfire management efforts in the region. This paper assists in applying the models to predict the future wildfire risk under climate change and land use conditions."
For more information on this research see: Wildfire indicators modeling for reserved forest of Vellore district (Tamil Nadu, India). Frontiers in Remote Sensing, 2025,6. The publisher for Frontiers in Remote Sensing is Frontiers Media S.A.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3389/frsen.2025.1518539.

urn:contentItem:6DD7-7701-DYJT-21PD-00000-00New Jersey wildfires now under control2024-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisREGIONPg. B1New Jersey wildfires now under controlFrank Kummer (Staff Writer)

Thousands of New Jersey firefighters have had a rough few weeks, fighting multiple simultaneous wildfires across the state that left one dead.

Sunday night's rain, however, helped dampen flames and smoke from the three fires that had been burning in South Jersey. Though the New Jersey Forest Fire Service was the primary firefighting agency, it has brought in fire companies from throughout the region to help with wildfires that started burning in October, which marked the driest month in the state's history.

As of Monday, the three major fires in South Jersey were controlled, and an arrest was made in one that authorities say began at gun range where a man was firing Dragon's Breath shotgun shells, which are designed to spread flames.

In North Jersey, emergency crews are mourning the loss 18-year-old Dariel Vasques, a New York State Forest ranger helping battle the 3,000-acre Jennings Creek Wildfire burning in both Passaic County, New Jersey, and Orange County, New York. Sunday's rain helped give rest to crews that had been working nonstop to contain the fire.

Here's the status of the South Jersey fires that began burning last week, all of which began amid an extreme drought in the state.

Shotgun Wildfire

Crews have made substantial progress fighting what the New Jersey Forest Fire Service has dubbed the Shotgun Wildfire, with 90% contained as of Friday. Officials have not updated the status of the fire as of Monday morning.

But it tore through 350 acres in the Colliers Mills Wildlife Management Area in the area of Stump Tavern Road in Jackson Township, Ocean County, not far from Six Flags Great Adventure. The fire began Nov. 6., burned 350 acres, and caused evacuations.

On Sunday, authorities arrested Richard Shashaty, 37, of Brick Township, and charged him with arson and firearms violations after allegedly firing prohibited Dragon's Breath shotgun ammunition. He was using the ammo while at the Central Jersey Rifle Range, where authorities say the fire ignited.

Shashaty turned himself in at the Jackson Township Police Department headquarters over the weekend, accompanied by his attorney, officials said. He was transferred to the Ocean County Jail, where he awaits a detention hearing.

What is Dragon's Breath?

According to authorities, Shashaty was firing rounds of Dragon's Breath 12-gauge from a shotgun, emitting magnesium shards that ignited "combustibles on the berm of the shooting range."

The firing of incendiary or tracer ammunition is prohibited in New Jersey. Officials said Shashaty was responsible for firing the ammunition. The ammo is designed to produce a pyrotechnic effect.

For example, Phoenix Rising advertises its "Super Dragon' Dragon's Breath" 12-gauge rounds, saying they have "an incredible range of 200 plus yards and a burn rate of over 5,000 degrees. It is the highest quality and most effective round of its type made. While it is extremely fun to shoot, it is also an effective deterrent."

The company notes that the Dragon's Breath rounds became much more popular after the release of John Wick: Chapter 4, part of the popular hyper-violent eponymous series. The Dragon's Breath scene has been analyzed by various aficionados. New York magazine's culture website,Vulture, for example, wrote a lengthy breakdown of the "Dragon's Breath" scene, and many have posted clips of it across social media.

The rounds became so popular, they had to be back-ordered.

Pheasant Run Wildfire

The wildfire that broke out in the Glassboro Wildlife Management Area in Gloucester County, and first spotted from the Blue Anchor FireTower on Nov. 7, burned through 133 acres, and was 75% contained as of Friday, the last update from the New Jersey Forest Fire Service.

Firefighters remained on the scene for days, and the blaze produced significant amounts of smoke that could be seen and smelled for days.

No more updates are expected, as officials considered the fire no longer a threat.

Bethany Run Wildfire

As of Friday, crews had contained 90% of the a 360-acre wildfire that broke out on the border of Burlington and Camden Counties on Nov. 7, where it was originally spotted from the Medford Fire Tower. The fire burned near the popular Black Run Preserve in Evesham and smoke could be seen in Philadelphia. It caused the evacuation of 12 homes. However, residents were later allowed to return home.

Did Sunday night's rain help drought conditions?

Though it rained overnight Sunday into Monday, a persistent drought still affects the Philadelphia region. Officially, 0.31 inches was measured at Philadelphia International Airport, and was not close to putting a dent into the deficit, though it did improve fire conditions.

The drought has been acute in South Jersey, where some counties were suffering from 10-inch rain deficits the past 90 days - prior to the rain. The state issued a ban on open fires in October and has asked residents to voluntary conserve water. There is no rain in the forecast for the next week.

urn:contentItem:6F20-9H13-RVDB-S19X-00000-00Study Findings on Climate Change Described by Researchers at Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee (Design and Development of a Pine Needle Briquetting Machine for the Uttarakhand Region of India)2025-02-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEStudy Findings on Climate Change Described by Researchers at Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee (Design and Development of a Pine Needle Briquetting Machine for the Uttarakhand Region of India)


2025 FEB 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on climate change. According to news originating from Uttarakhand, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Fossil fuels, a non-renewable source, supply more than 81% of the world's primary energy and contribute heavily to global climate change. This paper represents a strategy to address the administration of forest bio residue in the northern Himalayan district of India."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee: "Uttarakhand state, the north part of India, is rich in bio residues such as Pine needles of Chir Pine (Pinus roxburghii). Every year during the summer, there is a forest fire breakout, mainly caused by these dry pine needles, which cover a forest floor and are highly flammable. This forest bio residue is renewable and is a potential energy source for rural livelihoods, which would also generate social business enterprises among the locals. This is an effort to develop a practical manual-operated briquetting machine (BM) capable of fabricating briquettes from forest waste. The primary materials utilized to make briquettes are pine needles and forest waste. The proposed method inculcates principles of compression molding along with necessary optimizations. Briquetting is one of the cheapest ways to harvest the destructive energy of pine needles in a clean and economically viable way. Briquetting machines reduce forest fires by reducing dependency on wood from forests for fuel while simultaneously lowering carbon emissions by using biomass or agricultural waste as alternative fuel sources. This dual benefit protects forests and helps battle climate change and local air pollution, making it a long-term option for environmental protection."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The developed BM is one solution that can solve the dual purpose of climate change mitigation and employment. The designed and developed machine fabricates thirty-three briquettes per hour and is currently installed in the Uttarkashi district of Uttarakhand, India."
For more information on this research see: Design and Development of a Pine Needle Briquetting Machine for the Uttarakhand Region of India. Mechanics of Advanced Composite Structures, 2024,12(2):293-303. The publisher for Mechanics of Advanced Composite Structures is Semnan University.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.22075/macs.2024.33800.1644.

urn:contentItem:6DD8-84G1-DY68-114S-00000-00Fire Map Shows Update on New Jersey 'Extreme' Risks2024-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisFire Map Shows Update on New Jersey 'Extreme' RisksSophie Clark

A new map of wildfire risk in New Jersey shows the state at a high to extreme risk of fires as blazes continue.

A new map updated by the New Jersey Forest Fire Service shows that the entire state is at risk of fires, ranging from "high" risk in the south to "extreme" risk in the north.

The fires have already claimed one life, and according to the NJFFS, the fire raging between New Jersey and New York is still only 20 percent contained.

Caryn Shinske, a public information officer for the NJFFS, told Newsweek that the service is "extraordinarily busy" due to the state's fires.

The NJFFS stated on social media that it is facing "significant challenges" battling state fires, specifically the Jennings Creek wildfire in West Milford on the border of New Jersey and New York, which is still burning across 3,500 acres.

In a press conference Monday on the ongoing Jennings Creek fire, Chris Franek, assistant division fire warden, said: "The challenges that we are facing with the fire are, first of all, it is in a remote area, the terrain is very rugged, and we also have shifting winds."

The NJFFS said on X that it will deploy helicopters capable of dropping 250 gallons of water into the zone. It has already deployed Fores Fire Service engines and ground crews to contain the blaze.

The NJFFS defines a wildfire as a "major wildfire" after it exceeds 100 acres in size. At 3,500 acres, the Jennings Creek fire is far beyond the state's definition of "major. "

Fires are also burning in other parts of the state, including Passaic County and Jackson Township.

While the cause of the Jennings Creek fire remains unknown, local news station Fox 5 reports that the Jackson Township fire was caused by arson.

Fox 5 reported that Ocean County prosecutors are producing arson and firearms charges in connection with the blaze. Prosecutors claimed on November 9 that the fire was sparked by "magnesium shards from a shotgun round."

The Tri-State Area fires turned deadly yesterday when a teenager was killed in one of the many blazes across New Jersey and New York.

Dariel Vasquez, 18, was battling the fires in Greenwood Lake, near the New Jersey border, when, per authorities, a tree fell on him. His death remains under investigation.

October was also the driest month in New York City history. Afall drought has affected large areasof the United States, making forest fires much more likely to catch and keep burning.

urn:contentItem:6B11-SSR1-JCH9-G333-00000-00Laoag vice mayor urges public to prevent forest fire2024-01-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisLaoag vice mayor urges public to prevent forest fire

01 Jan 2024 (Philippines News Agency) Laoag City Vice Mayor Rey Carlos Fariñas on Monday called on the public help prevent grassfires during this dry and windy season.

Fariñas, founder of the Fariñas Fire and Rescue Volunteers in this city, made the call after he and his team responded to a grass fire in Barangay 33B, La Paz, Laoag City within the La Paz dunes, a popular tourist destination for 4x4 rides and sand boarding in Ilocos Norte province.

He said the grass fire was caused by some drunken men who lit fireworks near the 4x4 view deck as evidenced by a recovered empty fireworks box and lighter.

Fire authorities said the blaze was put out immediately with the help of the village's firefighting brigade and the operators of 4x4, who used big drums filled with water from the firetruck and transported them using the 4x4 vehicle because the fire truck could not go near the grassfire area.

'Let us be vigilant to prevent forest fire that could risk the lives and properties of our constituents,' Fariñas said, noting that the incident happened near residential properties.

Authorities have been raising alarm over the rising incidents of forest and grass fires in Ilocos Norte, with 23 recorded incidents from February to March 6, 2023 alone, which tore through the city of Batac and the towns of Vintar, Sarrat, Currimao, Marcos, Banna, Piddig, Paoay, Solsona, and Nueva Era.

Marcel Tabije, head of the provincial resiliency office, said most of the wildfires reported during the period were due to human activities that involved 'burning of agricultural farm wastes and throwing of cigarette butts in grassy areas.'

'We urge the public to be vigilant and report it immediately to the Bureau of Fire Protection if you happen to see a grassfire incident,' he said.

Aside from limited manpower, officials of the Bureau of Fire Projection (BFP) here said they currently lack forest fire fighting equipment and a jet shooter backpack.

The BFP has been recommending to local authorities the installation of radio towers in isolated areas to ensure quick response in case of wildfires.

urn:contentItem:6DD3-2KJ1-JCMC-W2MG-00000-00Deadly blaze near New York-New Jersey border has risk of spreading, forecasters warn2024-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisDeadly blaze near New York-New Jersey border has risk of spreading, forecasters warn

A wildfire fueled by drought near the New Jersey-New York border left an 18-year-old volunteer firefighter dead, burned through thousands of acres and forecasters are warning of an increased risk of spread Tuesday

According to theNew Jersey Forest Fire Service, theJennings Creekwildfire in West Milford, New Jersey, has consumed 3,500 acres and is 20% contained. The fire is burning through Passaic County, New Jersey and Orange County, New York, about 50 miles northwest of Manhattan.

The fire, discovered on Saturday, spread to Orange County that same night, reported NorthJersey.com, part of the USA TODAY Network.

Dariel Vasquez, 18, was a volunteer firefighter for the Wildland Fire Crew when he was killed by a falling tree Saturday night, NorthJersey.com reported. He was battling the fire on the border of New Jersey and New York.

Link to Image

"Our hearts and prayers go out to the 18-year-old volunteer with the Park Service who lost his life battling the fire today," the Town of Warwick, New York, state in a Facebook post.

His death is being investigated by the New York State Police.

USA TODAY has reached out to the New Jersey Forest Fire Service and New York State Department of Environment Conservation regarding the fire.

Elevated risk of spread Tuesday: National Weather Service

National Weather Service forecasters are warning that there is a high risk of the fire continuing to spread further Tuesday amid strong winds and low humidity levels.

Wind gusts of up to 35 mph and humidity levels between 30 and 40% "will support the spread of any fires that ignite," forecasters in New York said in a Special Weather Statement Monday afternoon.

The National Weather Service is strongly discouraging people in the area from having fires outdoors and warning people to properly dispose of any potential wildfire fuel, including cigarette butts.

New Jersey/New York wildfire mapWhat caused the fire?

The cause of the fire is under investigation, according to the New Jersey Forest Fire Service.

Rainfall offers respite

The area received around .25 inches of rain Sunday night through early Monday morning, according to the department. It allowed firefighters to contain a portion of the fire, which was made worse by the drought the area is facing.

The rain comes at a time when the area has seen the driest fall season in recorded history, James Tomasini, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service, NWS, New YorkNY, told USA TODAY.

"We're well well below average in terms of rainfall," Tomasini said.

From Sept. 1 through Nov. 10, the Newark, New Jersey, 42 miles southeast of Passaic County, received a total of .96 inches of rainfall.

Newark normally averages 3.79 inches of rain in October alone, according to Tomasini.

"That's pretty much the lowest amount of rainfall we've seen this far into fall," said the meteorologist.

In October, the city only got a "trace" of rain, which wasn't enough to be measurable, making it the driest October on record, and the driest month the area has experienced in recorded history.

Windy conditions

While the area is experiencing gusts of wind between 10 to 20 mph, the bit of rain the area experienced overnight into Monday and elevated humidity levels have made conditions less favorable for the fire to spread, Tomasini said.

We are able to see a wildfire along the NJ/NY border from space courtesy of @NOAASatellites. Some of this smoke/haze may be visible further south into NYC. Smaller fires are also faintly visible, one in central Passaic County, one in SE Orange County, one in SW Putnam County. pic.twitter.com/IMV9VtXUos

— NWS New YorkNY (@NWSNewYorkNY)

November 9, 2024

Smoke visible from space

On Saturday, smoke from the fire was visible from space, according to a post on the NWS New YorkNY X account.

"We are able to see a wildfire along the NJ/NY border from space courtesy of @NOAASatellites," it stated. "Some of this smoke/haze may be visible further south into [New York City]."

There were air quality alerts because of the smoke from the flames over the weekend, according to Tomasini. However, as of 12 p.m. ET on Monday, none are in effect.

urn:contentItem:6GBB-GG73-RRYX-40P9-00000-00Volumetric quantifications and dynamics of areas undergoing retrogressive thaw slumping in the Northern Hemisphere2025-11-15T08:18:07Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisVolumetric quantifications and dynamics of areas undergoing retrogressive thaw slumping in the Northern Hemisphere

Supplementary informationThe online version contains supplementary material available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-025-62017-0.Publisher’s note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

Retrogressive thaw slumping (RTS) is a mass-wasting process characterized by upslope backwasting and rapid thawing of ice-rich permafrost. High-resolution digital elevation models (DEMs) from ArcticDEM enable the volumetric and soil organic carbon quantification of medium to large disturbance areas undergoing RTS ( ≥10,000 m2) for the Northern Hemisphere. Using DEM time-series analysis and deep learning, we retrieve a total of 2747 disturbance areas undergoing active RTS with a total volume loss of (317.0 ± 0.3) × 106 m3 between 2012 and 2022. Here we show that climatic drivers of RTS activity exhibit latitudinal and regional variations, specifically, the number of precipitation-driven RTS decreases linearly as latitudes increase, whereas temperature-driven RTS increases sharply. Finally, we estimate that 96% of detected RTS thawed ~1.95 × 10–3 Pg carbon per year, equivalent to ~0.2% of annual gradual thaw emission estimates. Our results highlight the complexity of regional RTS dynamics and the importance of high resolution, long-term monitoring efforts.

This study systematically mapped 2747 retrogressive thaw slumps during the past decade. It finds that higher latitude thaw slumps are mainly driven by temperature, while lower latitudes are influenced by prior-year climate and precipitation.

IntroductionThe Northern Hemisphere, particularly the Arctic, is warming at a rate two to four times faster than the global average (refs. 1, 2–3). This rapid warming is driving cascading environmental4,5 and societal impacts6, including thawing permafrost7, 8–9. Permafrost underlies ~15% of exposed land surface of the Northern Hemisphere10 yet disproportionally consists of 34% of the global soil carbon storage11,12. When permafrost thaws, the landscape response is largely dependent on ground ice content, ranging from minor elevation change over ice-poor permafrost areas to larger amounts of thaw-subsidence in ice-rich areas causing landscape modifications known as thermokarst13, 14, 15–16. In recent years, efforts have been made to estimate thermokarst extent and its potential greenhouse gas emissions17,18, however regional scale empirically-based assessments indicate a wide range of variability in the nature and distribution of thermokarst processes15. While there is high confidence that climate warming is increasing permafrost temperatures, there is greater uncertainty in the magnitude and distribution of thaw-driven change and estimates of associated greenhouse gas release12.

Large uncertainties in understanding the consequences of permafrost thaw remain especially for thermokarst on hill-slopes (i.e., thaw-driven mass wasting) due to a lack of large-scale Northern Hemisphere studies concerning the spatial distribution of mass wasting, volumetric rates of subsidence, and a scarcity of information about biogeochemical cycling and emissions of thawed material19, 20–21. For example, Olefeldt et al.17 estimated 4.9% of the pan-Arctic (0.91 × 106 km2) to be susceptible to low-to-moderate levels of hillslope thermokarst activity, while Turetsky et al.18 initiated their hillslope abrupt thaw model spin-ups at 1.4% of all pan-Arctic lands to be affected by hillslope mass wasting (and 3% annual increases of active thaw afterwards). One of the most dramatic and rapidly evolving examples of hillslope thermokarst are areas undergoing retrogressive thaw slumping (RTS)22, 23–24. Despite increasing interests in understanding the three-dimensional characterization and dynamics of RTS at local to regional scales8,25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31–32, the majority of the literature (including recent deep learning studies) focus on one or two-dimensional detection and measurement of RTS (e.g.,33, 34, 35–36) through which thawed volumetrics (and greenhouse gas emissions) cannot be obtained. Quantification of the spatial distribution and rates of subsidence of medium- to large RTS (i.e., ≥10,000 m2) is especially important as these disproportionally contribute the most to regional-scale volumetric budgets due to deeper thaw and non-linear area-volume scaling effects8,31. These uncertainties and information gaps identify an important need for a Northern Hemisphere quantification of the total and annual volume loss of RTS to calibrate future earth system and emission models and validate predictions of previous models.

Thaw slumping describes “the landsliding process involving the melting of ground ice and [subsidence or] collapse of thawed material” (37, p. 91). When this process occurs as backwasting or upslope enlargement it is specified as retrogressive thaw slumping. The permafrost literature describes retrogressive thaw slumping both as a complex set of thermokarst processes as well as a thermokarst landform, termed retrogressive thaw slumps. This identical terminology between process and landform can create inconsistencies in what to map38 as well as challenge the calibration and validation of machine learning models for large-scale detections31,38. Henceforth for clarity, we use RTS to denote the process of retrogressive thaw slumping and use the term slumps to denote landforms described as retrogressive thaw slumps37.

The most common landforms undergoing RTS are thaw slumps; however, RTS can also shape landforms from dead glacial ice in recent ice-cored moraine complexes39, 40–41. Ice-rich permafrost is required for RTS to occur and as a thaw-driven mass wasting process, the primary process of RTS is the ablation of an ice-rich headwall typically of crescent or elongated shape (Fig. 1c42;). RTS can be highly dynamic; initializing quickly in a single thaw season and remaining active for decades33,43, or ceasing activity before potential reactivation occurs44. However, in the last two decades, intensification of material transfer in response to temperature and precipitation increases has transformed RTS dynamics in many Arctic regions, driving feedbacks that perpetuate retrogressing growth, increase downwasting, and impact downstream environments, leading to the development of areas undergoing RTS to reach between 50,000 m2 and 400,000 m2, creating landforms termed “mega slumps”8,22. Volumetric enlargement at the retrogressing headwall remains the primary mechanism of thawing ice-rich permafrost, and the disturbance areas undergoing this process are the focus of this study (Fig. 1). A lack of representative RTS training data is often cited as one of the greatest limiting factors to achieve accurate and transferable deep learning models for pan-Arctic detections45, 46–47, and studies typically overcome this by merging regional datasets from various sources and vintages (refs. 48,49), which might be sparse and biased50, as well as remote-sensing based and unverified by permafrost experts38. There is thus a need for a temporally consistent, reproducible, and spatially comprehensive and representative Northern Hemisphere dataset with standardized geomorphic ontological definitions.Fig. 1

Using the ArcticDEM time series51, here we present the quantification of volumetric change and soil organic carbon release from large disturbance areas undergoing RTS in the Northern Hemisphere for regions ≥60°N (including Alaska, Greenland, Kamchatka Peninsula) for the last decade (2012–2022) and generate a baseline inventory of RTS (i.e., actively retrogressing ice-rich headwalls) with disturbance area and terrain subsidence (total volume loss) estimates as well as annual volumetric yield estimates. These estimates are further correlated with climate variabilities and used to obtain a first-order estimate of soil organic carbon release.

Results

RTS Distribution and Area Estimates

The spatial distribution of medium- to large disturbance areas undergoing RTS ( ≥10,000 m2; minimum elevation change of 2 m) was obtained using deep learning detection models attuned to thaw-driven geomorphic RTS processes of annual subsidence (see Methods and Fig. 1). Sequential differencing of DEMs from the ArcticDEM time-series (n = 440,949 strips52;) highlighted incremental surface elevation changes associated with the retrogression of ice-rich headwalls53, the timing and spatial pattern of which was used as a key distinctive feature during detection (termed the “rainbow” pattern; Figs. 2c, S3e) that distinguished RTS from elevation changes caused by other landscape processes or time-series noise. After manual verification by topical experts, a total of 2747 disturbance areas undergoing RTS were retained across the Northern Hemisphere for which elevation change magnitudes were summarized (Fig. 2a). These verified sites reflect geomorphic change within a 10-year period (2012–2022), characterized by areas of active subsidence through annual thaw-driven headwall ablation and upslope expansion. The median and maximum RTS disturbance area was 20,680 m2 and 249,540 m2 (Fig. 3a), respectively, with a total disturbance area undergoing RTS in the Northern Hemisphere of 78.6 km2 (7860 ha). Compared to the pan-Arctic ground ice map54, 77% of RTS occurred in areas with high ground ice content (1.37 ha 1000 km−2; Fig. S10; ice content >20%), 5% in areas with medium ground ice content (0.15 ha 1000 km−2; ice content between 10% and 20%) and 18% in areas with low ground ice content (0.20 ha 1000 km−2; ice content <10%). The 2747 confirmed disturbance areas were spatially concentrated across several geographic regions (Fig. 2) consistent with results from regional-scale mapping efforts of slumps, such as Banks Island33, the northwest coast of Victoria Island, Peel Plateau - Mackenzie Delta regions31,55, Eureka Sound Lowlands46,56, Novaya Zemlya57, and western23 and central Siberian Arctic30,58,59. In addition to the detection of RTS of common landscape positions and morphologies (i.e., next to fluvial channels or lakeshore- or coastline-based), the deep learning models also identified a series of RTS in Yakutia, Russia (Fig. S13b) that exhibit a different morphology, termed thermoterraces41, that are morphologically distinct from the typical crescent shape of slumps and are challenging to identify and delineate even by domain experts38. Other areas undergoing RTS were detected along current glacier margins in northern Greenland, Svalbard, near Klutlan Glacier, Canada; and in Novaya Zemlya, Russia, where glacier dead-ice backwasting occurs (Fig. S13f) (ref. 60). There are considerable geomorphological differences between dead-ice backwasting in recent ice-cored moraine complexes and RTS, yet the small number of large dead-ice backwasting detections (>10,000 m2) were not manually excluded from the inventory as both mass wasting phenomena occur on ice-cored slopes, are thaw related, and exhibit similar elevation change “rainbow” patterns due to their retrogressive, rotational sliding failure mechanisms39, 40–41. Furthermore, the strong linkage between RTS detections with modern-day glacier margins is compatible with RTS activity across northwestern Canada where terrain encompassing the former glacial margins of the Laurentide Ice Sheet contains relict glacier ice preserved by permafrost61.

Volumetric Estimates and Growth Dynamics

We estimated terrain subsidence (total volume loss) as a result of headwall ablation and RTS growth over the last decade (2012–2022), with volume estimates consisting of ground ice loss and sediment release that would subsequently flow downslope (e.g., Fig. 18,22). The total volume loss for all 2747 areas undergoing RTS was (317.0 ± 0.3) × 106 m3 between 2012 and 2022. The 25 and 100 largest RTS by volume loss (0.9% or 3.6% of total RTS count) contributed 31.0 and 75.3 × 106 m3 (10% and 24%) of the total volume loss, respectively, confirming the disproportionate impacts of the largest areas undergoing RTS8,31.
