Across the Northern Hemisphere, the median ground surface elevation change for all medium-to-large RTS was −3 meters and the median volume loss was 62,484 m3 with a standard deviation of 167,125 m3 (Table 1, and Fig. 3b, c). Most RTS events (86.7%) considered in this study were <200,000 m3 in size (<400,000 m3 95.5%), and average and maximum headwall heights ranged considerably, between 1 to 10 m and 1 to 30 m, respectively (Fig. 3c, d). Larger RTS (by volume) were concentrated within narrow latitudinal bands of 67 °N and 81–82°N, while the highest headwalls were concentrated at latitudes 62°N and 65–68°N (Fig. 3e, f). The largest individual RTS by volume loss during the monitoring period occurred 30 km southwest of Aklavik, Canada (68°N) in the Willow River catchment8, totaling 3,584,000 ± 54,000 m3, a retrogression area of 249,540 m2 (25 ha), and a maximum surface elevation change of −33 ± 1 m. The RTS inventory also addressed knowledge gaps related to the volume loss from thawing headwalls and how that changes with further slump enlargement8,31. Our study shows a generally consistent (log10) power-law relationship between RTS area and volume loss across different regions in the Northern Hemisphere (Table 1, see “Methods”), with most regions clustered around a scaling exponent of 1.24–1.33. Larger regional contrasts do exist, e.g., scaling exponent ranging from 1.16 (in Plateaus and Plains of Northern Asia) to 1.36 (in Southern Nunavut), indicating a varying degree of non-linearity in the response of RTS expanding volumetrically with increasing area that are likely governed by regional topographic slope configurations and sub-surface conditions.

Temporal metrics provided insights into the annual dynamics of RTS. The majority (75%) of areas undergoing RTS yielded <10,000 m3 annually (<20,000 m3 89.6%), with median yields of 5013 m3 (Fig. 3g). Summarizing annual volumetric yields across regions (named after Provinces and Divisions as defined by62), RTS located in the Arctic Lowlands (e.g., Banks Island), Mackenzie Mountains, and Brooks Range (incl. Peel Plateau) exhibited the largest yields of 10.0, 4.1, and 4.1 million m3/year, respectively, due to their large population of areas undergoing RTS (Table 1). At a combined 18.2 million m3/year, these three regions contributed up to 56.8% of the observed annual yields across the Northern Hemisphere. The majority of RTS exhibited a relatively stable momentum in their annual yields (i.e., near 0 m3/year2), meaning that annual activity is neither accelerating or decelerating. However, as a whole Northern Hemisphere population, momentum was slightly positive with a mean of 179 m3/year2 (Fig. 3h) indicating a slight acceleration in annual volume loss. These momentum estimates are affected by pronounced annual peaks and lows of activity, but provide useful insights into the net long-term trends of RTS in the Northern Hemisphere as well as sub-regions. For example, across the Northern Hemisphere the decadal trend shows a slight increasing volume loss rate, with total volume loss per year showing peaks in 2016 and 2020 with lows in 2013 and 2018 (Fig. 4b), which are consistent with temperature peaks and troughs in these years (next Section). Temporal trends also varied across regions (Fig. 4c), some characterized by positive momentum with accelerating annual volumetrics, such as Plateaus and Plains of Northern Asia (PPNA) with an acceleration of (0.27 ± 0.05) million m3/year2, Ural Mountains (UM) (UM Division includes Yugorsky Peninsula and Novaya Zemlya Archipelago) with (0.29 ± 0.07) million m3/year2, and Brooks Range (BR) with (0.32 ± 0.08) million m3/year2, while other regions are decelerating (volume loss decreases through time) such as Arctic Lowlands (AL) with (−0.5 ± 0.3) million m3/year2. RTS Activity in Response to Climate Variabilities

To evaluate the impact of climate variabilities on RTS activity, the correlation between volume loss per year and the air temperature and precipitation time series was calculated for individual RTS (e.g., Fig. 2d), latitudinal and regional groupings, as well as for all RTS in the Northern Hemisphere. Correlations were calculated for the same year as well as the previous year to account for pre-conditioning effects where an extreme summer one year leads to slope failure in the subsequent year (refs. 63,64). Across the Northern Hemisphere a total of 816 RTS (30%) showed strong positive correlations (r ≥ 0.5) (Fig. 4) with same-year air temperature, consistent with current literature43,56. A total of 329 RTS (12%) showed strong correlations (r > =0.5) with same-year precipitation trends. Figure 5 highlights latitude-dependent differences in the linkage to temperature and precipitation, with individual RTS binned based on their latitudinal distribution. 71 °N marks the inflection point where RTS dynamics were predominantly driven by rising temperatures. The percentage of temperature-driven RTS (influenced by both the same year and previous year temperature) increased sharply from 40% to 88% (as percentage of RTS within their respective distribution bins, Fig. 5) as latitudes increased from 71°N–82°N, and the precipitation-driven RTS decreased linearly from 60% to 13% as latitudes increased from 60°N to 82°N. As shown in Fig. 5, preconditioning effects from climate in the previous year64 appear prominent at lower latitudes (< 65°N), where the percentage of RTS affected by previous-year precipitation (27%) is greater than by same-year precipitation (14%), while at high latitudes(>75°N), the percentage of RTS influenced by previous-year temperature (8%) is significantly lower than those affected by same-year temperature (42%).Fig. 5

Soil Organic Carbon Release

Here we provide the estimate of soil organic carbon (SOC) release from RTS on a Northern Hemisphere scale using empirical volumetric subsidence rates. An estimated 1.95 × 10–3 Pg carbon per year (where 1 petagram =1 gigatonnes) was released between 2012 and 2022 for 96% of the detected RTS that were within the Northern Circumpolar Soil Carbon Database area (NCSC)65. The remaining RTS were located outside the database coverage (e.g., Northern Greenland, coastal margins). The NCSC only estimates the upper 3 m of soil, therefore these values are an under estimation for 979 RTS that had mean elevation changes between >3 m and 19 m, however the highest carbon amounts have been shown to generally occur in the upper 3 m and decrease with depth58.

It could be argued that a large number of small disturbance areas undergoing RTS (area <10,000 m2, small elevation changes) not considered in this study could lead to underestimations of carbon release. To estimate this effect, we used area-frequency distribution modeling and comparisons with detailed manual RTS inventories to estimate the total RTS population size and volumetrics of small areas undergoing RTS (Figs. S11a, S12), resulting in an additional 2244 to 12,514 areas or 18.0–63.8 × 106 m3 (see Methods). The inclusion of small RTS increases the total Northern Hemisphere volume estimate from 317.0 × 106 m3 to a range of 335 to 381 × 106 m3, and shows that the effect of undetected smaller RTS on carbon release is small, comprising only 5–17% of the estimated total volume.

Discussion

This work presents the quantification of volumetric change from large areas undergoing RTS in the Northern Hemisphere between 2012 and 2022. This work has also generated a baseline inventory of active RTS and disturbance area, terrain subsidence (total volume loss), and annual volumetric yield estimates, that were correlated to climate variabilities and used to obtain a first-order estimate of soil organic carbon release. The detection models used in this study were attuned to the incremental surface elevation changes associated with the retrogression of ice-rich headwalls, i.e., visualized as time-transgressive rainbow patterns found in ArcticDEM53. The degree to which these signals were extracted (see “Methods”) and used in deep learning algorithms highlights continual advances in data availability and computing resources to further mature RTS mapping over large geographic extents. Furthermore, the presented ontology, methods, and results point to an important methodological improvement over existing methods using point or aerial detection and measurement approaches of RTS (e.g.,33, 34, 35–36). While there has been increasing interest in understanding the three-dimensional characterization and dynamics of RTS at local to regional scales, our study has identified important insights into the magnitude and distribution of hillslope retrogressive subsidence employing volumetric loss detections, non-linear scaling, and regional patterns of RTS > 60°N latitude. For instance, the total reported volume loss observed between 2012 and 2022 (317.0 ± 0.3 × 106 m3) and three-dimensional characterization (median elevation change −3 m, median volume loss 62,484 m3 ± 167,125 m3, most RTS <200,000 m3) help fill knowledge gaps to validate existing thermokarst, geohazard, earth system and emission assumptions and models (Fig. 317,18;). These models can be further refined in the future by taking into account updated estimates of annual volumetric losses (median: 5013 m3, majority <10,000 m3), the regional or latitudinal differences in morphology and dynamics (i.e., headwall height, annual volumetrics), as well as knowledge of how the volumetric loss from thawing headwalls changes non-linearly with further slump enlargement (area-volume scaling). In terms of future expected RTS intensifications, we note that the mean momentum for individual RTS in the Northern Hemisphere was slightly positive (representing increasing volume loss through time) at 179 m3/year2 with specific regions characterized by either positive (Plateaus and Plains of Northern Asia, Ural Mountains, Brooks Range) or negative momentum (Arctic Lowlands), or exhibiting constant/mid-decadal peaks. It was beyond the scope of this study to determine the drivers behind the regional differences in volumes, depths, yields, scaling coefficients, or momentum, which should be considered in future work. Drivers governing these differences are most likely related to regional topographic slope configurations, subsurface conditions, landscape genesis (e.g., glacial legacy), and the most recent disturbance or thaw history (e.g., presence of old or ancient RTS disturbances, wildfire) (31,42,61,63,66). In terms of RTS intensity, of particular emphasis is the degree of concentration observed at local to regional scales, with the 100 largest disturbance areas undergoing RTS (3.6% of total count) contributing 24% of the total volume loss observed across the study area, and with the top three regions, specifically the Arctic Lowlands (e.g., Banks Island), Mackenzie Mountains, and Brooks Range (incl. Peel Plateau), yielding up to 56.8% of the observed annual yields across the Northern Hemisphere. This not only further confirms the disproportionate impacts of the largest areas undergoing RTS8,31, but also points to the continued importance of sustained local and regional monitoring with northern stakeholders in parallel to large-area initiatives such as presented here8,15,27.

Limitations and Uncertainties

As with any large-scale compilation of mapped phenomena, there are limitations and uncertainties in the presented dataset and findings. In addition to common errors and noise in stereoscopic DEMs53, our approach contains limitations and sources of errors specifically related to the portion of a retrogressing landform under analysis (e.g., a slump), the temporal and geographic coverage of the ArcticDEM domain, and potential volumetric errors arising from sediment and snow. Firstly, from an ontological perspective, our method focused on detecting and measuring areas of active subsidence through DEM differencing, specifically detecting headwall retrogression between 2012 and 2022. The deep learning models were not trained to detect landforms produced by RTS (e.g., slumps) that include scar areas representing inactive areas. Rather, the models were trained to detect large contiguous areas undergoing RTS (as a geomorphic mass wasting process) with a minimum size of 10,000 m2 and a minimum elevation change of −2 m. The largest known slumps in the literature (e.g., the Peel Plateau’s “FM2” or Russia’s “Batagay”), considered megaslumps (landforms >20 ha)22,43,67,68, are complex disturbances comprised of multiple smaller active headwalls as well as inactive areas. Although these two thaw slumps have headwalls 10’s of meters high, activity is localized. The two specific slump landforms were not included in our dataset as they either did not meet the minimal size threshold, or due to other data limitations or surrounding noises that reduced the prominence of the rainbow pattern (Fig. S15b, e). Similar large, partially active RTS are missed in our analyses where minimum size or elevation change threshold of the actively subsiding area was not met. Heterogeneous activity across large disturbances and size constraints has also been reported by other detection studies (e.g., Batagay34;). Due to the minimum size or elevation change threshold adopted in this work, our dataset also excludes many small or shallow slumps characterized by smaller elevation changes (e.g., Fig. S15h26,69).

Secondly, an overall limitation of ArcticDEM is that the temporal resolution varies throughout its geographic coverage depending on the availability of stereographic pairs of images used to create the DEMs. Therefore, the temporal and geographic coverage of DEMs is not uniform across the study region. The ArcticDEM domain also does not include regions south of 60°N except for Alaska, southern Greenland, and the Kamchatka Peninsula and, therefore, does not cover the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, another known RTS hotspot36. Furthermore, classification based on the unique rainbow pattern reflecting the time-transgressive nature of RTS enlargement could miss detection of disturbances already initiated but with only two DEMs available for differencing. In this case, the corresponding rainbow pattern would be absent and thus not be included in the final RTS detection count. The large number of false positives before visual inspection (Table S4) were caused by various sources, such as other mass wasting, snow/glacier melt, and vegetation changes (e.g.,53).

Lastly, our analysis approach provided the mean elevation difference before and after the epoch with the most significant change for each pixel. This means elevation change may differ from a simple difference between the first and last DEM more commonly employed in geomorphology studies53. This is a potential source of error in volume estimates that are also found in other studies30 because the only measured change is within the active retrogressing area between two epochs. Reference 53 has shown that this commonly leads to under-estimations of volume losses and could therefore impact area-volume scaling coefficients, yet overall the expected impact to our Northern Hemisphere results and interpretations is low. Additionally, in order to conduct an analysis of RTS dynamics at this large scale we had to include winter scenes to ensure adequate temporal data coverage. Changes in snow cover between DEMs can cause an overestimation of measured RTS subsidence, because elevation differences would measure loss of sediments and snow when differencing a summer and winter scene70. Differencing two winter scenes would likely mitigate some effect of snow if snow depths are similar. Despite these limitations, this study represents the quantification of the volume and three-dimensional dynamics of RTS in the Northern Hemisphere, which was made possible by collaboration between remote sensing scientists and disciplinary experts.

Volumetric Estimates and Links to Climate Variability

A second objective of this study was to correlate the annual volumetric yield estimates with climate variability. We observed that 57% of RTS had growth dynamics that were either correlated with ERA5 temperature or precipitation trends from the same or previous year. RTS dynamics were predominantly driven by temperature increases at high latitudes, and RTS dynamics are most strongly linked to climate from the previous year at lower latitudes (<65°N). In areas where temperature dominates the driver for RTS activity (e.g., >71°N, climate-driven permafrost56,71), the volume loss rates are negatively correlated with precipitation time series (Fig. S14; Ellesmere Island). Higher latitude areas correspond with the distribution of Arctic polar desert environments72,73 that do not have enough precipitation to impact RTS retreat and the only moisture source to aid in sediment evacuation is from the ice face from the RTS headwall74. In contrast, permafrost in lower latitudes increasingly relies on ecosystem protection to persist71, which buffers against air temperature increases unless other disturbances coincide that initiate and/or sustain RTS63,67.

With respect to direct linkages between RTS growth dynamics and climate variabilities, it is worth emphasizing that 43% of RTS were neither correlated with ERA5 temperature nor precipitation trends from the same or previous year. It indicates that other drivers (e.g., ground ice exposure and local heterogeneity) introduce considerable variation in this observed temperature effect. Furthermore, as individual disturbances evolve and slope gradients change they can decouple from climate8,56. Limitations also arise from the heterogeneity in the accuracy and representativeness of ERA5 trends due to the limited number of Arctic weather stations and the short amount of yearly measurements (n ~ 10, Fig. 2d) used in this study. There is not a strong singular effect of temperature on RTS volumetric activity for lower latitudes (<71°N), which suggests it is not advisable to conduct risk assessments for the Northern Hemisphere purely on temperature trends alone75 without taking into account terrain conditions (ground ice, surficial geology, etc.) as primary explanatory variables. Future work should consider additional lagged or cumulative effects, as well as the importance of shorter-term extreme climatic events (e.g.,22,35,56). Overall, the results highlight there is a need for long-term and high temporal resolution monitoring and a densification of weather stations across the Arctic as ERA5 trends may be too coarse and imprecise to conduct local or regional correlations regarding RTS dynamics.

Carbon Release Estimates and Its Uncertainties

Carbon release from abrupt permafrost thaw is estimated to contribute approximately half of total permafrost carbon release from ~20% land area within the permafrost zone compared to carbon release from the gradual thawing of permafrost soils18. Within the modeling results by18, hillslope erosion, primarily from RTS, contributed to one-third of carbon release from abrupt permafrost thaw, or ~13% of carbon emissions compared to gradual thaw. While the amount of SOC released by RTS is not negligible, our estimate representing carbon released by abrupt thaw from subsidence processes suggests that the proportion of carbon released by RTS is less than initial model estimates. Our calculated value of ~1.95 × 10−3 Pg carbon per year within our time period is much less (~0.2%) compared to what was estimated (using modeling) to be released annually from gradual thawing permafrost (~1 Pg carbon per year)11. The impact of the RTS missed in the deep learning detection is likely small, around 20% (recall is high, 77%–80% - Table S3). Nevertheless, the carbon release is likely underestimated because some RTS are missed due to a less prominent time transient change pattern if only a single year of retrogression occurred during the observation period or if the disturbance area was affected by surrounding noise. The mean depth of elevation loss is 3 m, so our estimates represent at least average conditions within the study domain. Reference 58 found that the depths exceeding 3 m contributed to 15–20 % volume change and 5 to 10 % of total soil carbon mobilization. In our dataset, excluding carbon at depths greater than 3 m represents 30 % of volume with no carbon estimate. Ground ice content was not included in our carbon release estimate because the uppermost layers are comprised of the active layer and ice-poor permafrost above massive ice19. We believe the underestimation of not including the deeper ground layers offsets this potential overestimation for RTS with ground ice within the upper 3 m of soil.

While our study shows less overall carbon release from RTS process, field studies19,20 on the Peel Plateau have shown that released carbon is sequestered within redistributing and accumulating sediments (e.g., debris tongues, Fig. 1c) by becoming chemically bound through interactions with mineral soil. While variations in net carbon release vary regionally76, likely due to variation in carbon content of near-surface and deeper permafrost19, overall, our study along with these recent field studies19,20,76 point to net carbon released by RTS to be of lower magnitude than initially suggested by modeling18 and merits future work to better constraint values. Finally, most models focusing on the impacts of climate change on carbon release rely on increases in air temperature as a driver of thaw. Our Northern Hemisphere scale results of RTS dynamics show that only a subset of RTS dynamics correlate with ERA5 air temperature dynamics. While RTS may have less of an impact on carbon dynamics than initial modeling efforts have suggested, these processes still generate transformative impacts to the landscapes and ecosystems they are located in (e.g.,8,77,78). Their broad distribution, increasing size and dynamics, and general associations with a warmer and wetter climate highlight the importance of understanding complex interactions between thaw-driven mobilization and resequestration of organic carbon on the landscape and through aquatic systems (e.g.,8,19). We can anticipate that RTS will be a dominant, rapid modifier of many ice-rich permafrost landscapes in a warming circumpolar world, so bridging process knowledge of landscape evolution with geochemical and ecosystem impacts, and quantitative remote sensing assessments that track intensity and magnitudes of change at broad scales highlights the need for advancing multiscale assessments, and for interdisciplinary collaboration.

Methods

The ArcticDEM project51 provides a large collection of very high spatial resolution (2 m), open-access, and time-dependent DEMs covering the entire northern hemisphere landmass above 60 °N, as well as all of Alaska, Greenland and the Kamchatka Peninsula, enabling new opportunities for detecting and quantifying RTS. The ArcticDEM data are derived from sub-meter resolution (~0.5 m) stereo-pair images from the Maxar satellite constellation, including Worldview-1 (launched 2007), 2 (2009), 3 (2014), and GeoEye-1 (2008). ArcticDEM DEMs are created using stereophotogrammetry applied to overlapping pairs of images79, including pairs from the same or different orbital passes (i.e., in-track or cross-track pairs) and combinations of different sensors79.

The latest release of ArcticDEM (ArcticDEM strips version 4.1, Release October 2023) includes 440,949 time-dependent DEM strips across the Arctic. ArcticDEM data undergo basic automated quality control and filtering for errors due to clouds, shadows, detector saturation80, water surfaces, and other sources using algorithms developed by the ArcticDEM project team. To better preserve the original data, version 4.1 includes the error masks as separate files instead of applying the masks as in previous versions52,81.

The overall workflow for RTS detection is summarized in Fig. S1. It consisted of data preparations (Step 1: DEM co-registration and change detection) followed by an initial classification using simple raster-based thresholds (Step 2). This was followed by a multi-step deep-learning approach with iterative model training and validation using several training datasets and data augmentation approaches (Step 3). Finally, a two-step inspection approach using semi-automated decision rules followed by a manual inspection by subject matter experts reduced the sample size to its presented form (Table S4, Step 4).

Step 1: Retrieving surface elevation change from DEM time series

Co-registration of DEMs using bundle adjustment

The DEMs have an internal (pixel-to-pixel) accuracy of ~30 cm (1 sigma)82. Nevertheless, biases in the horizontal and vertical directions give an external (absolute) accuracy of several meters, caused by the errors in sensor models83,84. These biases can be removed through coregistration83,85 and the bundle adjustment of translational offsets among repeat DEMs82. Validation experiments over unchanging surfaces show that this coregistration reduces the uncertainty in elevation measurements to the random error in the DEMs of ~0.3 m ~ 0.5 m82,83,86,87. DEMs with consistently poor pairwise coregistration residuals are then identified as bad data and are removed. Note that to mitigate long-wavelength errors (e.g., tilt) (e.g.,86) in DEMs, we divide these DEMs into 2 km by 2 km tiles and carry out the coregistration and bundle adjustment within the small tiles.

Automated change detection algorithm

After coregistering DEMs, we developed automatic algorithms to detect the magnitude and time of the change in the ground surface elevation time series. First, we detect the time of the change by differencing the elevation between sequential observation times. A sudden change in the time series will appear as an outlier/spike in the differenced time series. The advantage of this method is that the differenced time series should cluster around zero (within the noise and seasonal variability) if no abrupt change occurs. The elevation difference is:1where yj is the elevation in meters at time tj, and ej is the measurement noise. The largest value for yj-yj–1 will be considered as a potential event of elevation change if it further conforms to a significance criterion, e.g., larger than 3 times the root mean square errors, and the time range of the event would be between tj–1and tj. The temporal resolution of the event time estimate is mainly limited by the temporal resolution of satellite imagery acquisitions. After estimating the event time, the elevation change can be calculated using a linear model based on the Heaviside step function, as demonstrated in88. Its uncertainty is estimated based on the posteriori variance of unit weight and error propagation88. For reader’s convenience, it is reiterated here:2where y is the surface elevation in meters at time t (in years), te is the time of the change, H is the Heaviside step function, a represents the surface elevation before the event and b is the to-be-estimated elevation change magnitude, a + b represents the surface elevation after the event.

We then constructed maps of event time of change, elevation change, and uncertainty by applying the above algorithm for each pixel on a regular 2 m grid within a 2 km by 2 km tile. Examples of these maps, shown in Fig. S2(a,d), display both real surface changes caused by mass wasting and deposits, as well as noise. The elevation change profile (Fig. S2(c)) shows that the magnitude of elevation change increases with the terrain elevation. The detected time of change (Fig. S2(d, f)) demonstrates how this RTS developed retrogressively over the years, where the time of change near the headwall is most recent (2015), and the left of the area had slumping activities in 2013, 2011, and 2010 (earliest where it is furthest away from the headwall). Another characteristic of the time of change map is that the estimated time is locally homogeneous over the depletion zone, but random in other areas.

Fig. S3 demonstrates the sample products from our change detection processing, which include 6 data types for each area. The 6 data types are the elevation change map, the uncertainty of the elevation change, the time of the change T1 (date of the closest DEM data before the detected change), the time of the change T2 (date of the closest DEM data after the change), the number of overlapping DEMs in the area, and the flag of confidence levels for the estimated elevation change at each pixel.

The confidence level is classified for each pixel using the following conditions:

Estimated time is homogeneous locally;

Elevation change uncertainty < 2 m;

Elevation change <−2 m;

The elevation change estimate should be larger than 3 fold the uncertainty, and the total number of overlapping DEMs is at least 4;

Total area of the selected cluster >200 m2.

Step 2: Simple classification based on thresholds

From the elevation change maps generated by the change detection algorithm, we then classify potential RTS with a simple thresholding method. The following criteria are used for classifying potential RTS:

Surface elevation changes ≤ −1 meter, and total area >2000 m2.

Within the polygon, there is at least one pixel with a high confidence level.

The standard deviation of the time of change (T1) within the selected cluster >1 year.

For two regions under consideration, based on only criterion 1, the total number of RTS candidates is 936,370 for Victoria, Canada (also identified as Region 9) and 9498 for a 50 km by 50 km area in Peel Plateau, Northwest Territories (Table S1). Criterion 3 is designed to identify slumps with multiple thawing periods that display the distinctive “rainbow” pattern. Adding criteria 2 and 3, the total number of RTS candidates is reduced by 8 ~ 50 times.

Step 3a: Mask R-CNN for RTS classification with training set 1

To detect RTS in images and generate segmentation masks, we adopt the algorithm Mask R-CNN (Region-Based Convolutional Neural Network)89, which has been widely recognized as a promising semantic segmentation algorithm across broad scientific applications (e.g.,90, 91, 92, 93–94). Mask R-CNN extends the previous Faster R-CNN architecture95 to include pixel-level segmentation on top of bounding box recognition. We use the open-source detection and segmentation software Detectron296, which is the latest implementation of the Mask R-CNN algorithm89. Deep learning models in this study are trained with Nvidia A100-SXM Tensor Core GPUs on Google Colab.

Training data preparation

We collected three bands of data as the input for deep learning. As shown in Fig. S4(a), based on criteria 1–3 only, it is difficult to distinguish RTS from other surface changes, such as ground surface changes around gullies. Hence, two extra bands of information are added as input images. Band 2 is the DEM total curvature97, which shows distinct patterns near gullies and RTS, e.g., the curvature is high and outlines the headwalls of RTS (Fig. S4g), whereas the curvature shows skeleton features along gullies (Fig. S4c). Band 3 is the time of change map, which shows unique “rainbow” patterns for RTS (Figs. S4h, Fig. S3e), whereas it shows random patterns near gullies (Fig. S4d). The 3-band images (Fig. S4e and i) are then rescaled to integers between 0 and 255, which are the input images for Mask R-CNN.

Each RTS candidate from Step 2 was prepared in a format compatible with the Detectron2 software. We applied a 100 m buffer around the outline, and then the 3-band images, RTS outlines, and bounding boxes were used as the input for Detectron2. The image sample size ranges from ~10,000 m² to 500,000 m². The RTS polygons were labeled as one class ‘slump’. The labeling information including coordinates of polygons outlining the boundary of RTS, bounding box, class types, and file size is exported as JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) files in COCO (Common Objects in Context) format to be read by the Detectron2 software. By scrutinizing candidates from Step 2 in Victoria, Canada, we manually selected the ones with strong “rainbow” patterns as the training and validation data. Training and validation data were randomly split with a ratio of 9:1. The training data contains a total of 900 images, and validation data contains a total of 104 images (Fig. S5).

Training model

Using the training data set, we fine-tuned a pre-trained Mask R-CNN model (mask_rcnn_X_101_32x8d_FPN_3x.yaml) available in Detectron2’s model library. Referring to the configuration of training parameters in the literature92,93, the learning rate (cfg.SOLVER.BASE_LR) is set as 0.00025, and the maximum iteration (cfg.SOLVER.MAX_ITER) is set as 48000, and the threshold for prediction confidence score (cfg.MODEL.ROI_HEADS.SCORE_THRESH_TEST) is set as 0.7.

Prediction and evaluation

We adopt the inventory of RTS in the Peel Plateau, Northwest Territories from Segal et al. (2016b) as the ground truth for evaluation. The inventory provides outlines of RTS derived from Quickbird imagery (0.6 m resolution) and SPOT imagery (10 m resolution). We further only selected RTS that show signals from our ArcticDEM data, i.e., the ones that coincide with our RTS candidates from Step 2. The selected 83 RTS in a 50 km by 50 km area in Peel Plateau are used as ground truth (Fig. S5b).

After training, the model prediction is applied to test images for evaluation. The output of prediction for each image is the 2D mask of classified RTS. We remove all clusters with an area of less than 2000 m2. To evaluate the performance of deep learning classification, we adopt the metric intersection over union (IoU). IoU is defined as the ratio of the intersection of two areas to the union of two areas. The threshold for IoU is set as 0.1. A polygon is classified as a true positive if the IoU is larger than the threshold, and a false positive if otherwise.

As shown in Fig. S5b and Table S2, there are 83 true positives in this 50 km by 50 km tile area in the Peel Plateau. The criteria 1–3 in Step 2 can successfully recover 77 true positives yet failed to filter out 1161 false positives. The deep learning results can reduce the number of false positives by 23%. We further combine the two solutions, by only selecting candidates that have more than 50% of areas classified as RTS by deep learning. This combination of deep learning and criteria 1–3 reduces the number of false positives by 3 times from 1161 to 357. This combination, by requiring the agreement of two methods to be better than 50%, removes a large number of false positives. As demonstrated in Figure S6a, for the ground truth Slump FM327, the cluster from criteria 1–3 and deep learning show a good agreement, yielding a true positive. For the uppermost cluster, the deep learning indicated pixels (red) are much less than that from criteria 1–3 (white), which indicates bad agreements, leading to a rejection of that cluster. However, a substantial number of false positives still remain, leading to a low precision of 17% (Table S2).

Step 3b: Mask R-CNN for RTS classification with training set 2

After the first iteration of applying the deep learning algorithm (from training data set 1) on several regions, we further manually selected a group of RTS across broader regions as a second training data. The manual selection of training data sets was conducted in QGIS, by visually scrutinizing each candidate shapefile on top of the time of change base map. The candidate shapefile that encloses an area with the “rainbow” pattern is classified as a true RTS. The dataset is randomly split into training and validation sets at a 9:1 ratio, resulting in 1660 training images and 189 validation images (Fig. S7).

Data augmentation and ensemble modeling

Considering that the available training data size is relatively small, data augmentation techniques (e.g.,91,92) were applied to minimize overfitting. The adopted data augmentation includes rotation, translation, rescaling, and flipping, which increases the sample size by 25 times. The precision and recall of five different models are compared for Peel Plateau as shown in Table S3. The overall issue is that the results have too many false positives, which yield a low precision. Data augmentation in fact unfavorably increases the number of false positives, e.g., 524 vs 357 for model 1aug (with augmentation) and model 1 (without augmentation). Using the training data set 2, the number of true positives increases slightly, but the number of false positives also increases. The ensemble model is retrieved by applying a logical AND operator to all individual model outputs. Since individual models may detect different false positives, when combined, the overlap of common false positives reduces, hence enhancing the precision (Fig. S6b). For the test area in Peel Plateau, the ensemble combination of five models (Table S3) reduces the number of false positives from 357 to 210. Yet, the precision remained low, only 24%.

The prediction performance shows regional variations due to different land cover and environmental settings such as vegetation cover, snow and ice cover, and water bodies. Further evaluation is carried out in Eureka, Canada (Fig. S5c56), which represents the Arctic desert environment with little vegetation. There are 45 RTS as ground truth in this test area manually examined by subject experts. Due to minimal impact from vegetation changes, the ensemble model achieves a considerably higher precision of 65% and a recall of 77% (Table S3). The performance differences across land cover types indicate limited spatial transferability of our method.

Step 4

After deep learning, we carried out a full visual inspection to ensure reliable results and achieve high precision. We visually assessed the polygons based on Google satellite images and the “rainbow” patterns in the time of change maps derived in this study. Additional visual inspection using ESRI satellite imagery basemap, Yandex Maps satellite imagery basemap and multi-year PlanetScope satellite imagery were carried out. Randolph glacier inventory maps98 were also used to mask out glacier areas. We further used a priori information for references including ground ice content maps54 and published RTS (Fig. S8). The final selection of RTS is listed in Table S4, which includes a total of 2747 RTS.

Population size and volumetric estimation of small RTS

Two avenues were pursued to model the total volumetrics of small RTS ( <10,000 m2), namely area-frequency distribution modeling and through comparisons with detailed manual RTS inventories.

The active RTS detected in this study yield a power law area-frequency distribution (Fig. S11a), which can be modeled using equation:where A is the RTS headwall expansion area observed between 2012–2022 (m2), p is the probability density, and are coefficients. The fitting of the area-frequency distribution yields =2.5 ± 0.2, =(2.7 ± 0.5) × 10−5. This power law distribution indicates that the number of RTS increases as the headwall expansion area decreases. The modeled parameters predict that the number of small active RTS (headwall expansion area <10,000 m2) is about 2244 (upper-bound: n = 3444). Considering the area-volume relationship (next section), the estimated total volume of small active RTS is about 18 × 106 m3 (upper-bound: 27 × 106 m3), which is a small percentage (5–8%) of the estimated total volume of small and medium to large RTS ((317.0 ± 0.3) × 106 m3). This prediction is consistent with the observation of 83 RTS in Peel Plateau (Fig. S5b), where small RTS (2000 m2 ≤expansion area <10,000 m2) represent 45% of the total count, yet only 12% of the total scar area.

The area distribution obtained in this study was compared to eight detailed RTS inventories. To do so required careful assessment of RTS ontologies and definitions used in the respective inventories. For example,30’s inventory represents annual average area change using medium resolution DEM differencing, whereas31’s multi-temporal inventory leveraging high resolution data was used to manually calculate annual average active area changes (n = 186) given that this inventory method also included inactive and partially active RTS. Reference 100’s inventory reflect 2002 and 2018 epochs, the areas of which were differenced to obtain annual average change estimates. Furthermore, other inventories commonly cited in the literature, such as24,45,55,63,101,102 are manual single-epoch delineations that typically reflect larger RTS scar zone areas, and not solely the area of active subsidence measured within a specific time period as in this work. We multiplied the scar area estimates with a mean standardized growth rate of 1.34% (i.e., twice the long-term rate observed between 1950–1960 and 2004–2008 in55 to account for RTS intensifications in the last two decades) to obtain an estimate of annual area change. Then all samples of the eight inventories were prorated to reflect a 10-year change estimate consistent with this work. The eight inventories (Fig. S12a,b) were characterized by a substantial number of small RTS (with active subsidence area <10,000 m2 over a decade), specifically 82% of total counts (n = 6736 small RTS versus 1520 medium-to-large RTS). This estimate does not include inactive RTS or those active for less than a decade35. These percentages differed among source imagery resolutions and among studies (Fig. S12c,d). If these percentages are generally consistent across the Northern Hemisphere we would expect that the number of areas undergoing RTS detected in this study (n = 2747) represents about 18% of all active RTS over a decadal period, for a total Northern Hemisphere population of small RTS of 12,514. Considering the area-volume relationship, the estimated total volume of small active RTS based on this population estimate is 63.6 × 106 m3, which is 17% of the combined estimated total volume of small and medium to large RTS.

Area-volume relationship

The volume of thawed material scales exponentially with RTS area8,31. Rates of RTS expansion and intensification across scales (or landslides in general) are typically quantified using area-volume allometry, which is a structural trait and an important indicator of potential nonlinearity effects31,103. The 2747 active RTS from this study provided a precise estimation and interpretation of allometric model coefficients for regional populations as well as the Arctic as a whole using high spatial resolution data:where, A is the retrogressing headwall area (m2), V is the corresponding volume loss (m3), is the scaling factor, is the scaling exponent31. As shown in Fig. S11b, the power-law relationship between headwall area and volume is evident and convergent in our product. A least-squares adjustment yields = 1.30 ± 0.01 and =−0.83 ± 0.05, with most regions clustered around = 1.24 to 1.33 (Table 1) indicating a consistent and non-linear headwall yield with slump enlargement across most of the Arctic. RTS belonging to the Plateaus and Plains of Northern Asia and Southern Nunavut represented allometric endmembers, with = 1.16 and 1.36, respectively (Table 1). In the former region suggests that headwall volume loss grows primarily with increasing planform area with little increase in the absolute depth (i.e., nearing linear growth model31). In the latter region suggests that the relative depth of thaw grows non-linearly but not quite in proportion to the planform area (i.e., = 1.5; self-similarity growth model31). Small differences in the allometric scaling exponent represent large volume differences, e.g., applying = 1.5 instead of = 1.4 produces a volume difference of a factor of 2104,105. This sensitivity also means that is difficult to directly compare against other studies using a landform-type definition of RTS, with8 and31 estimating of 1.45 and 1.36, respectively, based on very high resolution data in the Beaufort Delta (Canada), or using coarser data across several regions indicating ranges between 1.05 to 1.3730.

Climate variability data

To estimate Arctic air temperature, we used the surface air temperature (at 2-meter height) estimates from the hourly ECMWF Reanalysis version 5 (ERA5) data with 0.25° grid size106. CRU TS (Climatic Research Unit gridded Time Series, v. 4.07) surface air temperature dataset107 was also used for comparison (figure not shown). The precipitation data were from the hourly ERA5 dataset (total precipitation)106. The total precipitation is the accumulated liquid and frozen water, comprising rain and snow, that falls to the Earth’s surface. The mean values are calculated for all RTS sites during the selected summer months (July and August).

Soil organic carbon estimate

We used the Northern Circumpolar Soil Carbon Database (NCSCD)65,108 to estimate the amount of soil organic carbon (SOC) released in the upper 3 m of permafrost by RTS. We used the shapefile version of the dataset and the NCSCD provides a SOC mass (SOCM) estimate for each polygon within the database. We assume that the proportion of SOCM to be constant within each dataset polygon, therefore we calculated the area proportion for each individual RTS and applied this value to SOCM values. The NCSCD divides the SOCM for each 1 m interval for the upper 3 m of soil. Based on the mean elevation of individual RTS, we summed the SOCM data layers accordingly, meaning, for example, RTS with a mean elevation change of 2 m only considered the SOCM amount in the upper 2 m. Due to data availability, RTS with elevation changes of greater than 3 m still only considered the SOCM amounts in the upper 3 m. A total of 10 RTS had mean elevation changes of 1 m, 857 RTS of 2 m, 793 RTS of 3 m and 979 RTS of greater than 3 m, respectively. There were 108 RTS that were located outside of the NCSCD dataset and were not included in the SOCM estimate.

urn:contentItem:6DB2-HT21-JC11-119S-00000-00University of Exeter: Global CO2 Emissions From Forest Fires Increase by 60%2024-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:18:07ZLexisNexisUniversity of Exeter: Global CO2 Emissions From Forest Fires Increase by 60%Targeted News ServiceEXETER, England

(TNSres) -- The University of Exeter issued the following news:

A major new study reveals that carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from forest fires have surged by 60% globally since 2001, and almost tripled in some of the most climate-sensitive northern boreal forests.

The study, led by the University of East Anglia (UEA) and published today in Science, grouped areas of the world into "pyromes" - regions where forest fire patterns are affected by similar environmental, human, and climatic controls - revealing the key factors driving recent increases in forest fire activity.

It is one of the first studies to look globally at the differences between forest and non-forest fires, and shows that in one of the largest pyromes, which spans boreal forests in Eurasia and North America, emissions from fires nearly tripled between 2001 and 2023.

Significant increases were seen more broadly across the extratropical forests and amounted to an additional half a billion tonnes of CO2 per year, with the epicentre of emissions shifting away from tropical forests and towards the extratropics.

Increased emissions were linked to a rise in fire-favourable weather, such as the hot-dry conditions seen during heatwaves and droughts, as well as increased rates of forest growth creating more vegetation fuels. Both trends are aided by rapid warming in the high northern latitudes, which is happening twice as fast as the global average.

The study reveals a worrying increase in not only the extent of forest wildfires over the last two decades, but also their severity. The carbon combustion rate, a measure of fire severity based on how much carbon is emitted per unit of area burned, increased by almost 50% across forests globally between 2001 and 2023.

The work involved an international team of scientists - from the UK, the Netherlands, US, Brazil and Spain - who warn that further expansion of forest fires can only be averted if the primary causes of climate change, such as fossil fuel emissions, are tackled.

Lead author Dr Matthew Jones, of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research at UEA, said: "Increases in both the extent and severity of forest fires have led to a dramatic rise in the amount of carbon emitted by forest fires globally.

"Startling shifts in the global geography of fires are also under way, and they are primarily explained by the growing impacts of climate change in the world's boreal forests.

"To protect critical forest ecosystems from the accelerating threat of wildfires, we must keep global warming at bay and this underscores why it is so vital to make rapid progress towards net zero emissions."

Dr Thais Rosan, from the University of Exeter, added: "The findings of this study demonstrate the significance of fire geography and illustrate that fire disturbance represent a critical and growing threat to the global efforts to combat climate change.

"The frequency and intensity of forest fires in the extratropics are increasing, representing a significant risk to areas that constitute a substantial proportion of the global net land carbon sink.

"As fire intensity and severity rise, the capacity of these forests to continue storing carbon is increasingly threatened.

"To achieve international climate targets, it is essential to address the impact of these wildfires, which risk undermining the potential of forests to act as long-term carbon sinks and mitigate the effects of climate change."

Threats to carbon storage

Forests are of worldwide importance for carbon storage, with their growth helping to remove CO2 from the atmosphere and reduce rates of global warming.

They also play a crucial role in meeting international climate targets, with reforestation and afforestation schemes being implemented to remove carbon from the atmosphere and offset human CO2 emissions from hard-to-abate sectors such as aviation and certain industries.

The success of these schemes relies on carbon being stored in forests permanently, and wildfires threaten that.

Extratropical fires are already emitting half a billion tonnes more CO2 than two decades ago, and the long-term effect depends on how forests recover. More widespread and severe forest fires are a sign that emissions are now out of balance with the carbon captured by post-fire recovery.

Dr Jones, a NERC Independent Research Fellow, said: "The steep trend towards greater extratropical forest fire emissions is a warning of the growing vulnerability of forests and it poses a significant challenge for global targets to tackle climate change.

"We know that forests rebound poorly after the most severe fires, so there is huge interest in how the observed increases in fire severity will influence carbon storage in forests over the coming decades. This demands our close attention."

Escalating wildfire impacts masked until now

Significantly, the increased emissions from forest fires contrasts with the reduced burning of the world's tropical savannahs during the same period. Previous studies have shown that, since 2001, the area burned by all fires (forest and non-forest) fell by a quarter globally, mainly due to this.

The latest findings are important because forest fires burn more severely and release larger amounts of harmful smoke to the atmosphere than savannah grassland fires, presenting major threats to those living near fires and to more distant communities exposed to poor air quality caused by smoke.

The authors say the study debunks the narrative that falling overall annual area burned by fire globally means falling wildfire impact.

"Until now, reduced burning in the already fire-prone savannahs and grasslands has masked increases in forest fire extent and severity that are hugely consequential for society and the environment," said Dr Jones. "Our work shows that fires are increasingly happening where we don't want them to - in forests, where they present the greatest threat to people and to vital carbon stores."

Managing wildfires

Machine learning was key to unlocking new observations about the shifting global geography of forest fires. It was used to group the world's forest ecoregions into 12 distinct pyromes, allowing the researchers to isolate the effects of climate change from other influencing factors such as land use.

This knowledge also reveals new insights into which strategies can be most effective for mitigating wildfires and protecting forests. Dr Jones said: "Substantial financing is required to support strategic programs of forest management, stakeholder engagement, and public education, all of which represent a meaningful shift of fire management strategy from largely reactive to increasingly proactive.

"For example, priority areas for forest management and fire breaks must be defined based on proactive monitoring of forest productivity, particularly in the extratropics. Managing fuel loads in places where they could present greatest danger during fire-favourable weather is a key priority for limiting the severity and impact of fires when they do occur."

The paper is entitled: "Global rise in forest fire emissions linked to climate change in the extratropics."

The work was supported by funders including the UK Natural Environment Research Council (NERC), European Commission Horizon 2020 programme, and European Space Agency.
